Another thing to note is that we often average the loss across the mini-batches and therefore your gradients also get averaged across the size of the mini-batch. And this is to prevent large changes in the learning rate if your batch size changes, though if you choose a batch size of 32 examples to calculate the loss over, but then the next day choose 128 examples, then you'll be taking much larger steps and you'll have to change the learning rate or tune their learning rate again.</p><p> And so averaging over the amount of elements in the mini-batch itself allows you to be a little bit invariant to this defect. Gradient descent is guaranteed to convert under some limited conditions. For example, the learning rate has to be appropriately reduced throughout training. Of course, the theory doesn't actually tell us in real world cases how to decrease this learning rate. And so, in practice, all we can do is try out different things empirically.</p><p> Also, gradient descent converges to a local minima, that is small changes in the weights from the local minima would not decrease the law. However, that's not to say that there's a whole new set of parameters somewhere in weight space that can do much better. Finally, it turns out that some of the local minima that it finds in practice are still pretty good if the model is trained well. And so this is why deep learning works really well because even though it finds local minima, the local minima, I find tend to be really strong, especially compared to prior methods. We know how to compute the model output and the loss function.</p><p> The big question is how do we compute the partial derivative of the loss with respect to a particular weight? There is a whole class of different ways to do this. We can perform manual differentiation, meaning that we'll calculate through analysis and our knowledge of calculus, what the actual derivative comes out to be. We can apply symbolic differentiation tools. We can apply numerical differentiation tools, or we can do automatic differentiation, which actually does it for us. We'll talk about this later.</p><p> In most cases, manual differentiation is very labor intensive. And in some cases, we can't really compute the closed form solution for that if we have a very complex function. This is also true for symbolic differentiation, which only work for some classes of function. Numerical differentiation. On the other hand, we can do for any function, but it's very computationally intensive.</p><p> And you can have numerical issues, as well. And so really in deep learning and deep learning frameworks that already do this, they actually mostly use automatic differentiation. For some functions, we can analytically derive the partial derivative. And I think it's instructive to do so in order to see how it's done. So let's take a very simple example.</p><p> We have a function, which is the model and it's a very simple linear model, w transpose x, and that's it. Our last function is gonna be the difference between the ground truth y and w transpose x, which is the output of our model, and we'll square that difference. So we can now actually derive the update rule that we should be using for gradient descent, let's do that. The loss function is just the summation over all of the examples in our data set. If we have n examples in our data set, we essentially sum up the loss for each example k.</p><p> The loss for each example k is just yk- w transpose xk squared. Gradient descent tells us that we should update w as follows to minimize the loss, we should update wj as wj minus the gradient, the partial derivative of the loss with respect to wj, multiplied by a learning rate so that we don't take too large of a step. So the key question is what is the partial derivative of the loss with respect to wj? So we can write this out. First, we can move the partial derivative inside summation, and then if you remember from calculus class, the derivative of something squared is just two times within five times the derivative of what's inside. Now we can, for simplicity, define delta k, which is just the difference between the ground truth yk and our model, w transpose xk.</p><p> Now we can reorder some terms, we have -2 which we can move out, the negative comes from the last part of the term which is the partial derivative of yk minus w transpose xk. Because yk has nothing to do with wj, then it's essentially the derivative of that with respect to wj is just the row so it goes away but we still have that negative part. So we just move that negative into the front. And then we can essentially write out the w transpose xk into the actual dot product that we have to do. So for each wi, we multiply it with xki.</p><p> And so what's interesting here is that the partial derivative of this term, this summation, with respect to wj is really causing most of the terms to be zero because when i is not equal to j, then none of those weights actually affect wj. In other words, when wj is modified a little bit, then those terms don't change at all, and so those turn to zero. And so in the end, we really only have one thing, which is the partial derivative of wj times xkj with respect to wj. And the partial derivative of that is just xkj. And so, again, all of the terms within the summation in the dot product actually go away.</p><p> And all we have is that the partial derivative of the loss with respect to this one weight wj is just -2, times the summation over the data set of delta k, which is the difference between yk and the output of our model for xk, and multiplied by xkj. And so as you can see on the lower left, that is gonna be our update rule. If you notice, our partial derivative of the loss with respect to wj was negative, but because the gradient descent rule tells us to take the negative gradient direction, it turns into a positive. If we add a non-linearity, such as a sigmoid, the derivation becomes more complex, although we could still do it. If you remember the sigmoid function is 1 over 1 plus e to the negative x, we can actually derive, but we won't show that here that the derivative of the sigmoid function is actually pretty simple.</p><p> It's just the sigmoid function times 1 minus the sigmoid function. So our function now, our model will be not just w transpose x, which is what's inside the parentheses, but the sigmoid of that. So again, we're adding a non-linearity on top of the linear function. Our loss is just as before, it's the summation over our entire data set of the yi minus the model squared. So what we need to compute is the partial derivative of the loss with respect to wj, the one particular parameter wj.</p><p> Again, just as before, the derivative corresponds to two times the function itself, times the derivative of what's inside. We can again move the negative out, and we can just notate that the derivative of the sigmoid function is just sigmoid prime here. And we also need to take the derivative of what's inside the sigmoid function. So we add that at the end, which is the derivative of the w transpose x with respect to wj. And it actually can be simplified into this form.</p><p> We first define delta i just as before, which is the difference between why the ground truth and our function our model. We also define di which is just a dot product, w transpose x, which is the summation of wk times xik. So if we do that, we can actually just write out this partial derivative of the loss with respect to wj as the summation over our data set times -2 times delta sub i times the sigmoid of d sub i, which is again, just the dot product, times 1 minus the sigmoid of e sub i times x sub ij. Now I know this is a lot of notation so I do encourage you to work out all of this by yourself just so that you get some experience working out partial derivatives which is a really important thing to know for this course. So the update rule will be, again, the negative gradient.</p><p> So wj will be updated to be wj + 2 times the learning rate, times the summation. So again, it's a little bit more complex, but we can actually write a closed-form solution for this. Now if you noticed, even analytically deriving the partial derivative of the loss with respect to particular parameters, for a pretty simply function, a sigmoid of a linear function is actually not that nice. It's a little bit messy. And so what we wanna do is rather than have to by hand derive this partial derivative, we're gonna try to simplify the problem.</p><p> We're gonna decompose the complicated function into modular sub blocks. And this will allow us to develop a generic algorithm that can work on these sub blocks to derive the partial derivative. So what we're gonna do, is given a library of simple functions, including addition, subtraction, multiplication, sin, cosin, log, and exponential, we're gonna compose it into a more complicated function. For example, negative log of sigmoid function. And this, again, is just the typical logistic machine learning algorithm and so what we're gonna do is decompose that complex function into a set of modular subblocks.</p><p> Under the left side, we have the innermost part of the function, w transpose x, that gets output into an intermediate variable u, which goes into the next sub block, which is, again, the logistic or sigmoid function, that gets output into another intermediate variable p. And then we just compute the negative log of p, which is our loss function and that is the final output of the model. So we've taken a logistic regression kinda model and decompose that into a set of simple sub blocks. This will allow us to develop a generic algorithm to perform the differentiation that we want which is the partial derivative of the loss with respect to intermediate variables here. For example, we may want the partial derivative of the loss with respect to u, or at the end, we want the partial derivative of the loss with respect to w because that is ultimately what gradient descent wants to update.</p><p> And so we're gonna develop a generic algorithm that takes these modular sub blocks and does it in a much simpler way than by hand deriving the analytic forms.






<h1>06  Linear Algebra View  Vector and Matrix Sizes</h1><strong>M1L01</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll take a linear algebra view of what we've covered before, and look at the specific vectors and matrices and their sizes, as they are involved in this gradient descent algorithm. So if you remember, a simple linear model is just W transpose x, we actually have the +b term which is tucked into the W. And so the actual sizes of these is the size of W has c rows because there are c classes in this. And so we have c different classifiers essentially, and then d + 1 where d is the dimensionality of the input, and we add 1 because of this bias term. The size of x on the other hand is again, just d + 1.</p><p> Let's take a look at some convention with respect to the sizes of derivatives. The size of derivatives for scalars, vectors, and matrices are as follows. Assume that we have a scalar s which is one-dimensional. We have a vector v which is m-dimensional. And then we have a matrix M which is k by l.</p><p> Now what is the size of the partial derivative of v with respect to s, or a vector with respect to a scalar? The size is actually m by 1, which is a column vector of size m. Each element of this column vector is the partial derivative of a particular element in v with respect to s. What is the size of the partial derivative of a scalar s with respect to a vector v? Here, it's a row vector of size m, where again, each element is the partial derivative of the scalar with respect to each element in the vector. Now what is the sign of the partial derivative of a vector v1 with respect to another vector v2? In this case, it's actually a matrix called the Jacobian, which contains all the partial derivatives with respect to v1 and v2. Specifically, for row i and column j, it has the partial derivative of v1i with respect to v2j.</p><p> And so this tells us the interaction between each element in v1, and each element in v2, and that's why it's a squared form. So again this tells us that for each small change in v2, and element in v2, how does that affect all the elements of v1? And so on for all elements of v2. So what is the size of the partial derivative of a scalar with respect to a matrix? Again, it's a matrix, here the scalar is just one number. And so all we have is all the elements in the matrix essentially give us the partial derivative of the scalar with respect to each element in the matrix. So in deep learning, what we actually care about is the change in loss with respect to w, the partial derivative of the loss with respect to W.</p><p> So what is the dimensionality of that? Can you figure it out? Remember that the loss is a scalar, and W is often a matrix. And so the Jacobian is a matrix as well. What we have is a matrix specifying the change in loss with respect to any one parameter in the W matrix. And so this is really what we need in order to perform gradient descent. As mentioned earlier, gradient descent works in batches of data.</p><p> And when this data is for example, matrices, if you have an image or tensors if you have a multi channel image, then these gradients tend to turn into tensors. For example, if you have each instance being a vector of size m, our batch is of size B times m. If each instance is a matrix, for example our grayscale image, an image with one channel of size W times H, then our batch is B times W times H. If each instance is a multi-channel matrix, for example of color image, then our batch becomes B times C times W times H, where C is the channel. And so, when we compute gradient with respect to these types of input, it becomes a bit unwieldy.</p><p> What we do instead of turning Jacobians into tensors, is flattening out everything into vectors. And so all inputs become vectors, and then we get a vector of derivatives. This can also be done for particular derivatives between two vectors, two matrices, or two tensors. That is really the conceptually simple way to think about things.






<h1>07  How is Deep Learning Different  Hierarchical Compositionality</h1><strong>M1L01</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll cover how deep learning is different from traditional machine learning algorithms that you may know about already. So what is deep learning? There are several concepts that deep learning employs to be successful, and several terms that are used in association with it, for example, representation learning. Unlike prior machine learning methods, deep learning takes in the raw data such as images, audio and text, and automatically learns a feature representation for that raw data. That representation is often compact to dimensionality is reduced severely. In order to really take out the key features that are important to perform the underlying tasks such as image classification, or audio text classification.</p><p> Neural networks are by far the most dominant way to implement deep learning methods. Although note that other probabilistic models and methods can also be considered deep. Finally, deep learning can tackle using the same underlying technique a range of machine learning problems, including unsupervised learning, reinforcement learning, and so on. And so all of these concepts really are what define deep learning. There are three main kind of concepts that we'll cover here in order to differentiate deep learning from prior methods.</p><p> The first is that deep learning is one that is hierarchical or compositional. We will have a cascade of linear and non-linear transformation and multiple layers of representations that are learned. There's also the concept of end-to end learning, meaning that we will feed in raw data. We will have some very complex model with many parameters, and then we'll have an output. And then we'll end-to-end optimize this entire chain from input, to model, to output.</p><p> And hence, we're gonna also learn feature extraction. We're not going to perform hand engineering of features that will feed deep learning, just like we did in prior machine learning methods. Instead, we will automatically learn these features. And finally, deep learning will have a distributed representation that is learned. No single neuron in the neural network will encode one particular thing or everything.</p><p> Each neuron will encode some mixture of complicated thing and it will be hard to disentangle what exactly each neuron is capturing. But over multiple neurons, we'll be able to have a very rich representation that is sufficient to capture what we need to perform successful classification and regression. From your prior machine learning class, you probably realized the importance of feature engineering or feature extraction. In traditional machine learning for each modality such as vision, speech, or text in natural language processing, an expert had to determine what features are important in the raw data. In order to feed those features into a particular classifier such as, support vector machine or random force.</p><p> And so this is a very cumbersome process where for each new modality, an expert is needed in order to extract and figure out these features. A key idea in deep learning is to learn these features rather than hand engineer them. One of the key principles by which we can do this is hierarchical compositionality. Specifically the world is compositional, no matter what modality of data you're dealing with. In vision, we have pixels that create edges, we have what are called motifs such as circular shapes or corners that we can detect.</p><p> We have object parts and then entire object and so on. In speech we have samples that are forming spectral bands that then define things like phonemes and words. And in natural language processing, we have characters and words and clauses and sentences and stories and so on. One of the key features of deep learning is that we will be able to automatically learn feature representations. And the reason we can do this is because we will have hierarchical or compositional models that mirrors this natural compositionality in the world.</p><p> Because we mirror what actually is the structure in the real world, we're able to more easily learn features. The way we achieve this is by making our models themselves compositional. This is not a new idea. For example, in boosting or Kernel based methods, often we had a linear combination of different elements. Similarly, in deep learning, we will have a composition of very simple function to form a very complex function.</p><p> However, the composition will become very deep in that we'll have a very large number of modules all sequence together in various structures. And so we can really form very complex functions that form rich representations for our data. The key power of this idea is we're not limited to any particular function. We can have logs, cosines, exponential and so on. Really, we can have any function that is differentiable.</p><p> And as long as that function is differentiable, we can put it in with other modules arbitrarily. Here's a concrete example showing how we can take an image and learn a compositional representation for that image, such that by the end, we learn representations that are very discriminative. To determine whether the image contains a car or something else. This shows a visualization of the actual features that are learned at a low level. These are low-level edge based features that are actually very similar to those learned in the brain at the early visual system.</p><p> For mid-level features, you can see that the model has learned things like circular shapes or corners and so on, these are called motifs. And so it's able to learn again mid-level representations that are more abstract than the low level ones. At the high level, it can learn things like object parts, and so on. And so each level here is composing information from the earlier levels. So for example, edges are combined to form things like corners and quarters and shapes are combined to form objects parts.</p><p> And finally, the object parts are so discriminative for the classes, such that we can actually employ any trainable classifier including support vector machines or traditional machine learning methods. The key thing is that you can see nice features that are learned here after a long training period. However, these are actually initialized randomly, so if we just saw them in the beginning, they would just be speckled noise. And over time through gradient descent and the optimization procedure, the model becomes better and better and is actually able to automatically learn that it should have low level, mid level and high level features. And this is one of the key powers that deep learning has that did not exist in traditional machine learning.</p><p>






<h1>08  How is Deep Learning Different  EndtoEnd Learning</h1><strong>M1L01</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll discuss how deep learning models are not only compositional, but they can be optimized end to end using just raw data. One term that is strongly associated with deep learning is end-to-end learning. Here the idea is that learning is applied to the entire spectrum from raw data to feature extraction to classification. And so, again, in contrast to traditional machine learning, we will actually learn features automatically from raw data. As mentioned before, traditional machine learning employed handcrafted feature extraction.</p><p> And so this is limiting, because for each modality a number of experts have to develop these features in order to determine what's important. And not only that, but each modality, such as images for example, have many different features that different researchers have developed. And it's not clear which are the best features to employ for your particular application. And so traditional machine learning employed feature extraction through hand-engineered methods and then learned a classifier. Deep learning, on the other hand, moves this back, such that, again, we are only given the raw data.</p><p> And then all of the other things after that, including feature extraction, are automatically learned. So while shallow models use fixed, hand-crafted features and then learned a classifier, deep learning, again, on the other hand learned trainable feature transformation and then at the end learns classifiers. And the line between feature extraction and classification is actually rather blurry. We have a deep model that has many different compositional parts. And at each portion there's some complex transformation that is learned for the data.</p><p> And then by the end the key idea is to learn very separable feature representation that can be easily classified.






<h1>09  How is Deep Learning Different  Distributed Representations</h1><strong>M1L01</strong><hr><p>In this lesson we'll talk about how deep learning is different in terms of distributed representation a 3rd aspect that's interesting in deep learning is that employers distributed representation that is no single value in the model also known as it there on encode everything and no single neuron in code one particular think either it's really the concert of multiple values or multiple the rod in the representation working together that really forms its richness and allows us to perform successful tasks such as classification.</p>

<p>Here's an example of local vs distributed representation suppose that you would like to classify a set of shapes you can employ a sparse representation similar to a white hot representation where each node represents one particular shape the for example the 1st note represents a vertical rectangle while the 2nd though dread presents a horizontal rectangle and the 3rd node represents a vertical oval and so on a more interesting representation could be one that represents key attributes or dimensions of that they that actually can be combined together to for example here there are really 2 attributes What is the orientation the other is the shape type and so we can have those that represent vertical versus horizontal and we can also have those that represent rectangles versus ellipses note that by doing this nick and then combine all to pull values together to represent many different shapes but for example if our training set only had one particular combination of these things for example there was only a vertical rectangle there were no horizontal rectangles in our training set yet there were vertical and horizontal ovals then we can still learn this representation and generalize from it to actually classify things like horizontal rectangles even though they've never been an order or training.</p>

<p>One interesting aspect that the St Peter representation is that you can perform various combinations with the if you have a local representation that actually represents vertical rectangle horizontal rectangle and horizontal ellipse biting them doesn't make much stat However if we have a distributor representation where each node represents important attributes or features of the data then we can combine them for example if we have a no that represents vertical and another one that represents horizontal and a 3rd that represents ellipses if we combine all 3 of those attributes we could get a circle so again the key power of this is that we can actually combine these representations in complex ways even though for example the training data did not have all combinations in summary there are many interesting aspects to deep learning that make it successful deploring employees hierarchical compositional structures by combining linear and non linear transformations over and over again to create a rich function and representation it employs and do and learning where features are not hand designed but rather we feed raw data and we end to add optimize both the features and the classifiers together and finally deploring employs distributor representations were no single there on includes everything we have very complex representation that can be combined into interesting way to generalize to do types of objects or pieces of data that that not exist in the training.</p>






<h1>01  Neural Network View of a Linear Classifier</h1><strong>M1L02</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll talk about neural network view of linear classifiers and talk about how to make these models progressively more complex. As we've seen, a linear classifier can be broken down into the input, a function of the input, and a loss function that is computed at the end. It's really all just one big function that can be decomposed into these individual building blocks. A simple neural network, devised a long time ago inspired by how neurons work in the brain has a similar structure to our linear classifier. And indeed, neurons do have some similarities.</p><p> A nueron takes nputs from other neurons. This is akin to the input to our linear classifier. The inputs are sum in a weighted manner. This is just the weighted sum, w transpose x, that we employ. Learning is through a modification of the weights.</p><p> And while it's not clear what learning rules the brain uses, we use gradient descent. And If the neuron receives enough input, it fires, that is if the weighted sum is greater or equal to zero, if you employ a bias term, then the activation will be high. This is accomplished through the use of the non linearity, such as the sigmoid activation function, which is really just a step function, except it's a smooth version of it. So that is differentiable. This similarity to neurons is very simplistic, but our simple and incomplete understanding of how neurons work is actually how neural networks came to be developed in the 1950s and beyond.</p><p> However, it is indeed a very naive view of neurons in the brain, which behave in a much more complicated way and in ways we still don't understand, so don't go tell a neuroscientist that you replicated the brain. In this course, we focus much more on the linear algebra and machine learning viewpoint, though some terminology such as activations still linger. Continuing with our neural network terminology, we can have multiple neurons connected to the same input. This corresponds to the multi class classifier that you're familiar with. Each output node outputs the score for a class, for example, again, we can implement this using just the sigmoid of wx plus b.</p><p> And we will have a single weight matrix to make it more efficient. Where we just have the bias term tucked in. Again, we haven't really changed anything. We're just looking at the same thing through a neural network lens. Note that often in these visual depictions, you don't actually see the activation function.</p><p> It's assumed that each node in the output layer contains both the weighted sum and the sigmoid activation. This layer is called a fully connected layer. And it's also sometimes called a linear projection layer, because it projects some number of inputs to some number of outputs in a linear manner. As you can tell, neural networks have their own terminology that related to biological neurons. Each input or output is a neuron or node.</p><p> A linear classifier is called a fully connected layer. Even though we haven't really changed anything, this is just the multi class classifier that you are familiar with. Connections are represented as edges. This is just showing in a more detailed form the individual weights when we do w transpose x. The output of a particular neuron is referred to as activation.</p><p> This will be expanded as we view computation in a neural network as a graph and we increase the depth of the neural network. We'll go back and forth between the neural network view as well as the linear algebra and machine learning view. This is where the magic happens. And where we move beyond just a single layer multi class classifier, we can stack multiple layers together. The input to the second layer is the output of the first layer.</p><p> This is called a two layered neural network. The input layer is not counted. Because the middle layer is neither an input nor an output, for example, scores for a classifier, we don't really know what values they represent. As a result, we call them hidden layers. We will see that they end up learning really effective features.</p><p> And this is again, the magic of deep learning, where these hidden layers deep inside the neural network will be able to learn compressed feature representations that extract meaningful information from the high dimensional inputs such as images. This increases the representational power of the function when we add other additional layers, two layer neural networks can theoretically represent any continuous function. The same two layer neural network corresponds to adding another weight matrix in linear algebra terms. If you see on the right, the input layer is x just as before, the hidden layer is w1. This corresponds to a weight matrix that contains for each row the set of weights that are multiplied by the input to create the output of a particular node in the hidden layer.</p><p> And then the output layer, for example, the classification layer that outputs actual scores for each class is another weight matrix w2. If you notice, w2 corresponds to weights that are multiplied by the hidden layer, not the original inputs. And so we can really just see this as another function f of x, w1, w2. Which is the sigmoid of w2 times the sigmoid of w1 times x. So it is a compositional function.</p><p> Large and deep neural networks can be built by just adding more and more layers. If you look on the right, you can see a three layered neural network. Here, we have the input layer and then we have two hidden layers. Where again, each hidden layer takes as input the previous layer, performs the same operation, w transpose x, and taking the sigmoid of that result, and then outputs it to the subsequent layer. And then we have again the final output classification there.</p><p> Again, this increases the representational power of the model. It has shown that theoretically, three layered neural networks can represent any function. Now this doesn't mean that we've solved all problems. The number of nodes could grow unreasonably, for example, exponentially or worse with respect to the complexity of the function. So it's not clear how to learn such a function and how to learn the weights and how many nodes we'll need, for example, so how should we actually architect this neural network? So we haven't really solved the problem, but we do know that at least theoretically, they have very strong representational power.</p><p> By the way, we'll show these neural networks without individual edges usually just to simplify matters.






<h1>02  Computation Graphs</h1><strong>M1L02</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll generalize our viewpoint of multi-layer neural networks as computation graphs. Functions can be made arbitrarily complex, we really only subject to memory and computational limits. For example, we can have an arbitrary combination of linear and non linear layers, over and over and over and over again, as much as we want. And actually, we can use any type of differentiable function or layer that we want. We're not only limited to this linear multiplication, W times x, or W times the input, and we're not really only limited to sigmoid to be the nonlinear function.</p><p> We can really have any function as long as it's differentiable. The reason we have to have a differentiable is because we'll use gradient descent to optimize these functions, and so differentiability is an important concept. At the end we'll add the loss function, so again, in machine learning, we have these three elements, the input, the model, and the loss function. And so this entire composition can have some structure and can be arbitrarily complex. But in the end, we still only have the input, a very complex model in between, which again, learns very complicated transformations or features of the data.</p><p> And then at the end the loss function, which determines how well we're doing, and determines how to update all the weights that are part of the model. And again, the reason this is important is that the world is compositional, we have in Vision, in Speech, in NLP, all of this compositionality that exists in the data. Computer Vision is not just arbitrary data, it is data that is a projection of 3D real world, that has lots of structure in it. And we want our model to reflect this structure. There's also empirical and theoretical evidence that it makes learning complex functions easier, if they have some compositionality.</p><p> Note that prior state of art engineering features actually often had this compositionality as well. For example, going from pixels, to edge extraction, to object protection, to objects themselves, is something that was already thought of as useful even when the features were hand engineered. However, the key thing with deep learning, is that we're gonna employ this compositionality through the architecture of the neural network. In other words, we'll connect things in a way such that it reflects this compositionality, and that it makes it easier to learn features that tend to be composition. One thing that we glossed over when we discussed arbitrarily complex models, is that we're gonna be learning models with significant amounts of parameters.</p><p> We'll see models that will have millions or billions of learnable parameters. And there's a big question, how do we compute the gradients of the loss, which is all the way at the end, with respect to some internal parameters? For example, you see the second hidden layer here. And we wanna compute the change in loss with respect to one weight inside that layer. How do we compute that? Intuitively, we wanna understand how small changes in the weight deep inside are propagated to affect the loss function at the end, because ultimately, we're gonna try to change the weights, such that it can reduce the loss function. To develop a general algorithm to do this, we will view functions as a computation graph.</p><p> Graphs can be any directed acyclic graph, that is, it can have any structure as long as there are no cycles. The modules within this computation graph, must be differentiable to support gradient computation for gradient descent. And then a training algorithm will process this graph, one module at a time, to calculate the singular value that we want, which is the change in loss with respect to parameters of that module. Here's an example of the computational graph notion. We have a function f(x1, x2), which is equal to the natural log(x1) + x1x2- sin(x2).</p><p> As shown here, we can take this function and again represent it as a graph, where we show the input node in the beginning. These are fed into these small modular components, such as the natural log function, the multiplication function, and so on, and then we unroll the equation within this graph. One thing to note is that the graph itself may not be unique, there may be multiple graphs that represent the same function. But really the key thing is that it represents an ordering, which is to say that we know which order when we compute the function forward, we need to process the data and and later when we discuss computing gradients, we know how to compute it in reverse. To take a more machine learning example, again, just logistic regression with the loss function -log(p), which is the loss function when you get a binary ground truth value of y =1.</p><p> Again, we can decompose this function into just the w transpose x module, which feeds into the sigmoid or logistic function, and then we feed it into the loss function at the end. So again, any arbitrarily complex function can be decomposed in this manner. And why we will wanna do this, will become clear in the next few lessons, where we discuss a generic algorithm that processes over these graphs and determines the gradient information that we want for gradient descent.






<h1>03  Backpropagation</h1><strong>M1L02</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll talk about the generic algorithm called Backpropagation. Which allows us to compute the important gradient information that we need for gradient descent when we have a deep neural network. Given the computation graph, where we decompose a complicated function into its constituent parts, the training algorithm will perform the following computation. It will calculate the models outputs, this is called the forward pass. So here in this diagram, we will feed in the input h of l minus one which is the layer before this module.</p><p> We will compute whatever function that this module performs for example, W transpose X and so it could have some parameters. Although note that some modules may not have any parameters, and we'll see that later. And then we'll be able to compute h of l, which is the output of this module. We're going to then calculate the gradients for each module. And this is what's called the backwards pass.</p><p> The backwards pass is actually a recursive algorithm. It will start at the end, which is the loss function where we actually know how to calculate the gradients. Again, we've seen how to compute gradients of the loss with respect to parameters for some function that is tied directly to the loss function. And then we're going to progress back through the modules. We'll do this by passing back key pieces of information in the form of gradients.</p><p> And then we'll end in the input layer where we don't really need to compute gradients. That is the input layer has no parameters, we're not trying to update anything. So we don't need gradients for them. This generic algorithm is called backpropagation. Here's a visual depiction of the algorithm.</p><p> We're gonna have, let's say in this case, some three module function. And so it's a computation graph composed of three modules. We call them, sometimes modules, sometimes layers. Here we have layer 1, layer 2 and layer 3. And so we'll feed in the input and compute the output of layer 1.</p><p> Then the output of layer 2 is just taking the output of layer 1, computing the function and that results in the output of layer 2. And again, the output of layer 3 just takes in the output of layer 2 computes the function on it, and then produces its output. Note that as we perform this forward computation, we're going to store the intermediate outputs of all layers. In other words, for layer 1, we're not just gonna throw away the results, after we pass layer 1. We're gonna keep it in memory because we'll need it in the backwards computation.</p><p> This is because again, we need to compute the gradients and the gradients will often have equations that actually use the layers outputs or activations in them. In the backwards pass, we seek to calculate the gradients of the loss with respect to the modules parameters. So take a generic module any point in the computation graph, we'll have three different terms here. We have the partial derivative of the loss with respect to the input of the module, h of l minus 1. This is the output of the previous module.</p><p> We have the partial derivative of the loss with respect to our output, which is hl. And then we have the partial derivative of the loss with respect to our weights. Again for gradient descent, this is the key thing that we need, we need to know how the loss changes, no matter where it is. This module may not be connected to that loss function, it may go through a whole series of other modules afterwards and then be connected to a loss function. But we still need to know in the end, how the loss will change at the end, if we change our parameters within this module.</p><p> What we're gonna assume in this recursive algorithm is that we have the gradients of the loss with respect to the module's outputs. This is called the upstream gradients. This is the change in loss with respect to to h l. We're also gonna pass the gradients of the loss with respect to the module's input to the previous module. This is again to make this assumption that we talked about before true.</p><p> Again, this is not required for actually updating this particular module's weights. It's really just passing back information so that the previous layer can also calculate this gradient. So the overall problem statement is as follows. We can compute the local gradients, this is just the change in output as the input changes, or the change in output as the weights change. We know the actual function that this module computes, for example, W transpose X.</p><p> And so we can compute this. We are given the change in loss with respect to our outputs. Again, this is part of assumption that we have as part of this algorithm. And what we need to do is compute the change in loss with respect to our weights in order to perform gradient descent and take a step in the weights. In other words, update the weight through the negative gradient.</p><p> But then we also need to compute the change in loss with respect to our inputs. Again, this is not needed for the gradient descent update for this particular module. All that it's needed for is so that we can pass this gradient to the previous module. Because if you notice the previous module's outputs is actually this modules inputs. And so we can make this assumption true for the previous module that it knows the change in loss with respect to its output.</p><p> Let's go through this step by step. As I mentioned, we can compute what's called the local gradient. This is the change in output with respect to our input, or the change in output with respect to our weights. We'll see why we need the first one. That is the change in output with respect to our input, in order to pass back to previous module.</p><p> The change in output with respect to our weights is for gradient descent so that we can update the weights themselves. The reason we can compute this, is that it's just the derivative of our function with respect to its parameters and inputs. For example, we did this with our linear classifier or fully connected layer if we use neural network terminology. If the output h l is just w times our input, h l minus one, then the change of our output with respect to our input is just W. And the change in our output with respect to the weights is just our input transposed.</p><p> Again, we're just using calculus in this case matrix calculus to compute these terms. Now comes the harder part, we wanna compute for a particular module, the partial derivative of the loss with respect to its inputs, or the partial derivative of the loss with respect to its weights. What's tricky is that the loss is actually not necessarily connected to this module. It's deep down in the end of the computation graph. And so the question is, how do we compute these terms? The answer is gonna be pretty simple.</p><p> We're actually just gonna use the chain rule. If you remember from calculus class, the chain rule says that if you have a particular computation graph that goes from x to some intermediate variable y to z. The partial derivative of z with respect to x, is equal to the product of the partial derivative of the with respect to y, times the partial derivative of the y with respect to x. Intuitively all this says is that if we wanna understand how z changes if we make an infinitesimal change to x, what we need to do is understand how y changes if we make the small change. And then multiply that by how z changes if y changes.</p><p> So let's take a look at how we'll use the chain rule to compute these terms. The gradient of the loss with respect to its input is equal to the gradient of the loss with respect to its output, times the gradient of its output with respect to its inputs. What this is saying is that if we wanna understand how the loss changes with respect to our inputs, what we need to know is how does the loss change with respect to our outputs? So if our output changes by an infinitesimal amount, how will the loss change? And remember this is called the upstream gradient. This is what we're gonna assume that we're given by the subsequent layer. And then we're gonna multiply that by how does our output change if our input changes.</p><p> And this product will give us how does the loss change if our input changes. Similarly, the gradient of the loss with respect to our weight uses chain rule. The gradient of the loss with respect to the weight, is equal to the gradient of the loss, with respect to our outputs. Again, this is the upstream gradient, that is given to us, by the subsequent layer. And it's multiplied, by the change of our output with respect to our parameters.</p><p> And if you remember, again, this is something that we can compute if we know what the function itself is. Such as W transpose x, the change of our output with respect to W is just x. So now we have all the pieces, we compute the loss on some mini batch. We do this through the forward pass, all we do is we take the input, feed it through the function of the first layer. Take the output of that, feed it through the function in the second layer or module, feed it to the third layer or module, and so on.</p><p> Then we're gonna have a backwards pass. We start at the loss function where we actually know how to compute the gradient of the loss with respect to this module. This is just the exercise that we did earlier where we had a classifier that's directly connected to the loss. And we just compute the change in loss with respect to the inputs of the function or with respect to the parameters. And so we'll compute the gradients with respect to the parameters to perform gradient descent.</p><p> And then we'll compute the gradient of the loss with respect to our inputs in order to send this back to the previous layer. And then we'll do that we'll send that to the previous layer. And now the previous layer knows how the loss changes if its output changes. And it uses the chain rule to compute how does the loss change if our inputs change, and how does the loss change if our weights or parameters change. And then it'll pass back that upstream gradient to the first layer.</p><p> And again, the first layer can compute the change in loss way at the end of the computation graph, with respect to its own parameters. And note that in this case, it doesn't really need to send back any gradients because there's no previous layer. And then, once we have these terms the change in loss with respect to all the weights for all the layers, we're just gonna use gradient descent. We're gonna update the weights by subtracting the gradient. Going into negative gradient direction multiplied by some learning rate.</p><p> And so backpropagation is just the application of gradient descent to a computation graph via the chain rule.






<h1>04  Backpropagation and Automatic Differentiation</h1><strong>M1L02</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll talk about a generalized view of backpropagation and show how to compute these gradients across some specific computation graph example. Backpropagation tells us to use the chain rule to calculate the gradients that we care about for gradient descent. But it doesn't really say how to efficiently carry this out on the computation graph. And it turns out you can indeed apply this similar concept to any directed acyclic graph, where the edges allow us to represent an ordering constraint. In other words, which paths must be calculated first.</p><p> Given such an ordering, we can iterate from the last module backwards and apply the chain rule. But there's a lot of bookkeeping that we have to do. We have to store the activations when we do the forward path, and we have to store the gradient outputs for efficient computation. This is actually called reverse-mode automatic differentiation. And one of the key ideas here is that we'll decompose the function into very simple primitive functions where we already know what the derivatives are.</p><p> And so in the end, we'll have a framework where we can just define the computation graph, we can put together a set of functions that use simple primitives like addition, multiplication and so on. And we don't actually need to worry about the backwards gradients. We don't need to write code that actually computes the gradients of the function, for example, the gradients of the output with respect to its inputs, because we know that for the primitive functions such as addition, multiplication and so on, and so those can be coded beforehand. This is actually an interesting area of research that was developed independently really of backpropagation and machine learning. So let's take a look at this idea that computation equals graphs.</p><p> Again, we have the input, which is really just data plus some set of parameters of our model. We have the output which is this the loss function. And then we have the scheduling, which again is a topological ordering that is defined by the computation graph or edges in the computation graph. It tells us which computations have to be done first before further computations are done. And so automatic differentiation or auto-diff is a family of algorithms for implementing the chain rule in such generic computation graphs.</p><p> Let's take a look at a simple computation graph. Here we have a simple function f of x1 and x2. So there are two inputs, and it's equal to x1 times x2 plus the sine of x2. We wanna find the partial derivative of the output f with respect to all the intermediate variables. So in order to simplify this, we're gonna assign some intermediate variables, a1 is just gonna be the sine of x1, and a2 is just gonna be x1 times x2.</p><p> And we're gonna use some simplified notation, we're gonna denote the bar. So for example, a3 bar as the partial derivative of f with respect to a3. Again, just to re-emphasize, in gradient descent as well as in these examples, you want the partial derivative of the output, the final output of the function with respect to all the intermediate variables. And the intermediate variables in a machine learning computation graph will be things like the weight matrices. What we're gonna do is we're gonna start at the end and start moving backward.</p><p> Let's go through the computations for this. A3 bar, partial derivative of f with respect to a3 is just 1 because a3 is the final output of the function. A1 bar, partial derivative of f with respect to a1, is just the application of the chain rule. It's equal to the partial derivative of f with respect to a3 times the partial derivative of a3 with respect to a1. If you notice, the partial derivative of f with respect to a3 was already computed.</p><p> It's a3 bar and it's equal to 1. So we're not gonna recompute that, all we're gonna do is use that term and keep it in memory. And when we move backwards through the computation graph, we'll have that stored. The second part of the term, partial derivative of a3 with respect to a1 is just the partial derivative of a1 plus a2 with respect to a1. This is because a3 is equal to a1 plus a2.</p><p> And so what is that, that's just 1, because the term a2 is gone and the partial derivative of a1 with respect to a1 is just 1. And so we notice that when we roll out the chain rule, it's just equal to a3 bar. A2 bar is very similar, a2 bar is the partial derivative of f with respect to a2, we can compute the chain rule, and it turns out to be exactly just a3 bar as well. This is because the partial derivative of a1 plus a2 with respect to a2 is also 1. Now we get a little bit more interesting because we have internal parameters that are not connected to the final output.</p><p> Here we have x2 bar, which is the partial derivative of f with respect to x2. Again, we apply the chain rule, it's the partial derivative of f with respect to a1. This is a1 bar times the partial derivative of a1 with respect to x2. This is just equal to a1 bar times the cosine of x2. So we have another path, however, to x2.</p><p> If you notice, there are two paths to x2, and so we'll need to compute both of them. The partial derivative of f with respect to x2 is also equal to the partial derivative of f with respect to a2 times the partial derivative of a2 with respect to x2. Again, you can compute this and at the end it will be a2 bar times x1. Again, it's a recursive application of things that we already computed times something new, in this case, x1. If you notice, gradients from multiple paths will have to be accounted for.</p><p> And the way we do this is by just summing them together. So we'll have these two different computations for x2 bar and we'll add them together and that will be the final partial derivative of f with respect to x2. Again, this makes intuitive sense. If we wanna understand how the change in x2 affects the final output of the function, we need to basically propagate it across all paths that occur from it to that function. And so if there are multiple paths, then it essentially has to incorporate those changes across both paths.</p><p> Finally, we have the partial derivative of f with respect to x1, which again, you can work out the math, which is a2 bar times x2. So again, I didn't go through all the details of every single term here, I really encourage you to go do it yourself in order to increase your understanding. One interesting thing that we can notice as we analyze this is that different operations have different effects on the gradient. For example, if we take this addition operation, we'll notice that a1 bar which is the partial derivative of f with respect to a1 was just a3 bar, which is the partial derivative of f with respect to a3. A2 bar was similarly a3 bar.</p><p> This is because the plus operation is actually a gradient distributor. It takes the partial derivative of f, the function output, with respect to it and distributes it back across all the paths. So, if you remember when we discussed backpropagation each module passes back gradients to the previous modules. And in this case, if it passes back the gradients along the plus operation, it will distribute it to all of its inputs. Multiplication, on the other hand, does something different with the gradients.</p><p> X2 bar was equal to a2 bar times x1. So it's the upstream gradient times the other inputs. Whereas, x1 bar was almost the same thing but in reverse. So was a2 bar times x2. Which is again, the upstream gradient times the other input.</p><p> And so multiplication operation is a gradient switcher, it multiplies it by the value of the other term. Why is this important? Again, gradients are the key thing that gradient descent works on. If the gradients have a particular property such as they become too small or they become degenerate, then learning will not happen. And so one of the key considerations that we'll use as we design these computation graphs for machine learning is how gradients flow back through the entire computation graph or model that we'll have. And this is a key piece of information that we'll want to analyze and understand in order to ensure that the model is gonna be learning properly.</p><p> There are several other patterns as well. For example, the max operation selects which path to push the gradients through. Specifically, the gradients will only flow through the path that was selected to be the maximal value. So what this means is that this information must be recorded in the forward pass. So on the example to the right, if we have some output from one node or one layer that has an output of 5 and another output that is 1, and we take the max of those two values, 5 and 1, the actual output is obviously 5.</p><p> So we need to store the fact that we took the left output as the max during the forward pass of the computation graph. Then when we pass back gradients, we will only pass back the gradient through that particular element that was selected to be the maximum. Again, the flow of gradients is one of the most important aspects in deep learning. If gradients are not flowing back properly, learning will slow or stop. And so we need to understand how different operations or different functions will affect the gradients.</p><p> So the key idea of automatic differentiation, which is a generalization of backpropagation is to explicitly store the computation graph in memory and the corresponding gradient functions for these primitive elements that we'll be using. Such as addition, multiplication, sine, cosine, exponential, and so on. If you look to the right, we'll have the computation graph stored in memory and the computation graph imposes some topological ordering because it is a directed acyclic graph. In other words, it tells us what functions or modules must be computed before other ones can be computed. And so we'll just compute the forward pass or the forward function for this and compute with the value of a3 or the f value is.</p><p> And then we'll have a corresponding backwards function that will be the gradients of the individual primitives. So we know that the derivative of sine is cosine. And so we'll have that primitive stored and during the backwards function, we'll actually just pass the gradients backwards along a set of gradient functions that correspond to the computation graph. And specifically the nodes will be broken down to basic primitive computations and corresponding derivatives will be known. This is a powerful concept because in the past, when you performed neural network computations, you had to specify both the forward function for example, w transpose x as well as manually compute the backwards function for that module, or for that layer, and then code it up.</p><p> Here, we'll break down everything to very primitive elements where somebody has already coded for us the gradients, and all we need to do is put together this forward computation graph, and automatically all of these gradients will be computed for us. I should note that there's also something called forward mode automatic differentiation. This is computing exactly the same terms that we want, which is the partial derivative of the function output with respect to all the intermediate variables. However, unlike reverse mode automatic differentiation, which has a forward pass and then a backwards pass. Here, we start from the inputs and propagate the gradient forward.</p><p> So we don't have a forward pass and a backward pass, we just have many forward passes one for each input. Here, the complexity is proportional to the input size because we'll have to run forward across each input. In deep learning and in machine learning, in most cases, we have a very large input size for example, an image with a million pixels and then a very small output size for example, a scalar loss function. And so forward mode automatic differentiation is not common in deep learning. Typically, we perform reverse mode automatic differentiation.</p><p> One of the powerful things about automatic differentiation is it allows deep learning frameworks to basically build out these computation graphs as we code. So as you write Python code, in the background, these deep learning frameworks actually build a computation graph. And then getting the partial derivatives with respect to all the intermediate variables that we defined in our code is actually really easy because it just runs this generic algorithm that works on any computation graph. So here's an example from PyTorch. You can ignore some of the syntax here.</p><p> But essentially first we import some elements of PyTorch. And this is actually an older version of PyTorch, which has a little bit more complexity than your assignments will have. But we can create a variable called x, which is a vector that we initialize as some random numbers which is 10 dimensional. We have another vector called previous h and this is again a 20 dimensional vector, then we'll have weights. These are linear projections that occur from the input x to h and from the previous h to a new h.</p><p> The key thing is that you'll see as you type the code, it creates the computation graph. So we added this matrix multiplication, this i2h equals matrix multiply of the weight matrix Wx times x transpose. Similarly, h2h is equal to a matrix multiply of Wh times the previous h transpose. And you can see on the right, it built out the computation graph for us as we typed out this code and it was executed by the interpreter. When we then perform another computation, for example, nexth is i2h plus h2h.</p><p> Again, it expands the computation graph. Now, the key thing is that what we want is the gradients of the output, this final output, with respect to all of these intermediate variables, for example, Wx, Wh and so on. Cuz this will be some loss function, for example, and we'll wanna update the weights according to the loss, the gradients of the loss with respect to the parameter. So we can actually do this using one line of code. What we're gonna have is just a backwards call that will automatically go through the computation graph in reverse and compute all of the gradients of the final output, nexth, with respect to all intermediate inputs.</p><p> Again, this is a really powerful concept because in the past, in deep learning frameworks, you used to have to define both the forward function of a new layer that you added, for example, as well as the backwards function. So you had to manually compute what is the backwards gradient of the new layer that you added with respect to its parameters as well as with respect to its input. And then you had to code that up. Here, if you notice, there's nothing like that. We literally just compute the function forward in pythonic code.</p><p> And then we essentially just call a backwards function, and it automatically computes all of the gradients that we want and need for gradient descent. And what's really powerful about this is that computation graphs are not limited to simple mathematical functions. They can actually have control flows, if statements, loops, and so on. And you backpropogate through them and essentially backpropogate through algorithms themselves. So rather than program specific algorithms, which is how typical programming is done, we can program algorithms that have many different parameters, intermediate variables in them, and you can back propagate through your entire program, which includes things like control flows.</p><p> And this can be done dynamically. So gradients are computed and then nodes are added, and you can repeat this. This is a concept called differentiable programming, and it's really powerful and one that Andrej Karpathy as well as other researchers have really identified as something that might change how programming is done across their span of application. For example, in self-driving cars, there's a lot of components that are hand designed such as planning algorithms, rather than just the perception side, for example, computer vision to analyze images through machine learning. And so you can actually have an entire pipeline or program that takes in all the sensor data from a self-driving car and outputs the actual control outputs.</p><p> And you can optimize the entire program that sits between that.






<h1>05  Computation Graph Example for Logistic Regression</h1><strong>M1L02</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll talk about an example for computation graphs that's more closely related to machine learning, namely, logistic regression. Let's take a look at another example. In this case, an actual machine learning computation graph, namely, just a linear classifier, logistic regression. If you remember the input is some x, we have a binary label minus 1, plus 1, we have a set of parameters, w. The output prediction is just the logistic function of w transpose x, and this is the probability that y equals 1.</p><p> And we have the loss that I won't derive here, but hopefully you are familiar with from your machine learning class. That includes the negative log, the probability of y given x, as well as maybe some regularization. We'll actually ignore the regularization term for this case, but you can also apply the same principles to that. So we've discussed computation graphs for generic functions, such as sine, cosine, and so on. The key idea here is that machine learning functions are also functions.</p><p> There's the input model and loss function, and that entire thing is just one big computation graph. And so we can use the computed gradients from backpropagation or automatic differentiation to update the weights, the parameters of these models. So here's the logistic regression function as a computation graph again. And if you remember, automatic differentiation can carry out the procedure of calculating the gradients of the loss with respect to all the intermediate variables on arbitrary graphs. And it does this by knowing the derivatives of primitive functions.</p><p> So in this case, we use multiplication, we use division, addition, exponentiation, and the log function. And so those have well known derivatives. And as a result, in order to define this model in the automatic differentiation framework, all we need to do is define the forward function. We don't need to specify the backward function. So how does this look like? Again, we can perform the automatic differentiation procedure.</p><p> The change in loss with respect to itself is just one. The partial derivative of the loss with respect to p is just negative 1 over p. This comes from calculus. p is just a sigmoid of w transpose x. And again, the sigmoid is 1 over 1 plus e to the negative x.</p><p> Again, this is because we just defined p as an intermediate variable to be those values. Now, u bar, which is the partial derivative of L with respect to u, we can apply the chain rule for computing. Specifically, it's the partial derivative of L with respect to p times the partial derivative of p with respect to u. Again, the first term is just p bar. And the derivative of the sigmoid function or logistic function is just sigmoid times 1 minus sigmoid.</p><p> And so the partial derivative of p with respect to u is just that. Finally, the partial derivative of the loss with respect to w, this is a key term that we need for gradient descent to update w, is the partial derivative of the loss with respect to u times the partial derivative of u with respect to w. This is just u bar times x transpose. And so we can actually do this in a combined way if you wanna see all the terms together. Here it is.</p><p> Here we just unruled essentially the chain rule across the entire path. And so this effectively shows the gradient flow along the path from w to L. Again, I went through this a little bit quickly, and so you should work out these terms by yourself to make sure that you understand them. But the key point is that even for machine learning function such as logistic regression. And eventually, as we discussed, you can add additional layers that have arbitrary modules that are differentiable to create a very large computation graph or deep neural network, whatever you wanna call it.</p><p> And then we can apply these same automatic differentiation techniques in order to compute the key thing that we need for gradient descent. Which is the partial derivative of the loss with respect to all parameters in the entire computation graph.






<h1>06  Vectorization and Jacobians of Simple Layers</h1><strong>M1L02</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll talk about vectorization and Jacobians for simple neural network layers talked about how to mathematically compute the gradients that we need for gradient descent. Computationally. The chain rule can be computed via a series of operations on scalar, vectors, and matrixes. For example, we'll have scalars to scalar, or scalar to vector or scalar to matrix multiplication, and maybe at the worst end we'll have matrix to matrix multiplication. For example, here we show logistic regression, which is pretty simple.</p><p> We just have a vector W transpose, which is one by D multiplied by x, which is d by one After that, it's a scalar throughout after it's fed through the logistic function, as well as the negative walk function. And the backwards pass, where we show w bar which is the partial derivative of the loss with respect to w can be composed into these series of computations. We have essentially the reverse of what we had before a set of one by one scalar multiplications. And then at the end, we multiply with x transpose which is a one by D vector. However, as your inputs get more complex, for example to be images, as well as we have mini batches of data, not just one piece of data, then these turn into at the worst matrix to matrix multiplications.</p><p> Which are still extremely efficient on specialized hardware such as graphical processing units. And so what we're gonna be able to do is compute these forward and backwards passes extremely efficiently using specialized hardware. And then that means we can process a lot of data and perform a lot of iterations of gradient descent. In order to get a really good result. Let's take a look at specific neural network layer types and see what their matrices and vectors look like as well as the resulting gradients or Jacoby.</p><p> And here again, we're taking the simple, fully connected linear layer. We have H L, which is the output of the layer is equal to w times HL minus one. When we look at the resulting sizes, we see that HL has a particular output dimensionality. And here it's represented as a column vector. So the size of HL are a number of output nodes by one.</p><p> Is equal to W which is a matrix and the matrix size is the output dimensionality by the input dimensionality. Notice here that we can take the rows of W and these correspond to individual classifiers. If you look at this as a linear classifier we'll specify wi as being each row except that we will have it as a column vector. So here we show the rows of W as wi transposed. We'll see when we compute the Jacobian.</p><p> We'll compute them with respect to these particular rows, rather than doing it with respect to a matrix, because it gets complicated as the result will be a tensor. And the size of hl-1 is just the input dimensionality. So this shows the specific dimensionality of the vectors and matrices for this forward function. Let's take a look at the sizes of the Jacobians or gradients. On the left we have the local gradients the partial derivative of the output with respect to the input, which is just w for linear layer.</p><p> The partial derivative of the output with respect to one particular row in our w matrix, which is equal to the output vector transposed. This is not actually what we need though what we want is the partial derivative, of the loss. For example, with respect to our input, we use the chain rule to compute this. And it's equal to the partial derivative of the loss with respect to our output times the partial derivative of the output with respect to our input. This is what we get when we look at the particular sizes of these matrices and vectors.</p><p> Again, the input vector h i minus 1 is a column vector. And so according to our convention, the partial derivative of a scalar the loss with respect to this column vector is a row vector. Upsize one by the input dimensionality. This is equal to the partial derivative of the loss with respect to our output vector, which also has a size of a row vector one by our output dimensionality. We then have the partial derivative of our output with respect to our input.</p><p> This is a partial debater of a vector with respect to another vector and so the resulting Jacobian is a matrix whose size is our output dimensionality by the input dimensionality. If you notice the size is all workout and everything can be reduced into a series of vector to matrix or eventually matrix to matrix multiplications and this can be computed efficiently. In order to compute our partial derivative of the loss with respect to our weight matrix, we actually boil it down to a particular weight vector rather than doing the whole matrix by itself. What we have is the partial derivative of the loss with respect to a particular row in the weight matrix. The row is wi which, again, according to last slide is a column vector.</p><p> And so the resulting size, again, to our convention, is one by the input dimensionality, which is a rho vector. This is equal to the chain rule, which is the partial derivative of the loss with respect to our output vector, whose size is again a rho vector. One by the output dimensionality And then we have the partial derivative of our output with respect to a particular row in the weight matrix. This is again is a Jacobian matrix. But what's interesting is that it has a sparse structure.</p><p> That is we're looking at a particular row have w which actually affects a particular output node in the output vector that is a particular output node h i, because all the other weight rows do not actually affect this particular node. Output node h i, all digico Viens are actually zero except for that particular row, which is equal to the partial derivative of h i L with respect to w i. And so again we do this because if we did the partial derivative of the output. Which is a vector with respect to the entire w matrix. You'll have a partial derivative of a vector with respect to a matrix, and that is a tensor.</p><p> And we wanna avoid that complexity, but it's interesting to note that there's this sparse structure inside the partial derivative of the output with respect to each row in the weight matrix. As we mentioned, we can employ any differentiable or piece wise differentiable function. A common choice that we'll talk about is the rectified linear unit. This is in contrast to the sigmoid or logistic function that we showed before as the non-linearity. The rectified linear unit provides better gradient flow and so is preferable over the sigmoid.</p><p> This is something that we'll cover in other lessons. It's also performed element wise. So the actual function is h L, the output is equal to max of 0, h H l minus 1 the input. In other words, if the input is less than 0, then we just output 0. If the input is greater than 0, we just output that input.</p><p> If you look, this is not quite differentiable,because there's a discontinuity, but it turns out that there are sub gradients here. And so we can essentially just take the gradient as being if it's to the left, then zero. If it's to the right, then one and if it's exactly zero, then we can just choose either left or right. So how many parameters does this new layer have? Well, the answer is none. Here, it's just taking a max operation and so there are no parameters here.</p><p> Let's take a look at the Jacobians or gradients for this layer. The forward pass is just max of 0, hl minus 1. And the backward pass can be computed using the chain rule. But if you remember, the max function funnels gradients through the selected max. So the gradient will be zero if the input is <= 0, you can view this as if it's picking the zero part as the maximum, then it's not gonna funnel the gradients at all.</p><p> It'll have 0 gradients. The fold Jacobian of the Relu is actually large its input dimensionality by output dimensionality. And actually both dimensionality are the same. But again, it's sparse. Only the diagonal values will have non-zero elements.</p><p> This is because an output value is affected only by the corresponding input values. Intuitively, you can think of this as a particular input dimensionality, and H(L-1) only affects the same dimension of the output. It doesn't affect any of the other ones. And so the non-diagonal entries will all be 0. In other words, changing the particular input dimensionality will have no effect on those outputs.</p><p> So this is gonna be the final Jacobian. It'll be one if H of L minus one is greater than zero and zero otherwise.






<h1>01  Optimization of Deep Neural Networks Overview</h1><strong>M1L03</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll talk about the optimization of deep neural network. We'll talk about architectures, that is, what non linear layers might be possible to use and how you might combine them. We'll talk about data considerations such as normalization, we'll talk about training and optimization. Specifically, we have a deep neural network with lots of parameters overall, and we want to find the best set of parameters that increase our prediction. And finally, we'll talk about machine learning considerations such as regularization and overfitting.</p><p> Backpropagation and automatic differentiation allows us to optimize any function composed of differentiable blocks. There's no need to modify the learning algorithm dependent on what's inside. And the complexity of the function is only limited by computation and memory. We can continue to add more and more blocks as we want. A neural network with two or more hidden layers is often considered a deep model.</p><p> Now depth is important for various reasons. The world is compositional, we have characters and words and paragraphs and documents in natural language processing. Or we have object shapes and object parts and objects and scenes in computer vision. So the better that your model reflects this nature or structure in the world, the easier it will be to learn.
