That is, you'll require less data to learn this function.</p><p> There's some theoretical evidence that leads to parameter efficiency. For example, there are some functions where if you learn them using a two layered neural network, you'll need exponentially more nodes to learn this function than if you just had a three layered neural network. That is adding depth gives you some parameter efficiency. And as we know in machine learning, dimensionality reduction is crucial. We often start with very high dimensional data such as images or text.</p><p> And what we wanna do is gently reduce this dimensionality in order to slowly pick out more and more abstract capable features that are discriminative for our target classes. And so adding depth allows you to perform this dimensionality reduction in a much gentler way. We've described a generic algorithm that works on any composition of differentiable building blocks. So you might wonder what else is there left to do? There's still many design decisions that must be made and this can make or break your model. There's a question of what modules or layers should we even have and how should we connect them together? This can be very problem dependent, where if we know there's some structure in our data, in our particular domain, then we might want the architecture to reflect that structure.</p><p> Again, theoretically to learn the function, you don't need this. But it often makes learning much easier, and therefore you'll need less, for example, labeled data in order to learn. There's data considerations. For example, in machine learning we know normalization is important, here, since it's completely data driven, maybe that's an important factor as well. There's the training and optimization algorithm.</p><p> We're starting with some parameters, sometimes millions or tens of millions of parameters, and we wanna start from some initialization and get to a set of parameters that best models our data or obtains the best prediction. There's machine learning considerations. Everything you've learned about bias versus variance or overfitting is actually even more relevant here. We have very over parameterize models, sometimes we have more parameters than we have data even. And so there's a heavy question of how to optimize these through methods such as regularization in order to tame our models.</p><p> Let's take a look at these considerations one by one. First in terms of architecture, we have to design the neural network architecture. This includes what modules or layers we should use, and this can be problem dependent. For example, if we're processing text in natural language processing, we may want different layers than if we're processing images in computer vision. In reality, you'll see that a lot of these layers will be shared across many different applications.</p><p> However, for example, in computer vision, geometric transformations are much more important. And so you'll see specialized geometric transformation layers that are used in computer vision. There's also the question of how to connect the modules together. Again, you want to reflect the reality of the structure in your particular data or problem domain. However, one of the key things is gradient flow that is through backpropagation or automatic differentiation, how the gradients flow backwards.</p><p> The specific function that each module computes affects this and some can bottleneck these gradient flows. And if that happens, then learning will not be effective. You'll see examples of specialized layers that are designed specifically to improve the flow of gradients backwards. There's also the question of whether we can use domain knowledge to add architectural biases. The power of deep learning allows us to model any function that we want.</p><p> And we can do so using a whole range of different types of architectures. However, as we know in machine learning, there's no free lunch. We have to add architectural biases in order to effectively learn and this is especially true if you don't have a lot of data. That is, the better that your architectural biases mirror the reality or structure of your data, the easier it will be to learn. Let's take a look at some example architectures.</p><p> By now we know about fully connected neural networks. That is we take an input such as an image, convert it to a vector and feed it through a series of linear and nonlinear transformation. There are hidden layers in the middle and these hidden layers are expected to extract more and more abstract features from the high dimensional raw input data. If you notice, by design we often reduce their dimensionality or size as we get deeper into network. At the end, we have a layer that represents our class scores.</p><p> We have a node that outputs a score for each class and then we combine these to produce probabilities to make our prediction. If you think about it, this architecture is not well suited for several things. For example, images have a lot of input pixels, let's say a million pixels and the number of parameters is equal to the number of inputs times the number of outputs for a particular layer. So if the hidden layer next to this input is 1000 nodes, then the number of parameters will be a million times 1000 plus some bias terms. This is a lot of parameters.</p><p> And if you think about it, we're not really leveraging the spatial structure in the images. And so there are better suited architectures called convolution neural networks for images. Rather than tie each node into all pixels in the input, these will reflect only feature extractors for small local windows in the image that is, will stride a local window across the entire image. And each local window will have features extracted from it. Such as little shapes, corners or circles or object parts such as eyes or car wheels.</p><p> And we'll continue to do this over and over again. Again, extracting more and more abstract features such that at the end we'll have features that represent where object parts or entire objects are located in the image. And these at the end will be fed to fully connected layers as classifiers. We'll talk more about these architectures in later lessons. Another downside of fully connected layers is that they represent very fixed sized inputs.</p><p> And so for text where we don't know how many words we'll have in a paragraph will actually build a dynamic neural network. We will have a layer for each word in the paragraph for example. And the output of this layer will be dependent on both the input from the previous layer that is the vector representing the sentence thus far and the new input that is the new word. And we'll apply this recurrent structure over and over again over the sentence. Again, we'll cover these in later lessons.</p><p> The key point is that different architectures are suitable for different applications or different types of input data. And it's not always clear what architecture to apply. For example, convolutional neural networks were first developed for images but then applied actually to sentences as well. And similarly, recurrent neural networks were thought to be the best for sequential structures. But then better architectures came along called transformers that we'll describe as well in later lessons.</p><p> And so it's not really clear what architecture is best. Really, as a designer, you have to try to design the best possible architecture that best reflects your data. As in traditional machine learning, and actually even more so in deep learning, because all we're doing is feeding in raw data. This data is key, and so the first step to machine learning or data science is to really understand your data and go through it. There's also a bunch of design considerations, for example, how do we pre-process the raw high dimensional data? Should we normalize it? Again, this is very common in traditional machine learning.</p><p> And data is key. And so what we want is the most data we can in order to feed a large amount of variations to the neural network model so that as we optimize it, it can actually generalize across these variations. And so what we're going to show is that we can actually augment our data by adding various transformations such as noise or other perturbations that we think will be likely in the real world. And we can use this in order to feed more variations to the neural networks such that it can learn to generalize across them. Even given a good neural network architecture, we need a good optimization algorithm to find good sets of weights.</p><p> That is, what optimizer should we use? Thus far we've talked about gradient descent, but really a specific form of gradient descent which is steepest gradient descent. If we take the negative of the gradient and multiply it by a learning rate. What we're doing is we're taking the direction that is the steepest direction towards the minimum. However, there's may be other ways you could do this. There's other optimizers that maybe make different weight updates.</p><p> They still depend on gradients but they might depend on them differently and if you think about it, all of this optimizers have sets of biases. That is they prefer certain weights over others and so different optimizers might make more sense for different applications depending on what your problem is. There's also a question of how we should initialise the weights. If you initialize the weights such that they're very close to a local minima, then getting to that local minima is actually not that hard. And maybe it doesn't really matter that you have a really great optimizer.</p><p> Maybe an okay optimizer is good enough. However, if your initialization is very poorly behaved, for example, the gradient flow is very poor for a particular initialization, then your learning will be much more difficult and you'll need a much better optimizer in order to perform learning effectively. Deep Learning or deep neural networks will have millions or tens of millions or hundreds of millions of parameters. And so regularisation is crucial here. In some cases, we may have more parameters than number of examples.</p><p> So we need to regularize these networks in order to prevent overfitting. There's also a question of what loss function is appropriate. We talked about cross entropy for categorical data. We talked about mean squared error for regression problems, but there's lots of other types of things that we can apply. And so you can even design specific loss functions for your particular problem depending on what it is.</p><p> As you can see, the practice of deep learning is complex. For your particular application, you'll have to trade off all of these considerations together. You can't make decisions independent of each other. For example, what modules or layers you choose actually affects what initialisation you might want to use. Because the gradient flow will be different depending on those modules, and so some initializations might be better for some layers than others.</p><p> Similarly, the particular optimizer you choose is also going to behave differently with different regular risers. And as in all machine learning, you have to trade off between model capacity as crudely measured by a number of parameters, for example, and amount of data. This is not a straightforward task, and there's not really a lot of theory that tells you exactly what to do here. And this is even worse problem in deep learning because what we'll wanna do is we'll wanna have a very high model capacity. This is actually why neural networks in the past have failed because they tried very small neural networks with modules such as sigmoid nonlinearities that weren't effective.</p><p> And so there's nothing that you can do in order to make learning effective. If you start with a very high capacity model that is very rich and then regularize it in order to tame its power, then that's going to be a much more effective strategy. In other words, you always want to have enough capacity. If you don't have enough capacity to learn a very complex function, such as a function that map's a million pixel image into a categorical probability distribution, then there's nothing you can do. If you do have enough capacity, then still you'll need to tame that capacity through methods such as data augmentation, initialization, that smart and regularization.</p><p> And also relate this to the amount of data that you have. So it's a function of the complexity of the function that you're trying to learn, the model capacity and the amount of data. And there's no free lunch and machine learning adding appropriate biases based on your knowledge of the domain will make learning easier. Now of course there's also a double edged sword here if the biases that you add are not reflective of your actual domain. For example, you pick features manually in an engineered way.</p><p> And those features are not actually perfectly predictive of what you wanna predict. Then again, there's nothing you can do to improve the model. And again, all of these considerations are just things that you must trade off together at once. Unfortunately, there's not a lot of theory to describe this. And so really the best way to get an intuition for all of these things is to get your hands dirty, try many applications and explore.</p><p>






<h1>02  Architectural Considerations</h1><strong>M1L03</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll talk about architectural consideration, and specifically, what types of non-linearities you should use. Designing neural network architectures is not easy. You have to determine what modules to use and how to connect them as part of the architectural design. This should be guided by the type of data that's used in your application and its characteristics. And so the first step is always to understand your data.</p><p> You should specifically visualize it and ask domain experts that understand what physics or other underlying phenomena produced that data. Fortunately, there's lots of data types or modalities that researchers have already looked at. So if you're dealing with images, there's already a whole host of very effective neural network architectures that you should start from. And so you can always try to think outside the box and discover your own new types of layers or modules. But really starting with what is already effective is one of the key ways that you can speed up the deep learning process.</p><p> One of the key concepts that we'll talk about over and over again is the flow of gradients throughout your neural network architecture. Backpropagation lives or dies by gradients. If your gradient flow is not effective, that is, let's say your gradients become smaller and smaller as they backpropagate through all the way to the input, then learning will become less and less because you're having gradients that are small multiplied by the learning rate. And so the ultimate steps that you take in the weight space will be small for those modules. And so not only is learning not equal across the entire neural network architecture, but you can have modules that accidentally bottleneck or stop gradient flow that's effective.</p><p> Again, we'll talk about very specific modules that try to improve gradient flow. Deep neural networks consists of a sequence of linear and non-linear layers. Actually, the combination of only linear layers has the same representational power as one linear layer. This is because you can just take the weight matrices and multiply them together to form a new one single weight matrix that represents the same exact transformation. And so you don't get any additional representational power by composing a sequence of linear layers.</p><p> Therefore, non-linear layers are crucial. They increase the representational power of the deep neural network and they allow you to perform complex transformations of the data. However, this complexity comes at a cost, the gradient flow across linear layers is straightforward. However, the gradient flow across non-linearities heavily depends on their shape. And so there's several aspects that we can analyze to see how a particular non-linearity will behave.</p><p> We can take a look at the minimum and maximum of that function. We can take a look at the correspondence between the input and output statistics of this layer. For example, if we know that the input is normally distributed with some mean and standard deviation, then what is the statistics of the output after this transformation? We can either calculate this theoretically or just empirically measure it. The backward stage, the gradient flow, depends on the non-linearity itself. For example, at initialization, it depends on what the non-linearity looks like and, specifically, the derivative looks like.</p><p> In order to understand that when we have small weight values, which is, as we'll see, how we initialize these weights, what will the actual gradients look like? Will they be small, will they be amplified to be larger, and so on. We can also look at the gradient flow at extremes of the function. For example, some gradients flatten out to be 0 at the end where you have large values fed into it. Some stay linear at all portions of the function. And finally, there's computational complexity.</p><p> Some piece-wise linear functions are super fast to compute because they're just max functions, for example. Others require computing exponentials or division, and so those might be more complex. And if you add these over many layers across your neural network, then these can add up. Let's take the sigmoid example. The min for the sigmoid is 0 and the maximum is 1.</p><p> So it always outputs a positive number. One interesting thing here is that you can see that the sigmoid function is saturated at both ends. So what does this mean for the gradients? If you look at the gradients on both ends, the gradient is essentially flat, meaning that it's a gradient of 0 or a very small number. And so, the gradients essentially vanish at the ends of this function, and it's also always positive. So the gradient itself is shown here labeled as derivative and, as you can see, the derivative is always positive with the highest value when the input is 0 and vanishing on both ends.</p><p> So why is this an issue? If you remember, backpropagation works like this. We have an upstream gradient, and then we multiply that by the local gradient, the gradient of our function. Now if we received very high values as input, then our gradients are gonna be very small, vanishingly small. And so this is an issue for two reasons. First, this partial derivative of the loss with respect to the weights, which is what we use to update the weight using gradient descent, will become a very small number because you're multiplying a very small number by the upstream gradient.</p><p> And so for this particular module, if we have a small gradient, the updates of these weights will be small, meaning that we won't be really learning much. The worst issue is that we're also passing back the gradient. And the change in loss with respect to our inputs is what we pass back, and that is the upstream gradient for the previous module. And again, if we pass back a small learning gradient, then essentially even the previous module, we'll also have a lower learning rate essentially, and it won't learn very much. And so this vanishing gradient problem is not only one that's a problem for this module, but it accumulates as we go backward.</p><p> Note that also the fact that it's also a minimum of 0 and a maximum of 1 means that it also can explode going forward. So if we pass a higher value, meaning that we always pass positive values, so we keep passing higher values, and those higher values will then be fed into the next non-linearity potentially. And then it will become even larger if it's the same type of non-linearity, always positive, and so on and so forth. And so we'll have larger and larger forward values. And so there's a lot of issues with the sigmoid function, both going forward and going backward.</p><p> Also, it's not great computationally because it has the exponential term. Here's another popular non-linearity called hyperbolic tangent or tanh. It has the same shape as a sigmoid, but varies from -1 to 1. This means that it's a balanced or centered function. And so the neural network can learn sets of weights that finally balance this.</p><p> And it can also provide negative outputs, meaning it can flip the sign of different features, for example, however, it's still saturated at both ends. If you look at the derivative curve, again, it's maximal at the input being 0 and then saturates at the end, which again is an issue for learning. And so in terms of gradients, again, it has the same issue as sigmoid and, again, it's always positive. It's also still somewhat computationally heavy in that computing tanh is not as simple as computing something like the primitive operations multiplication, max min, and so on. Now this function looks completely different.</p><p> This is called the rectified linear unit. And it was one of the innovations in 2012 that led to effective deep neural network training. If you look at this function, essentially its output is 0 if it receives any negative input, no matter of what magnitude. On the positive side, it's essentially a linear function. If you look at this function, its minimum is 0 and maximum is infinity.</p><p> On the downside, its output is also always positive. And so it's not centered like tanh is, although maybe this is not as much of an issue since the gradient flow is much better, which we'll see. One of the key aspects or reasons that gradient flow is more effective is that there's no saturation on the positive end. And so the gradients can push it in any direction as long as it's on the positive side. Now what happens if it's less than 0? If you notice, the gradients are again 0 and this is an issue.</p><p> And you could actually have what's called a dead ReLU, which is a ReLU that has inputs coming to it with negative values and then it will not really learn anything because its gradients are 0. However, notice that it's never the fact that there's only one ReLU tied to any input. You have all these inputs tied to many ReLUs, and so those other ReLUs can maybe push the values of the inputs to become more positive. And on the positive side of the curve, it's a constant gradient and so it does not vanish, which is a good thing. This is an extremely computationally cheap function to compute.</p><p> It's essentially just a max of 0 and the input. Now there's been a ton of different variations of non-linearities that people have proposed. And in fact, people are still publishing papers on this. This is one example that tries to address the dead ReLU problem. If you notice, it's the same thing as the ReLU on the positive side, but on the negative side it has a slight slope.</p><p> And in fact, you can even parameterize the slope so you can add a parameter to learn the slope. And so in this case, on the minimum side it's negative infinity, on the positive side it's positive infinity. It has learnable parameters, which gives the neural network extra flexibility, and this is something that is a concept that we'll use throughout. Whenever you want the neural network to have some flexibility to learn something beyond what you're actually programming in terms of the functions, then you should parameterize those functions so that it can have a little bit of flex and can learn those parameters. Here, there's no saturation on the negative side, which is really nice.</p><p> And again, in terms of gradients, there's no dead neuron that's possible and it's still very cheap to compute. One thing you might wonder about both of these functions is this is not a differentiable function, if you notice. Unlike the sigmoid or tanh functions, they're not smooth. And it turns out it's actually okay. We can have what are called subgradient, which means as long as there's a finite number of components to the function that have gradients that we can compute, it's fine.</p><p> So for example, for this particular function, at the 0 we can choose either side in terms of computing the gradient. And on the positive side, we'll choose the right piece-wise function, and on the left side, we'll choose the other piece of the piece-wise function. I've shown a handful of different non-linear functions. And of course, the natural question is, which one should I select? Unfortunately, there's no one activation function that's best for all applications. Again, this is something that you will have to gain through intuition in solving your problem.</p><p> The rectified linear unit is the most common starting point. This is because on average across most applications, it tends to result in pretty fast convergence in terms of learning. But I've seen many applications where adding a leaky ReLU actually makes a big difference in terms of performance. Again, this is typically not a difference between success or failure. But if you want to eke out that last 4 to 5%, for example, you might wanna try different types of non-linearity.</p><p> In most cases, actually, you won't even get that much of a difference. But there are some functions that are not so great. We know sigmoid is typically avoided unless you have a specific reason where you want to clamp the values from 0 to one, and we'll see some examples of that later in the course.






<h1>03  Initialization</h1><strong>M1L03</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll talk about intelligent initialization of the parameters for the deep neural network. This is a very important aspect of optimization. Because if you initialize the weights to values that are degenerate in some way. For example, very close to bad local minima or that lead to bore gradient flow in the backwards pass of your neural network, then learning is not going to be effective. The parameters of our model have to be initialized to something.</p><p> And in fact initialization is extremely important. It determines how the statistics of our output given the input behave. For example, if you initialize the weights such that the activations tend to statistically be large. And these large activations are fed to our nonlinearities, such as the 10h function, then you'll start in the saturation range of these nonlinearities. In other words, the gradients will vanish and you won't have very effective learning in the beginning and probably not at all.</p><p> However, if you initialize your weights such that the inputs to these activations actually are very small values, you will be in the linear regime or close to it of these nonlinearities in the space where the inputs are close to zero. And so then you'll have very strong gradients to learn with. And so it actually does determine how well both the forward and the backward gradient flow occurs in the beginning of training. And the beginning of training is crucial because if it goes awry in the beginning, it won't effectively learn at all. You can also use initialization to limit the full capacity of the model.</p><p> As I mentioned, if your model weights are initialized such that you're essentially in the linear regime of all the nonlinearities, then essentially it's behaving as a roughly linear model or roughly linear function. And so this allows it to start with a much simpler sort of model than if it's very highly nonlinear. And so, this is biasing it to start with the simplest possible explanation for your data first. And then, only moving into the very highly nonlinear regime only if necessary. And initialization that is close to a good local minima will converge much, much faster and to a better solution than if you start in a bad part of the weight space.</p><p> Let's take a look at example of poor initialization. Initializing values to a constant value leads to a degenerate solution. Why do you think that is? Specifically what happens to the weight update, that is the gradient? If you think about it, each node has the exact same input from the previous layers. These are fully connected layers. So each node is fully connected to the previous layer.</p><p> And so if the weights are exactly the same, then what you get is that the gradients will be exactly the same. And since you're using the same update rule for the gradient descent update, they will move in the same direction in the same step size. And then your new weights will be exactly the same across all the nodes, and so on and so forth. And so essentially, this is what's called as shared weight because the weights are moving together, up or down, and there's no real differentiation that's happening. And so these are not good initializations unless you want for some reason the weight to move together.</p><p> And we'll see some applications of that later on. A common approach is to initialize your model using small normally distributed random numbers for each weight. For example, we could choose a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 0.01. Small weights are preferred since no feature or input has prior importance.</p><p> Why should we assign a large weight to any one random feature or a small set of random features? And as mentioned, that also keeps the model within the linear region of most activation functions. So essentially, you're preferring a simpler, more linear model across all your layers before moving on to the more complex one. This is actually a very reasonable initialization that's still pretty common today. But deeper networks with many layers are more sensitive to initialization. With a deep network, the activations or outputs of nodes get smaller as you get deeper into the network.</p><p> And this means that the standard deviations reduce significantly. You can see this on the upper right box. This plot shows the distribution of the activation values for different layers. And so the light most color that has a very small standard deviation and a very high peak around 0 is layer 5, which is towards the end of the model. Whereas layer 1, which is right close to the input has a much larger standard deviation and a much smaller set of values.</p><p> And this leads to small updates, because smaller values multiply by upstream gradient results in a small update step. And so gradient descent will make small adjustments to the weight but they're not big enough to substantially change the model or its prediction. Larger initial values on the other hand can lead to saturation. Again, as mentioned, if your non linearity for example is 10 H or sigmoid, then you'll have gradients that are very small at the end. And so we really don't want either too small or too large of values.</p><p> And we don't want this distribution to really change across the depth of the neural network. What we wanna do is finally balance this. Unfortunately, balancing this is not easy. Again, it depends on the specific modules that you pick. But let's look at some analysis for some specific types of modules.</p><p> Ideally, we'd like to maintain the variance at the output to be similar to that of the input across all the layers in the neural net. Specifically, we don't want the variance to shrink as we get deeper into the network. There's no reason to start using a smaller variation or range of values in our activation outputs, which is what that means. We also don't wanna increase the variance. We just wanna maintain the variance to be the same at initialization.</p><p> And this condition can actually be analyzed for a particular activation or non-linearity function. For example, this shows the activation functions across a range of different layers in a deep neural network using the Xavier Initialization. You can see that unlike the previous plot across all the different layers, the distribution is very similar which is what we want. Now I won't derive what the actual weight initialization is to make sure that this condition holds. But it actually leads to a very simple initialization.</p><p> What we do is we sample from a uniform distribution between a negative and a positive value. And the value is specifically square root of 6 divided by nj plus nj plus 1. Here nj is the fan-in that is given a node, it's the number of input nodes that connect to it. And nj plus 1 is fan-out, which is given a node, the number of output nodes that it connects to. And so this makes sense intuitively, because we're dividing by these values.</p><p> For example, if a particular node has a large number of inputs, then we probably wanna tune down the weights, because we're summing up the weighted summation of the inputs. And so the more inputs that we have, given let's say a particular set of weights, the larger that sum will be. And so in order to mitigate that, we can reduce the weight. Conversely, if a node has very few inputs, then we may wanna increase the weight. And so again the analysis for this can be shown in that paper to show that the condition of maintaining the variance at the output to be similar as that of the input for the 10H function can be had using this particular initialization.</p><p> In practice, you can have a simpler form that works just as well empirically. So it's not derived in any way but has similar performance. Specifically, you sample from a normally distributed distribution and you multiply it by the square root of 1 over nj. Again nj is the fan-in, the number of incoming connections. And that is a crucial factor to making sure that the values don't change their distributions at the output.</p><p> Because if you have many different inputs then the weighted summation will blow up. These analyses hold for the tanh or similar activation functions. And so again, for each new activation function that you'd like to try, you need to do a similar analysis, either theoretical or empirical. And actually, people have done this for the ReLU activation, and it's typically very similar to Xavier. And this is called Xavier 2, because it just has an extra factor of 2 in there.</p><p> Again, I won't derive these but you can find them in the paper. In summary initialization matters. And the key way to determine this is to somehow derive or empirically analyze the activation statistics and the gradients statistics because both of these are affected by initialization. If the gradients are small, then no learning will occur. This is called the vanishing gradient problem.</p><p> And we'll also see other enhancements that can improve this, specifically new types of layers that maybe have better gradient flow. Again, it's important to reason about the output and gradients statistics. So you need to reason about both the forward path making sure that values don't blow up especially during initialization. And the backwards path to make sure that the gradients don't vanish or blow up. And you have to analyze them if you develop new layers or architectures to make sure that their characteristics are conducive for effective learning.</p><p>






<h1>04  Normalization, Preprocessing, and Augmentation</h1><strong>M1L03</strong><hr><p>In the next several lessons, we'll talk about data, specifically normalization of the data pre processing and augmentation that is producing variations of your data in order to beat it to deep neural networks such that they become robust to it. The data is key to any machine learning algorithm. But in deep learning in particular, which is completely data driven, that is we don't really have a lot of biases or feature engineering that's being done. Data is even more crucial, and its characteristics are therefore very important. You should always seek to understand your data before you do anything else.</p><p> And as we saw with initialization, the relationship between the statistics of the data and layers such as non-linearities and gradients, is very important. Just like initialization, normalization can improve both gradient flow and therefore learning, as well as normal forward statistics. Typical normalization methods that you might know about from machine learning apply, for example, subtracting the mean, dividing by the standard deviation, which is the most common. And you can do this per dimension. That is you don't need to whiten your data such that they're statistically uncorrelated.</p><p> You can actually just individually or independently perform this normalization. You can also do whitening, for example through principal component analysis, but it's actually not common and often not necessary. In some applications, you might get a few percentage boosts, but in most cases, it might not be worth it. In deep learning, rather than just normalizing the data at the input to make sure it's statistically well behaved, we can actually come up with a layer that does this normalization for us, and put it across the neural network. In other words, we'll put it in many different places in the network such that we know that the statistics will be well behaved.</p><p> Given a mini-batch of data [B x D] where B is the batch size and D is the dimensionality of the data. All we're gonna do is compute the mean and variance for each dimension independently. So we're not decorrelating or performing whitening or using PCA here. This shows the calculations for this four values of x over mini-batch B, we simply compute for each dimension, the mean and variance for that dimension. And given this computed mean and variance, we can just normalize the data as usual, we can subtract the mean and divided by the variance.</p><p> Notice that there's often a small epsilon added for numerical stability. So if the variances are too small, this division doesn't blow up. Note that this particular part does not involve any new parameters. But it's differentiable, meaning that we can put such a layer that normalizes the data like this in and we can compute the gradients that flow through it. We don't have to compute the change in loss with respect to its parameters because there are no parameters.</p><p> But we can pass back the upstream gradients to the previous module before this normalization layer. And we could put this normalization layer anywhere in the computation graph. But actually, we can give the model more flexibility through learnable parameters gamma and beta. Specifically x i hat is the normalized data, we take x i, we subtract the mean, and then we divide by the variance. But y i our outputs is actually just the scaled data that's normalized.</p><p> So gamma times x i hat plus beta. So if it wants to the network can learn not to normalize, it can choose gamma to be the variance. And beta to be the mean and then you're multiplying by the variance again and adding the mean back. And then you're essentially unnormalizing it, or the network can learn some parameters in between. So it's some interpolation of that.</p><p> And so again, whenever you can, it's good to give the neural network flexibility to learn additional parameters. Here again, everything is differentiable. So we can compute the partial derivative of the loss with respect to these two parameters. This layer is extremely popular and it's called batch normalization layer. And essentially, you can put it anywhere you want in your model in order to ensure that the output statistics are normalized.</p><p> Now there's some complexity to batch normalization. During training, as we mentioned, we compute the empirical mean and variance over your mini batch each iteration. And so you're essentially normalizing by a different amount each time. Because your number of samples might be small in each batch compared to the large amount of data that you have. And so there's some noise in the estimation of the means and the variances.</p><p> During inference on the other hand, we use the stored means and variances calculated across the entire training set. And so one thing to note is that during training, sufficient batch sizes must be used to get stable per batch estimates during training. This is especially an issue when you're using multi GPU or graphics processing unit or multi machine training. What those algorithms do is they take batches of data and then they split it among many machines. And so each machine might not have a big enough batch size to compute this mean and variance accurately.</p><p> There's actually a solution that for example, pi torch, a deep learning framework that we'll look at in this course uses and this is called SyncBatchNorm. What it does is essentially centralizes all the data we're computing the mean and variance and then performs the distributed computations for the rest of the network. Normalization is especially important before non linearity. As we saw in initialization, we'd like the statistics of the inputs to be well behaved such that they don't saturate these nonlinearity. We don't want very low or high values or unnormalized or imbalanced data, because they cause the saturation issues.</p><p> And so what we'd like to do is write before the non linearity, insert a batch normalization. And again, we can do this before every non linearity in our network. There are many, many variations of batch normalization. We'll see some specific ones for convolutional neural network. But the idea is that you'll have different shapes and sizes for your inputs or for various parts of your network.</p><p> And so you'd like to have normalizations that might be specific to the particularities of those types of layers. One resource that you can check out is this ML Explained normalization blog that has a lot of good information for a number of these variants. But again, we'll describe some of these when we cover a convolution neural network.






<h1>05  Optimizers</h1><strong>M1L03</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll talk about different optimization algorithms that can find good weights or parameters in order to model our function. So far, we've only talked about stochastic gradient descent, and namely steepest descent, which is only one way to update the weights. In this lesson, we'll talk about more sophisticated methods. Deep learning involves complex, compositional, highly non-linear functions. This means that the loss landscape, that is, how the loss function changes as your parameters change is extremely non-convex.</p><p> You can see some example here on the right. And so what this means is that while there's a lot of theory, analyzing convex situations and deriving algorithms for them, it's not really possible to study directly the actual types of functions that we're optimizing. And so this is not to say that theory is not useful. In fact, theory has been used to gain a lot of insight into the algorithms that we should use. And for example, convergence properties or generalization bounds and things like that.</p><p> However, at the end of the day, really there's a lot of intuition and rules of thumbs that one must use in order to effectively optimize these functions. It used to be thought that the existence of local minima is the main issue in optimizing these very complex loss surfaces. But it turns out that's actually not the case. In fact, there's been theory that's been coming out that we can actually find local minima that are pretty good, even global minima in some cases on the training set. And so it's not really the fact that we can't optimize these on the training set in a manner that's very effective.</p><p> It's that there's other aspects of the loss surface that are hindering our ability. And also keep in mind that optimizing to the training set does not always necessarily mean that you're generalizing to the test set very well. And so there are other more impactful issues that occur in these loss surfaces. For example, we obtained noisy gradient estimates because we take mini batches of data. That is, we can't compute the gradients across our entire data set because it can contain millions of examples, for example.</p><p> And so we just take, let's say 62 or 128 examples, and the gradients that we obtain have pretty high variance. There are also other geometries of the loss surface, called saddle points, that we'll talk about. And you can have ill-conditioned loss surfaces where the curvature or the gradients are much higher in some directions than others., or some parameters than others. And this, again, is difficult for learning.</p><p> In practice, we use a subset of the data at each iteration to calculate the loss and therefore the gradient. This is actually an unbiased estimator, meaning that the expectation is equal to the true non-stochastic full batch value. That is the value of the gradients if we just calculated them on our entire data set. However, that's only on expectation. In reality, we'll have high variance, meaning that we'll take very noisy steps during gradient descent.</p><p> On the right you see a loss contour where lines depict regions of the whitespace that have equal loss. What you can see is that we are taking noisy steps from one direction to the other, rather than going directly to the local minima, meaning that convergence will be much slower. Even without variance, there's several loss surface geometries that are difficult for optimization. And there's not just one local minima, but there's several, such as plateaus and saddle points. And actually, it's been found that saddle points in particular, are much more common in these high dimensional optimization problems that are induced by deep learning.</p><p> Saddle points are those that where the gradients of orthogonal directions are zero. And so you might think it's a local minima, but actually, it's disagreed on whether it's a minimum or a maximum. In other words, it's a minimum for one direction but a maximum for another. And so gradient descent and in particular steepest gradient descent, which is actually what we do when we take the negative gradient, doesn't necessarily behave very well in these saddle point regions. In particular, it will stay stuck or learn very slowly because these areas have very small gradients.</p><p> And so we can take some intuitive ideas in order to improve upon this. Imagine that you're a ball rolling down this loss surface, and you wanna get to the minimum. You might actually try to use something called momentum in order to pass surfaces that are flat. And so we actually do employ this idea very commonly in deep learning. In particular, rather than just updating by the negative gradient, we first calculate a velocity term here.</p><p> The velocity is actually updated by some beta, which is a hyperparameter, times the previous velocity plus our gradient right now. And so what this is doing is essentially decaying the velocity over time for past gradients. So beta is typically something like 0.99, and so, it's decaying your velocity and adding your current gradient. In terms of the actual weight update, you actually update by the velocity term, not by the local gradient that you have right now.</p><p> And so if you've come from a region where you have very high gradients, then you'll still have high gradients because you haven't decayed it that much. And you're adding it to your current gradient which might be flat right now, so close to zero. Yet, you'll still move in the direction that you used to move in. And again, this can kind of pop you out of local plateaus or saddle points. Notice that this is actually a generalization of stochastic gradient descent or SGD because when beta = 0, then essentially it's what we had before.</p><p> Intuitively, the velocity term can be seen as an exponential moving average of the gradient. We can see this easily by just taking the equation that we had before. vi, that is the velocity at the current iteration, is equal to beta times vi- 1, where beta is something like 0.99, plus the current gradient. If we just take the vi- 1 term and recursively apply this equation again, we get that vi is equal to beta times vi minus 2 + the change in loss with respect to weight i- 2 + the current gradient.</p><p> And you can continue to unroll this. But what you can see is that this is actually equal to the beta term being exponentiated based on how far away it is from the current iteration. And so older iterations or gradients from older iterations are much more heavily discounted, whereas closer iterations are weighted more heavily. And actually, there's a whole class of accelerated gradient methods. And a lot of these do have theoretical analysis under some assumptions that show that they can, for example, converge faster than certain other algorithms such as vanilla stochastic gradient descent.</p><p> One thing to note is that there's actually an equivalent formulation of momentum that is mathematically the same. Here, rather than subtracting the learning rate times the velocity, we push the learning rate inside to the calculation of the velocity itself. This actually doesn't change too much, but you might wanna know because different deep learning frameworks apply it differently. And so it changes the meaning of the learning rate a little bit. There's also an advancement over this momentum term called Nesterov momentum.</p><p> The key idea is that rather than combining the velocity with the current gradient, we'll actually first just go with the flow. We'll go along the velocity, and then we'll calculate the gradient at the new point. This can be thought of as, again, an acceleration method. In the sense that we already know that the velocity term is probably giving us a pretty good, smooth gradient direction. And so, we can just do a look ahead and jump straight away to that place and then calculate the gradients at that new location.</p><p> And so, you can see in the equations, we have a new weight i- 1 hat, which is just the current setting of the weights. But then we take a direction again in a beta times the velocity term. And then given that new location we are in the weight space, we just apply the momentum as usual. Again, note that there's equivalent formulations for this as well. So, for Nesterov momentum, and so just something to be aware of.</p><p> Now, all of the optimizers that we've thus far talked about are first order methods. However, there's various ways to mathematically characterize the loss surface around the current set of weights. Again, steepest gradient descent takes the current weights in the weight space and performs a linear approximation. That is, finding the steepest direction, which is the negative gradient. However, this leads to some limitations, such as requiring some estimation of what step size to take, which is why we have things like learning rate.</p><p> You can actually try to do a little bit better and perform a second order polynomial or quadratic approximation of the loss surface around the current weight in the weight space. Now, if you liked Jacobians, you can try to study Hessians to do this. Hessians, like Jacobians, are matrices of gradients, but here they're matrices of second order gradients with respect to pairs of variables. I won't go into a lot of details, since this isn't an optimization course. But roughly, it gives us information about the curvature of the loss surface.</p><p> And if we use tricks like Taylor series expansion, we can actually perform a quadratic approximation of the loss surface around the current weights in the weight space. And the advantages of this is that we can actually just jump directly to the minima of that approximation. We don't need a learning rate anymore. Now, in practice, we don't actually use these methods very frequently in deep learning. That's because computing does Hessian is computationally and memory-wise inefficient.</p><p> But actually, things like momentum actually approximate this to some degree. And so, we're getting some benefits of some of the theory that comes from this. Now, the Hessian can also tell us how ill-conditioned or difficult the loss surface is. Specifically, there's something called the condition number, which is the ratio of the largest and smallest Eigenvalue of the Hessian. Again, I won't go into details on computing this and Eigen analysis.</p><p> But at a high level, it tells us how different the curvature is along different dimensions or directions. If this condition number is high, then that means that different directions actually point to very different curvatures. And so, Stochastic Gradient Descent will actually make big steps in some dimensions and smaller steps in other dimensions. This is a problem, because what you'll have is what you see on the right. You'll have very large jumps in certain directions, because the curvature is very high.</p><p> And that means that along the directions that the curvature is not so high, you actually won't get very effective learning. And so, again, second order optimization methods divide these steps by the curvature, but they are very expensive to compute. And so, we'll look at alternative methods that are much more efficient computationally, but also roughly try to do something similar. And this specific idea that we'll talk about is having a dynamic learning rate for each weight. Specifically, there's gonna be several flavors of optimization algorithms, including terms that you may have heard, RMSProp, Adagrad, Adam, and so on.</p><p> And this is still an evolving field of research where you have every few years new papers that propose new methods. Now, we'll discuss these in the next few slides in this lecture. But one thing to note is that again, like a lot of things in deep learning, there's not really one method that will work the best across all conditions. And in fact, a lot of these dynamic learning methods where you have a per-weight learning rate actually have been shown to not generalize as well as very simple vanilla Stochastic Gradient Descent plus momentum. And so, the question is, why do people use them? And the answer is that Stochastic Gradient Descent with momentum actually takes a lot of tuning to get it right.</p><p> And so, a lot of these other methods, just like other things in deep learning on average, for most applications do pretty well without requiring tuning. Or at least not as much tuning. And so, that's why algorithms such as Adam are typically preferred to start with anyway. The first algorithm called Adagrad has a very simple idea. What we're gonna do is we're gonna have a per-parameter or weight learning rate adjustment.</p><p> And what we're gonna adjust it based on is accumulation of some form of gradient statistics. You can see this as trying to approximate, for example, the curvature or the speed with which we're going along this particular direction for this weight. The specific equations that are described here are shown, and it looks complicated, but it's not. So, we're going to have a gradient accumulator, Gi. And this accumulator just takes Gi- 1, which is the previous accumulation.</p><p> Plus our gradients squared. So all you're literally doing is squaring your gradients, and this makes it positive. And just accumulating them or adding them up as you go through the iteration. Now, when we perform a weight update, unlike doing the normal negative alpha times the gradient, which we do in steepest gradient descent. We're gonna divide the learning rate by the square root of Gi plus some epsilon.</p><p> Again, the epsilon is just for numerical stability. And so, what we're effectively doing is for each weight, basically toggling the learning rate down based on how much gradient or how strong the gradients are for that weight. And if you have some weights that have very strong gradients, that is, there's very high curvature probably along that dimension, then we're gonna tone down the learning rate. Whereas, if there are other weights that have smaller grading, then we're gonna have a smaller value in the denominator and then a higher effective learning rate. And so, that's the overall idea.</p><p> We want directions with high curvature to have higher gradients. And therefore, the learning rates will be reduced. And the directions with low curvature will naturally have lower gradients and will, relative to the other ones, not reduce them as much. Now, there's one problem with this. If you notice, we're just accumulating all the gradients through the iteration.</p><p> And so, this number naturally just gets bigger, and bigger, and bigger for all the weights. And hence, the learning rate gets smaller, and smaller, and smaller. And so, can you think of an idea or a way that we've actually discussed in this lesson to maybe mitigate this problem? And so, the solution here is something very similar to what we did with the momentum. Rather than just keep adding up gradients squared, we're gonna keep a moving average of the squared gradient. And so here you see that Gi is equal to beta, again something like 0.</p><p>99 times Gi-1 + 1- beta times the current gradient squared. And so, again, this beta term is a hyperparameter that tells us really how much do we care about the past accumulation versus the current gradient. And again, the weight update is very similar to before, except that we use this new Gi. And the advantage here, again, is that we do not saturate the learning rate because it doesn't go to zero as the gradients accumulate higher and higher. Because here we're also decaying the past accumulation.</p><p> A third optimizer that has become very popular is called Adam and it was developed around 2015. And it really just combined a lot of the methods that we've talked about thus far. So let's look at the equation. So again, just as before, such as when we did momentum, we're gonna accumulate just the gradients in a way that decay is the older one. And so here we're gonna have vi = beta 1 times vi -1 + (1- beta1) times the current gradient.</p><p> We're also gonna have the gradients squared accumulated, again, in a similar manner where we decay the older ones. And then we simply just have the same form of weight update, except this time that we multiply the learning rate alpha times the first order statistic, divided by the square root of the second orders, that is Gi. Now, there's only one issue with this. The initial values for all of these things the vi and Gi typically start out as 0. And so these are gonna be pretty small values, you're gonna update them using the current gradient at whatever initialization you start out with.</p><p> And then you'll essentially have this tiny gradient and these values will be very small. And so you're multiplying alpha by some arbitrary small value and dividing by some arbitrary small value. And if you notice one of them the Gi is a squared term. And so it depends on what the gradients will be. In some cases it could be much higher, or in some cases if it's less than 1, then it'll be lower.</p><p> And so in order to address this instability, we're actually gonna do some time varying smoothing of these values such that in the beginning, we'll try to perform less biased estimates. And then over time, we'll just converge to these actual values that are shown here. And so this is the final Adam algorithm. What we have is on top the same vu and Gi calculation, except now we have these two terms vi hat and Gi hat. Now, the purpose of these is really to stabilize the initial values.</p><p> For example, vi hat is equal to vi divided by 1- beta 1 raised to the tth power. And so as t starts from 1 to infinity, or however many iterations you're doing. What we'll have since beta 1 is typically less than 1, something like 0.9, is that beta 1 raised to the tth power will get smaller and smaller and smaller. In the beginning it'll be something like 1 minus 0.</p><p>9, which is 0.1. So you'll have vi hat is equal to vi divided by 0.1. So again, you're making this value larger in the beginning.</p><p> As t goes to very high values, it'll take 1 minus b beta 1 to the power of t to 1. And so you'll have vi hat is equal to vi divided by 1, which is just vi, and similarly for Gi as well. And so what this is doing is pumping up these values in the beginning so that you don't have very small values that blow up your learning rate. Because, for example, if Gi is a very small number, then your effective linearity will be blown up. And so you'll jump into very poor locations and whitespace and you won't be able to get out of them.</p><p> One thing to note is that even though Adam changes the learning rate per parameter or weight, and actually still has some initial learning rate alpha. So it's not like you're escaping the fact that you still need to hyper parameter tune the learning rate. And so one thing to note is that all of these optimizers behave differently and they behave differently depending on the actual last surface. So for example, if you have some saddle point looking thing, you can see here that gradient descent for example, it takes forever to get out of it, whereas Adam almost immediately jumps out of it. So Adam here is the darkest line.</p><p> And as you can see, it's very quickly goes out of the saddle point. Again, different geometries of the last surface will make each of these algorithms behave differently. And as mentioned, it's true that plain SGD, Stochastic gradient descent, plus momentum can actually generalize typically better than these adaptive methods. And so again, the reason is are used is because on average for most applications, they just tend to be much less of a hassle. You can start with Adam for your particular application, and you'll get a pretty good result and you won't have to tune that alpha value very much, or those beta values.</p><p> It's not very sensitive to those values. Whereas SGD if you wanna get a really good performance, then you'll have to perform a lot of different tuning. And again, there's very recent literature as recent as 2019 that perform some improvements on this. And this is a continuously evolving landscape. And so the final thing to note is that despite all of these sophisticated methods, learning rate schedulers that is hand coded ways to change the learning rate through the iterations is actually still pretty common and well supported by deep learning frameworks.</p><p> The theoretical results that show things like convergence of optimization actually rely on the learning rate that came through the iteration. But it's not clear exactly how to do this, a lot of the theory makes simplifying assumptions that aren't true in practice. And so there's a lot of empirically derived schedulers that people have found to work. The classic one is graduate students gradient descent. You can have someone stare at the Oscars, determine when it's converged and then reduce the learning rate, let's say by a factor of 10.</p><p> These days there are some other ones that are pretty effective. So step schedulers are the simplest ones where you change the learning rates, let's say divided by 10 every few epochs or every end epoch. You can also do exponential decay, for example. One interesting finding that recently has been developed is that cyclical learning rate schedules where you reduce the learning rate and then pop it back up again and then reduce it again, actually works quite well in practice. And so there are these methods called cosine schedulers, for example, where you're modifying the learning rate via some function of cosine in a cyclical way.</p><p> And one of the advantages of this is that you can think about the last surface being very complicated and then converging towards some local minima. Popping the model out of that local minima to find maybe a better local minimum, and so on. And so you can do this over and over again and maintain the best accuracy on the validation set. And then figure out which local minima was the most generalizable to the validation. Again, none of these things are very hard and fast rules and different things are developed over time that supersede older understandings.</p><p> And so again, these things will continue to evolve, but these are very good things to start with.






<h1>06  Regularization</h1><strong>M1L03</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll talk about regularization. This is a crucial aspect in machine learning, but especially so in deep learning because we're going to have very complex, very non linear models with tens of millions or hundreds of millions of parameters. Many of the standard regularization methods that work in machine learning still apply to deep learning. For example, you can apply L1 regularization where you just take the L1 norm of your weights. What this does is sums up the values of your weight, and so it will try to encourage the network to learn weights that are small.</p><p> That is you don't wanna rely very much on particular features. And actually L1 regularization has an interesting effect. It actually encourages sparsity, that is it encourages lots of small, close to zero values in your weights and only a few non-zero values. There's also other types of regularization, you can do L2 regularization, which again, encourages small values but in a slightly different way. You can also have what's called an elastic L1 or L2, which is just some linear combination.</p><p> And typically we have some sort of weight for this loss or regularization term. In deep neural networks, we can actually apply a more specialized form of regularization. Specifically, even with L1 and L2, the neural network can rely on strong features that really work well on the training. This can be individual features or even what's called co-adaptive features that is small subsets of features that again, are very predictive on the training set. But if they are not very generalizable features, that is they're overfitting to the training set, then you won't perform very well on the test set if it relies too strongly on those features.</p><p> In order to prevent that from happening, here's an idea. This is called dropout regularization. For each node, I'm gonna keep its output with some probability P, let's say 0.5. And this is done at each iteration.</p><p> So at a particular iteration, I'm gonna flip a coin for each node to determine whether to keep the activations from that node or not. If I do not keep it, you can see it as setting the activations from that node to zero. So essentially computing the forward and backward function is not affected by that node. So, you can see this as choosing, whether to mask out a particular node, again at each iteration. In practice, we can implement this with a mask that's calculated at each iteration.</p><p> For each node that exists in your neural network, we're gonna have a mask of zeros and 1. And a 0 means that that note is deactivated. In other words, its activation is multiplied by 0 and therefore it's not affecting anything in the forward pass. Note that during testing, no nodes are dropped out, that is, you just use all of the nodes together. If you think about it, there might be a problem here.</p><p> During training, each node has an expected p times fan_in node coming into it. If you remember p is the probability of keeping the node. And so 80% of the nodes that each iteration approximately are coming in to this particular node. During test time though, we keep all the nodes and so it gets activations from 100% of the nodes. And so statistically, its activations in the input will be much higher.</p><p> This is breaking a principle that we always wanna maintain, which is we want similar train and test time input and output distributions. And this is true for all layers in your neural network. There's a simple solution though, all we need to do is scale the outputs or equivalently the weights by p. For example, at test time we scale W test = p times W. This is essentially normalizing the statistics of the input to this particular node.</p><p> Alternatively, if you don't wanna do something special at test time, you can actually scale by 1 over p at training time. And then during testing time, you don't have to do anything else. So why does this simple method work? There's several interpretations we can have. For example, the model should not rely too heavily on particular feature or subset of features. This is because if it does so, and there's any perturbations or noise that happens at test time, then it won't be robust to it.</p><p> Using dropout, if it does rely too heavily on a particular feature or a subset of features, it has a particular probability of losing those features. And so, during forward inference, it won't do very well in prediction because it relied on features that are no longer there. And then during backpropagation, it will update the weights of other features. And so you can see it as equalizing the weights across all of the features, such that it doesn't rely too heavily on any specific subsets. Another interesting interpretation is that you're actually training 2 to the n different networks.</p><p> That is, if you think about the number of masks that you can create, the number of configurations that there are for n node neural network, it's 2 to the n. That's how many possibilities there are for the mask. And each configuration is actually a neural network. That is it defines which nodes are in or out of the neural network. And most of these neural networks are trained with only a small number of examples.</p><p> This is because 2 to the n is a very large number, especially as n increases. And so even if you do 1 million iterations of training, you're unlikely to get the same exact mask very often. And so you're training a small number, let's say 1 million neural networks compared to 2 to the n. And you're only training them for a small number of examples, let's say 1 or 2 mini-batches. And so, what you're doing is essentially having an ensembling effect.</p><p> You're training many, many different simpler neural networks. They're simpler because you're dropping those out, so they're smaller. And you're essentially trying to ensemble or combine them together at the end. Because at the end, you use all of the nodes, you don't drop anyhow.






<h1>07  Data Augmentation</h1><strong>M1L03</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll talk about a very simple method In order to prevent overfitting. Specifically, we're going to take our data set and augment it by applying various forms of transformation. Such as adding noise or different lighting conditions in images in order to make sure that the neural network is robust to such variation. The idea of data augmentation is extremely simple. We're gonna perform a range of transformations to our data to essentially get new samples for free.</p><p> This essentially increases your data set. And again, you don't have to pay anything for it. You don't have to go out and capture that data. The only caveat is that the transformations should not change the meaning of the data. So, here's a simple example.</p><p> Image flipping, we can take an image of a bird and just flip the image. We know that flipping does not actually change what's in the image itself. And we know also that in the real world, the neural network might encounter a bird in that particular orientation. And so, what we want is a range of transformations that mirror what might happen in the real world. Variations that the neural network might encounter in the real world and that do not change the meaning of the data.</p><p> There's lots of examples like this. Another one is random crop. We can take different crops during the training. Here you're adding robustness such that if the neural network only sees parts of the object, that it still has to reliably predict what it is. And by the way, you can do this not just during training, but you can also do it during testing.</p><p> Why would you wanna do this? Well, you can combine the predictions. For example, average the probabilities over all of these different crops. And maybe that increases the robustness of your prediction because it's seeing different portions of the data. And maybe if there's some particular noise that is fooling it on one crop, then the other crops will be okay. There's also more sophisticated forms called CutMix, where you're mixing and cutting different portions of the images together.</p><p> Here is another example, color jitter. Here we're adding or subtracting small or large random values to the red, green, and blue components of the image. Again, as you can see here, you're actually producing a very large set of variations across these images that the neural network must be robust to when it makes predictions. You can also apply geometric transformation. So, you can perform translation of the object or crops within the image.</p><p> You can rotate the image in various ways. You can scale the image up or down, or you can shear the image, which is what's shown here. Note that the neural network might or might not be generalizable in terms of these transformations. For example, if you give it rotations of up to 15 degrees of the image, then it probably won't be as generalizable to 30 degree rotation. And so, it really varies on the type of transformation, your model, and the input data to understand how robust it will be.</p><p> We can also combine these transformations to add even more variety. Again, the more variability that you give to the neural network and force it to make correct predictions, the more robust it will be during testing time. And if you think about it, having many different augmentations has a very multiplicative effect. If you have four different rotation variations, and four different crop variations and so on. You multiply those together, you get a very large multiplying factor of your data set.</p><p> So, even if you have a relatively small data set, you can make it really large. You could start from 100 or 1,000 images and end up with hundreds of thousands of images with these variations. Now, of course, you might not be getting, for example, different types of objects or objects in different scenes or different contexts. But you're getting some variability at least. Here's a more complex type of transformation that actually involves multiple images.</p><p> This is called CowMix. On the left you see, you're combining an image of a cat with kind of a cow-looking pattern in terms of a mask. These masks determine whether to take pixels from the image, which is the cat, or to take pixels from the noise, which is fed in. And you could see that the resulting masked image is some complex transformation. And you could see that for example, you're blocking out large portions of the cat.</p><p> This forces the neural network to be very robust to things like occlusion, where parts of the object might not be visible. On the right side, you can see an even more complicated situation, where you have two unlabeled images, one of a cat and one of a dog. And now, you're combining those two images through this CowMask. And specifically, you take cat pixels from one color of the CowMask, let's say black. And dog pixels from the other region of the CowMask, the white pixels in the CowMask, and you combine them together.</p><p> And there's a question, what should the ground truth label be here? And you can actually make the ground truth label proportional to how many pixels you took from the cat and how many pixels you took from the dog. So, rather than a one-hot ground truth distribution that has a probability of 1 for the cat, you actually give it a probability, let's say, of 40% for the cat. If 40% of the cat pixels were retained, and 60% of dog, and 0% for anything else that you might have in your categorical distribution. So, these are very complex transformations that we're performing and forming them using multiple images together.






<h1>08  The Process of Training Neural Networks</h1><strong>M1L03</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll talk about the process of training neural networks and specifically how to monitor the learning process to understand whether the model is overfitting or whether it's learning correctly. Training deep neural networks is Is more of an art form than science. Lots of things matter and they matter together. The key is to find some magical combination of things that work together and allow it to learn a really good function for your application. I know that sounds a little funny, but this is actually the way things work.</p><p> Even in research, if you have a great idea, it will likely not work very well the first time you try it. You'll have to apply various tuning methods you have to monitor everything, understand what's going on and fix a few things on the way in order to get everything to work well together. The key principle is to monitor everything that's going on. Unlike the human brain, you can actually monitor and print out every single activation, every gradient, every loss value that happens across your entire optimization. And so last and accurate curves are mandatory.</p><p> You have to take your loss function computed at each iteration, which you already do for the optimization. And then you plot it out on a graph, and you show how it goes up or down across the iteration. Similarly, you can have various accuracy or other metrics that you care about for your application, and you should plot those across your iterations as well. But you can actually go further and print out gradients, statistics or characteristics and other aspects of the computation graph. As we've seen, these are key things that you can do.</p><p> For example, to determine whether your initialization is behaving properly or whether your normalization layers are acting according to what you think they're doing. Analyzing what's going on in your particular deep learning application always starts with proper methodology. It's not uncommon to see even published works get this wrong, so it's really important to pay attention to this part. As machine learning practitioners, you should always separate your data into training validation and testing sets. The training data is data that is used to directly optimize the weights or the parameters of your model.</p><p> The validation set on the other hand is just for monitoring whether the model is overfishing, for example. Or determining which different modules you should use or what hyper parameters to use. In other words, the validation data is not used to optimize the parameters of the model themselves. But it is used to determine the hyper parameters or what architectures you should use and so on. The test set you should never look at until you've decided upon all of those design decisions.</p><p> And so only at the end once you have found really good settings on the validation data, will you then test your model and your method on the test set. If you don't have a lot of data, you can use cross validation to decide hyper parameters. However, this is a bit computationally expensive and so often it's not done as much in deep learning. But if you don't have a lot of data, sometimes it's the only thing you can do. Once you start optimizing your model, there's a whole host of sanity checks that you can perform to make sure that your learning is going according to plan.</p><p> For example, you can check the bounds of your loss function. For example, we know that cross entropy ranges from zero to infinity. But more than that, we know that the loss given some small random weight values has to be something like negative log p for cross entropy where P equals 0.5.
