If you have a binary classification problem.</p><p> And so you could try to estimate what you think the loss should be around without regularization starting from random initialization. Another example is to start without regularization and make sure that the loss goes up when you add it. Again, regularization is often an additive term and so if you're adding the L1 or L2 norm of your weights to the loss function, then obviously it should go up. The key principle here is that you should simplify everything to make sure that you can try to predict what will happen and ensure that it is happening. You can simplify the data set to make sure that your model can properly (over)- fit before applying regularization, for example.</p><p> This is because if you have a small data set, we know that we can have sufficiently powerful models. If you have enough layers and complexity or parameters in your model to fit to the data. If nothing else, it can just memorize the data and so we know that under this setting it should be able to over fit your model. If that doesn't happen, that means that your capacity is not correct. That is, your model is not powerful enough or, there's some bugs somewhere that's preventing it from learning properly.</p><p> The change in loss indicates the speed of learning and so you should always plot and monitor loss curves, or learning curves. These curves show on the x axis, the number of iteration that have gone by. Where and duration means that you've taken a mini batch of data, say 64 examples computed the forward pass and the loss function. Computed the backwards pass and the gradients and then apply those gradients to update the weight. On the y axis we will plot the raw loss values.</p><p> And so this indicates various issues that might be going on. For example, if your loss is changing very slowly over thousands of iterations, or maybe 10s of thousands of iterations. Then you have too small of a learning rate. This doesn't mean that it won't converge to a great local minima. It just means that we don't have time to wait that long.</p><p> On the other hand, if your loss is increasing, which shouldn't be the case, because you're optimising directly to reduce the loss. Or it turns into not a number NaN, that typically means that you have too high of a learning rate. And so if you think of the loss surface, for example, that is quadratic on the lower right. What you can imagine is that in weight space, you're bouncing around out of a local minima because you're taking too big of steps. Now, these are just two examples and these symptoms actually don't uniquely identify a problem.</p><p> You need to look at all the data for example, other issues can cause the same not a number issue. If your loss function accidentally has a divide by zero, it will also have the same symptom. A common problem is that people forget to implement the log part of the loss function and so then the loss will again diverge. One nice thing to note is that in pytorch, you can use a nice decorator called detect anomaly. That actually gives you a trace of where these things happen.</p><p> For example, if you have a NaN a number occurring, it will tell you exactly where in the computation graph that happened. And so this is handy for debugging your issues. Now classic machine learning signs of under and overfitting still apply here. And this is why you should always plot both the loss and the accuracy. Or the training and validation, don't just stare at a screen with numbers scrolling pie, plot them.</p><p> So that you can see the global trends that are occurring. For example, in over-fitting will have the validation loss or accuracy improve in the beginning just as it does for the training. But then at some point it gets worse and worse as the number of iterations increase. Now, this means, again that you have over-fitting you have a larger generalization gap. That is the gap between how well you're doing on the training.</p><p> Which you're directly optimizing for and how well you're doing on held out data that you're not optimizing for is increasing. You can also have under-fitting where the validation loss is very close to the training loss, or both are high. This means that you're not doing very well on the training set. You should be optimizing directly for the training and you're still not reducing the loss sufficiently. We know that in deep learning, you have such rich models and so many parameters.</p><p> Sometimes more than the number of examples that we should be able to get Very low training loss. And so if you don't that means your model is just not powerful enough and you should increase the expressiveness or capacity of your model. For example, by adding nodes in a layer or adding layers. You can also have various strange phenomena happen. For example, you might see that the training loss is higher than the validation loss.</p><p> This might seem counterintuitive. You're directly optimizing the training loss, why should it be higher than the validation? One thing to consider is the validation loss has no regularization. That is in during training, you're applying things like weight decay or dropout regularization. And the only reason you're doing that is because it's improving the optimization. For validation when you're testing your loss or accuracy on it, you're not actually updating the parameters.</p><p> And so there's no reason to apply regularization. And so by definition, the training loss will be higher cuz it has this extra term in it. Also one thing to consider is that the way we typically measure validation is very specific. That is at the end of an epoch. When you've gone through the entire data set once.</p><p> Then we measure the validation loss or accuracy. However for the training loss, you're actually calculating them as you go, and averaging them at the end. And so if you think about it, your training loss includes models that are not even as well trained as what you try it on the validation loss. In other words, the training loss is calculated or averaged across the iteration. And so for those iterations in the beginning of the epoch, you were using models that weren't as finely trained.</p><p> And so your validation loss might actually be better because you're using a later model to calculate it across the entire validation set. Deep learning has a lot of hyper-parameters to tune. Hyper-parameters are not the parameters or weights that you're directly optimizing inside your model. These are design decisions or other constants that you have decided upon in your algorithm. For example, the number of nodes to use per layer, the number of layers to use, what nonlinearities to use.</p><p> Or the constants that we've talked about, such as learning rate and weight decay. Actually, these two are the most crucial in tuning. That is, the algorithms that we use tend to be pretty sensitive to these two. And so you should always tune them. There's other ones such as momentum that the algorithm is not that sensitive to.</p><p> And so we typically just set to values that other people have found to work. But you can, of course, also tune these as well. It's impossible to overemphasize that you should always tune your hyper-parameter. Even a great idea that you know should work will typically not work when you first try it out with hyper-parameters that you just reasonably pick out. You will typically need to then tune all of these hyper-parameters in order to get the biggest boost out of your idea.</p><p> And so hyper-parameter tuning can either make or break your idea or how well your model works and you should always do it. So how would you do it? Typically for values such as constants, we start with a course search. For example, we can try a learning rate that's exponentially increasing from 0.0001 all the way to 0.1 in an exponential manner.</p><p> Once you have a rough idea of what learning rate to use, then you can perform a finer grained search around the good values that you found. Now there are automated methods that are pretty decent. However, these typically work when you don't have a very large hyper-parameter tuning budget. That is you can't be bothered to spend a lot of time or you don't have the computational resources. And so these methods such as Bayesian hyper-parameter optimization do well in those cases.</p><p> However, in typical cases, you do have a decent amount of computation in order to try different hyper-parameters out. And often if you have done this for a while, and you have good intuition based on what exists already and what has worked in the past, you can typically do much better. One difficulty is that hyper-parameters are not independent. That is, you can't independently tune each one and then hope that the best of each one when combined will do well. There's a lot of interdependence between them.</p><p> And how this interdependence happens is not always very intuitive. Here are some examples, batch normalization and dropout are both forms of regularization. And they're slightly different. So you might think, why not combine them so that you can get an even heavier dose of regularization. It turns out that in many cases the combination of batch norm and dropout actually performs worse than individually using them.</p><p> Now, the reasons for these are not always obvious. You have to do some research. And there are papers written about this in order to find out what is the exact interaction between them based on the last surface, your application, and the optimization dynamics that are occurring. Another example the learning rate should be changed proportional to batch size. For example, as you increase your batch sizes, you should also similarly increase the learning rate.</p><p> There's some intuitive justification you can think of here. For example, as you have larger batch sizes, the variants of the estimate for the gradient are much reduced. And so maybe you can take larger steps. However, again, there's also more complicated interactions as well. And so again for all of these really you should be taking what's known in the literature in the state of art and try to understand how these things work together.</p><p> This can be obtained both through hands on experience, getting your hands dirty, or understanding what other people have tried and either succeeded or failed there. Another thing to note is that in deep learning we're optimizing a loss function. This loss function is differentiable, so we can plug it into gradient descent. But what we often care about is typically not that, we care about other metrics. And the reason we don't optimize for those metrics directly is because they're not differentiable.</p><p> And while there are works looking at applying sophisticated methods such as reinforcement learning to actually optimize for them. In vanilla form, we can't just plug it into gradient descent. Some examples that you may have seen include accuracy or precision/recall. And these are typically based on various statistics that you can gather, shown on the right. For example, there's different types of correctness or errors that you can have.</p><p> Your model can have false negative, that is, when the model outputs the negative in a binary classification but it's actually a positive. Or you can have false positives, meaning that your model outputs a positive such as it detected a person in an image, but it's actually not there. And you can have correct one such as true negatives and true positive. And so you can combine these in various ways to determine some of these statistics. The key point is that the relationship between the two, that is the loss function and the metric is not always clear and can be complex.</p><p> And so you can have various weird phenomena that you see when you plot the loss curve versus the accuracy curve. Here's an example. By now you know about the cross entropy law and here is the form. It's just a negative log probability of the correct class given the data that your model outputs. The actual accuracy metric that we often look at is just the ar gmax of it.</p><p> That is we take the probability distribution that your model outputs over all the classes and we take the highest probability one as the prediction. But you can have weird phenomena for example, your loss curve can plateau and not decrease very much anymore. Yet your accuracy can keep improving. Why is that? This is because the correct class score only has to be slightly higher than the actual other classes. And so we can have a flat loss curves meaning that the values are not really changing that much in terms of the weight and also the prediction.</p><p> But actually, it pushes the probability of the correct class over all the other classes just slightly just enough to get a better accuracy. Another example is the precision/recall curves. These represent the inherent tradeoff between the number of positive predictions and the correctness of those predictions. For example, if you wanna pick up all the pedestrians in an image dataset, then you clearly wanna say for all the pedestrians that they are pedestrian. But typically there's some error rate.</p><p> And so you might say that a fridge is a pedestrian. You can take, for example, a threshold over the probability that it's a pedestrian. And say if it's over 0.9, I'll say it's a pedestrian, or if it's below, I'll say it's not. And so as you vary the stress hold, you're gonna pick up more and more of the pedestrian.</p><p> However, you're gonna also sneak in a few of the false predictions as well. And so what happens is that you can plot a curve in this instantiation. On the right, the false positive rate versus the true positive rate that tries to show you the trade off. This curve is the best on (0,1) where you have a 0 false positive rate and a 1 true positive rate. A random guessing is in the diagonal from (0,0) to (1,1), and anything above that line is better than random.</p><p> And as you vary the threshold you might get more and more true positive examples. But you'll also again accidentally have additional false positive examples. And so your false positive rate will also increase. It's very difficult to increase your true positive rate without introducing additional false positives. In terms of definitions, for example, the true positive rate = tp / tp + fn.</p><p> Where the bottom one is actually just all positives because false negatives means that it was actually a positive and you said it wasn't negative. And so, on the diagram on the lower left, you can see this instantiated. If you have, for example, the blue circles be birds, and the lighter circles be cups, and you wanna say what is your true positive rate for detecting birds. And this oval is the set of examples that encompasses what you said were right. What you can see here is that the number of true positives 3 divided by the true positives plus the false negatives, which is 1 because you missed one bird.</p><p> And so this will be 3 out of 4 or 75%, which is pretty good. We can also have the false positive rate where this is the number of false positives divided by the actual number of negatives. Which is the false positives plus the true negatives. For example, in this case for the birds, you have one false positives because there's that one lighter circle in the oval that is a cup, but you said was a bird. And it's divided by all of the negatives.</p><p> And so you can actually have, in this case, six negatives, and so you'll have. Your false positive rate actually just be one out of six. And so this is actually pretty good performance. But it shows you that there's an inherent trade off between these different aspects. You can also measure accuracy in terms of these different terms.</p><p> So the key point here is that, as you can see, these computations are not simple in how they relate to the loss function. We can have various other metrics, such as area under the curve, actually summarizes the entire curve by just taking the area under it. This is in case we just want one number that tells us how well an algorithm is doing. And again, mapping any of these into a loss term is actually a, not possible in terms of optimizing them. And b, the relationship between our actual loss and what these metrics say is very complex.</p><p> And so again, you can have various weird phenomena where the loss goes one way and the accuracy or the false positive rate or true positive rates go one way and it's not intuitive. And again, you should try to understand why these things happen if you do see them. In summary, optimizing deep neural networks and understanding what's happening during the training process is not simple. And so that is why you should always monitor everything, monitor the loss function both on the training and the validation set. Monitor accuracy or whatever other metrics you are interested in and try to understand the relationship between these two.</p><p> Similarly for hyper parameter tuning through intuition and experience, you have to start understanding how these different aspects relate to each other. The best way to get started is to understand what other people have found. And so, this is an example of a great resource by Leslie N Smith that looks at a disciplined approach at tuning some subset of these hyper parameters. However, there's many other guides and you should, again, through experience, gain some intuition about this as well.






<h1>00  Data Wrangling  Lecturer Introduction</h1><strong>M1L04</strong><hr><p>Hello, my name is Kristen Altenburger and I will be co-teaching the set of lectures on data wrangling. I am currently a Research Scientist with the Core Data Science team at Facebook. My research broadly focuses on developing statistical methods for characterizing social structures and networks with applications to data privacy. And focuses on promoting equitable digital systems that feature complex cultural and political considerations. Given my own range of experiences with data wrangling across a variety of settings ranging from the national security to tech spaces.</p><p> I look forward to talking more on best practices for data wrangling to ensure a high quality data analysis. >> Hi my name is Sam Pepose and I will be co-teaching this set of lectures on data wrangling. I'm currently an Applied Research Scientist on the Portal AI team at Facebook. My research focuses on computer vision for human understanding and mobile-optimized machine learning. I look forward to discussing data wrangling and specifically how to process our data for deep learning in this set of lectures.</p><p>






<h1>01  Data Wrangling</h1><strong>M1L04</strong><hr><p>Welcome to the first lecture on data wrangling. In this lecture, we will provide a broad overview on data wrangling along with specific considerations for deep learning applications. You can think of data wrangling as all the steps cycle into cleaning and transforming your data for modeling. Setting up a cross validation pipeline, evaluating model results, and ensuring reproducibility for other strap locate those results. We will consider questions such as how do you handle missing data.</p><p> How do you address class imbalance. Or how do you evaluate model performance. A good data wrangler is someone who explores the data, understands the setting in which data is being collected, and thinks carefully about repairing that dataset. There are countless examples of where data wrangling has gone wrong. The figure on the left describes a retracted paper where the treatment assignment recoding was reversed for treatment and control groups.</p><p> The figure on the right is from a nature human behavior paper titled, evaluating the replicability of social science experiments in nature and science between 2010 and 2015. In this figure from the paper illustrates the variability and more broadly the challenge in replication efforts. The goal of this lecture is to help you think through your own data wrangling process, think through where an analysis might go wrong. And to think about setting up reproducible analysis in your own work. We first provide an overview of the typical data wrangling process.</p><p> First, you have some target population of observations. Next, you think about sampling from that entire population because it is often not possible to work with the entire population. So we think about taking a sample s from that population. Here, we will be focused on building prediction models. So we then implement a cross validation step where a portion of the data called the train split is used for building a learning model.</p><p> And the test split is used for model evaluation. Next, we'll walk through each step of the data wrangling process in more detail. So we'll first step through what is the population of interest. And what sample s are we evaluating and is sample s representative of the population. So there are many ways to define the target population of interest.</p><p> So we'll just provide a couple of examples. We could think of a population being all users on Facebook. Or maybe we're interested in a population defined by all U.S users on Facebook. Finally, maybe we're interested in all U.</p><p>S users on Facebook that joined in the last month. Next, we think about sampling from this population. Again, there are many ways to sample data and we'll just cover two examples here. So first, a simple random sampling design is one in which every observation from the population has the same chance of being sampled. The second one, stratified random sampling, is if you're interested in partitioning your population into groups.</p><p> And so the idea is that you then random sample within each group. Again, there are many ways to sample and we provide a link to a website describing more details below. In the first step of the data wrangling process, we first discussed clearly defining your population and sample. Second, we went through different sampling schemes and understanding the representativeness of your sample such as a stratified random sampling and needing to sample by group.






<h1>02  Cross Validation and Class Imbalance</h1><strong>M1L04</strong><hr><p>In this portion of the data wrangling lecture, we will discuss the next step in the data wrangling process cross-validation, and we'll highlight data specific challenges such as class imbalance. So recall from the last lecture, we discussed identifying the target population of interest and considering what sample S we are evaluating. In this portion, we will discuss step two, how do we implement cross-validation to evaluate our predictive model and how do we avoid overfitting or data mining these results? As described in the book Elements of Statistical Learning, cross-validation is the method for estimating prediction error. One cross-validation strategy is called k-fold cross-validation, which we illustrate here. The idea is simple, we split the data into k equally sized parts.</p><p> Oftentimes in practice, you see k equals 5 or k equals 10 and you fit the model on k minus one parts and predict on the holdout kth part. So here we would be fitting the model on parts 1, 2, 4 and 5 and predicting on part 3. We do this for each of the parts or splits and then we obtain an average estimate of the prediction error. There are several considerations when implementing cross-validation and here we cover only some of the best practices. First for model hyperparameter tuning, the paper random search for hyperparameter optimization offers empirical evidence that from neural networks in deep belief networks that random searching can find models at least as good if not better than a grid search in a fraction of the computation time.</p><p> Second, there are also ways to check that the hyperparameter range is sufficient. So for a random forest model, an out-of-bag prediction means that for a given training observation, you can construct a random forest predictor by only averaging the trees that correspond to bootstrap samples not containing that observation. Then one can evaluate such as model hyperparameter such as the number of decision trees increases in a random forest model, whether the out-of-bag error rate for the training observations decreases and stabilizes at some point. Three, another issue to be mindful of is whether your test sample will be at a future time point. If so, the time series cross-validation set up would be set up so that training happens on historical data and testing happens on future data.</p><p> This also means that future observations cannot be utilized for future construction. And finally, overfitting can occur when you learn a model that does not generalize to a true out of sample observation. One quick way to check for overfitting is to compare the error rate on the training set versus the error rate on the test set. For example, overfitting becomes a concern when as the model complexity increases, the training error rate becomes significantly smaller than the test error rate. Overfitting can be a concern especially when you have more predictors or features than observations.</p><p> We next consider a data issue called class imbalance. Class imbalance may occur in binary class prediction settings where one class outnumbers the other class. This figure here, we would call the grey class the majority class and the red class the minority class. Class imbalance can be problematic when your model learns to optimize predictions for the majority class. There are two general ways to address class imbalance in your data set.</p><p> First are sampling based methods, and the second are cost sensitive learning methods. For sampling based methods, one popular method is called the synthetic minority over-sampling technique or SMOTE introduced in 2002 by Chawla et al. Prior to SMOTE, a typical method was to address class imbalance by over-sampling with replacement the minority class, yet there might be concerns of overfitting those minority class observations since you're exactly duplicating those observations. So to address overfitting, the idea of SMOTE is to generate synthetic minority observations. So for each observed minority observation, SMOTE identifies nearest neighbors and feature space will randomly select a subset of these nearest neighbors based on some desired amount of over-sampling.</p><p> And then will uniformly sample from the line segment connecting the minority observation and the selected nearest neighbor. We provide an illustration in this example here where we're randomly generating a synthetic minority point along the dotted line. >> We're gonna see how class imbalance can affect object detection. Region CNN and Single Shot Detector are models that can localize and classify many objects in an image for instance, these two dogs in this image. The way object detection models work is by densely sampling many boxes of different sizes at different anchor locations in the image.</p><p> The first step is to create a dense grid of anchor points on the image. Then for each anchor point, we sample many boxes of different sizes and aspect ratios. These boxes are called proposal boxes. In object detection, the goal is to classify a proposal box into foreground or background. The way that we measure this is using IoU intersection over union.</p><p> Intersection over union is calculated using two boxes. The numerator is the area of the overlap between the two boxes and the denominator is the area of the union of both boxes. We assign a ground truth label of foreground if the IoU with the ground truth box and a proposal box is greater than 0.5. Otherwise we assign a ground truth label of background.</p><p> So you can see we have a class imbalance here. Since we're sampling so many proposals from the image, we have a much larger number of background boxes than we do foreground boxes. Cross entropy is a popular loss use for bounding box regression. However, easy examples incur a non-negligible loss which in aggregate mask of the harder more rare foreground examples. An alternative loss, focal loss instead down-weights easy examples to give more attention to these difficult foreground examples.</p><p> The purpose of focal loss is to down-weight easy examples. What we mean by easy examples are well classified examples with high probability from the model. The blue line here represents cross entropy, the baseline. You can see, even for higher probability predictions, we still incur a non-zero loss. Compare this to focal loss, where for higher probability predictions, we incur a much smaller loss.</p><p> >> We illustrate here how to correctly implement oversampling methods such as SMOTE with cross-validation using the figure from the paper cross-validation for imbalanced data sets, avoiding over optimistic and overfitting approaches. At the top we have our original imbalanced data set. So in red are the minority class units A through E and in gray, we have our majority class units 1 through 10. On the left is an illustration of cross-validating after oversampling and this is incorrect. So let's see why.</p><p> So we first oversampled so that we have equal representation of both classes. Then we cross-validate. Let's focus on the k equals 1 split. In both the training and test split, we observe A appearing as indicated by the asterisk. That's because we oversampled first.</p><p> So this will lead to an overoptimistic error estimate, since you have data leakage on the same observation appearing in both the train and test split. So don't do this. Instead, the right side illustrates the correct approach to implement cross-validation during oversampling. First, the original data is divided into k partitions and only the training split is oversampled. So this is important because it means that no data from the training split will become part of the testing split and we can ensure a fair evaluation of the model to generalize from the training data to the test data.</p><p> So in the previous lecture, we considered defining your population and sample and discuss different ways of sampling. In these set of slides, we discussed cross-validation, ways it can go wrong especially in class imbalance problems and how it's important to understand the relevant problem and prediction task that will be done in practice.






<h1>03  Prediction and Evaluation</h1><strong>M1L04</strong><hr><p>In this portion of the Data Wrangling lecture, we'll discuss model prediction and evaluation. We previously discussed the process of cross validation and how to avoid over fitting data mining. And here we'll focus on Step 3, what's a prediction tasks such as classification or regression, and what is the meaningful evaluation criteria? Let's consider a binary classification model, which aims to predict the likelihood of a test observation being in class one, which will refer to as positive or class zero, which we'll refer to as negative. Note this discussion extends to multi class settings as well. So once we have our fitted classification model on the training data, we then use it to predict a test observation selecting a threshold for classifying the test point as class one or class zero.</p><p> We'll call these our predicted values. Then a typical way to compare predictive performance for classification is comparing the actual versus predicted values via this two by two confusion matrix. Suppose we have an actual positive observation, then it can be either correctly classified as positive, which we'll call a, true positive, or it could be falsely classified, as a negative, which we'll classify as a false negative. Similarly, let's suppose we have an actual negative observation. Then, it can be falsely classified as a positive if we predict it's a positive, or it can be correctly classified as a negative, which we'll refer to as a true negative.</p><p> Next, if you are learning a regression model, there are a variety of evaluation metrics to consider such as the mean-squared error and simply visualizing the errors themselves. For classification models, sometimes it matters not only predicting the class label, but predicting the associated probability. If we care about the classification score that corresponds to a probability score then it can help to examine calibration plots. A calibration plot, as shown here, plots on the x-axis the mean predicted value and on the y-axis the fraction of positives. So a perfectly well calibrated plot is shown by the black dotted line where mean predictions are exactly equal to the fraction of positives.</p><p> A miscalibrated plot is one that deviates from the dotted line. In this plot here we see a logistic regression model as well calibrated, this makes sense since logistic regression is aimed at optimizing the log loss. Meanwhile, we see a support vector classification model is very miscalibrated. If you find your model is, miscalibrated. Then there are a variety of options for calibrating such as isotonic regression.</p><p> It is important to ask what are we comparing our model performance against? We'll call this the baseline. A baseline could be many things. Perhaps it's random guessing. Perhaps, you're comparing against the current model in production. And it's generally useful to compare predictive performance with current and the proposed model.</p><p> We've previously defined population and sampling and understanding the representativeness of your sample and the last set of lectures went through cross-validation. Here we talked about knowing the prediction task of interest, whether it's regression or classification, as well as incorporating model checks and evaluating multiple predictive performance metrics. In this step, we covered what's the prediction task and identifying meaningful evaluation criteria. We'll conclude with asking how do we create a reproducible pipeline? The replication crisis has affected the social sciences and biomedicine. Currently only a small percent of papers at top artificial intelligence conferences make code available.</p><p> Simultaneously, researchers have an increasing number of researcher degrees of freedom, especially in deep learning settings, and it is critical to ensure general reproducibility. One such proposal for ensuring reproducible analyses is based on a paper called, Datasheets for Datasets. The idea is that every data set would be accompanied by a documentation for the collection process, its composition, recommended uses, and so on. Likewise, the paper model cards for model reporting provides guidance on including documentation on any trained model, such as the details on the training data, and what were the performance evaluation procedures. Any analysis you do should have reproducible ability in mind.</p><p>






<h1>04  Data Cleaning for Machine Learning</h1><strong>M1L04</strong><hr><p>Now we're gonna look at Data Cleaning for Machine Learning. There are three steps in data preparation. First, we clean the data, then we transform the data, and finally, we pre-process the data. An important part of cleaning data is understanding missing data. There are three missing data mechanisms we can use to understand why our data is missing.</p><p> Missing completely at random, is when the likelihood of any data observation to be missing is random. Missing at random, is when the likelihood of any data observation to be missing depends on an observed data feature. Finally, missing not at random, is when a likelihood of any data observation to be missing depends on unobserved outcome. As an example, let's say we were conducting a survey on levels of depression. If someone forgot to fill out a survey answer, that would be missing completely at random.</p><p> Statistically, men are less likely to fill out a depression survey, so we may be missing more data from males. This would be missing at random because the missing data directly depends on an observed data feature, gender. Finally, missing not at random would be if we're missing data from the survey because someone didn't fill it out as a direct causation of their depression. Here's an example of missing data. One way to handle this is we could simply throw away the rows where we're missing data.</p><p> This is easy, but we are losing valuable information. Another way to approach this is through imputation, where we give a best guess to fill in the gaps. For instance, for numerical data, we could apply mean, mode, most frequent, replace it with a zero or a constant value. For instance, for the row with the name Max, we replace the value with the mean of the other rows or the mode of the other rows. For categorical data such as profession, we could use hot deck imputation, where we simply replace it with the most frequent of other similar rows.</p><p> We could also do more complicated approaches such as k-nearest neighbors to group similar rows, or use deep-learned embeddings to cluster rows together. The next step in the data preparation process is transforming your data. This is highly dependent on the input data format. For instance, if you're given an image, you may need to convert the image from RGB to grayscale, for example. If you're given text, you wanna convert this text into a numerical representation.</p><p> You can do this by simply assigning a unique value or index to each word. You could use a bag of words, TF-IDF, or you could run a model to get a unique embedding for a word. The next data preparation step is to pre-process your data. This helps to make our models converge faster. For instance, given your original data, you can mean subtract to zero-center the data across every individual feature.</p><p> We can also normalize the data so that each dimension is approximately the same scale. Now, we're gonna look at a case study for data preparation, Depth Estimation. For depth estimation, we're predicting at every pixel in the image, the distance from the camera. Usually, depth sensors predict very highly noisy data. You can see the holes in the depth images in the second row here.</p><p> So the first step we need to do is clean these holes, clean the data. There are many ways we could fill in the missing depth values. And naive baseline would be to use nearest neighbor interpolation. Another approach would be colorization, which uses inpainting to find the missing results. This is how the depth map looks after we've filled in all of the missing values.</p><p> The next step is to transform our data. Learning Rich Features from RGB-D Images for Object Detection and Segmentation found that instead of using a single channel depth map, they'd see improved performance by using 3-channels as the input. They do this by transforming their single channel depth map into horizontal disparity, height above ground, and angle with gravity. They feed these three channels into their model instead of a single channel. The final step is pre-processing.</p><p> For depth estimation, inverse depth helps to improve numerical stability and provides a Gaussian error distribution. For example, see in the chart on the right without normalization, training quickly collapses and our mean depth goes to zero. However, with normalization, we're able to train for long periods of time without our depth collapsing to zero.






<h1>CS7643 Module 2 Introduction v2</h1><strong>M2L00</strong><hr><p>In this module, we're gonna start talking about different types of layers. So far we've learned about fully connected layers where the output nodes are connected to all input nodes. Now this connectivity structure doesn't have to be that way. And in fact, for some types of inputs, it doesn't make sense for them to be that way. And so we'll talk about different types of layers that have different connectivity structures.</p><p> So far, we've seen how to build an optimized deep feed forward neural network architectures consisting of linear and nonlinear layers. And as we've seen, these can be generalized to arbitrary computation graphs. We can add whatever layers we want. And so, there's only a question of what types of layers make sense for particular types of applications. And no matter what layer we use as long as it's differentiable, backpropagation and automatic differentiation can be used to optimize all the parameters across all the layers using gradient descent.</p><p> Now layers don't have to be fully connected like we've seen. In fact, in many cases this may not make sense. So for example, for images, it makes sense to have nodes look at only small regions in the image rather than have each node be connected to all the million pixels in an image, for example. We may only want to consider small patches of input and this is because features and images actually tend to be pretty localized. For example, we may want to extract edges or color or texture or other types of very local features.</p><p> And so as long as a node looks at a particular window around the image, then it can pick out these features. And so this operation, which can be another neural network layer, can be formalized with what's called a convolution operation. And so here we'll have an image, for example, and we'll have a kernel and this is the parameters that we'll learn. This kernel will be a feature extractor. For example, in this case here, you could see very dark values on one side and light values on another side.</p><p> And so essentially, this will be an edge extractor or edge detector. And so when this window is convolved with different image patches across the image when there are strong edges of the orientation that it has, then it will result in a high value. Whereas if the image patch does not have very strong edges then it will result in a low value. And the output of this particular operation will be an output map shown on the right, which is a spatially organized set of values where high values represent image patches that were very strongly indicative of this feature. And we'll show how this new convolution layer can take any input tensor shape, say an RGB image with three channels and a width and a height and perform feature extraction across multiple features.</p><p> That is, we'll have multiple kernels and it will output another similarly shaped output. Where the depth of this output will be equal to the number of kernels that we have, and the width and height will be slightly different than the input image. And so what we're going to have is a layer that performs some linear transformation of the input to produce an output of a very similar shape. And again, these kernels can be seen as feature extraction. So some of them can be edge extractors, others can extract color features or texture features and so on.</p><p> And the convolution layers can be combined with other types of layers such as the nonlinearities, as well as pooling layers, which reduce the dimensionality of the data. For example, we'll take image patches let's say three by three and take just the max operation and reduce those nine numbers into one. And again we'll have a smaller output and perform dimensionality reduction effectively. And so we can have a series of convolutional and pooling, linear and nonlinear layers that are alternated. Specifically given an image, we can feed it through a convolution layer with some non linearity.</p><p> And so here we'll have the output maps for each kernel, again, fed through a pixel wise nonlinearity. And then we'll apply a polling layer to downsample those images. And then we'll apply another convolution layer to extract even further features. And again, the hope is that over the depth of the network, we'll start to extract more and more abstract features. And in the end, we can then have fully connected layers, hopefully by then the size of the tensors will become smaller.</p><p> And so we can just have a fully connected layer or a set of them that can be seen as the classifier. And so this is a complete convolution neural network that consists of convolution, nonlinearity, and pooling layers that are over and over transforming the inputs. And then at the end, a set of fully connected layers that are essentially performing classification. And so we can use again backpropagation and the notion of a computation graph to optimize all of the parameters across all of these layers, in an end to end manner, in order to improve our classification results. And so the hope is that it'll continue to improve the features or the kernels that it learns as the optimization progresses, as well as the fully connected weights as well.</p><p> And so given knowledge of these types of layers that we will cover in this module, we'll actually get to pretty advanced architectures called convolution all neural network that actually have existed for a while. In the 1980s, these were used to read a decent percentage of bank checks, for example. And so this shows what's called the LeNet architecture that has existed since the 1980s, which again consists of the same types of layers that we've been talking about. Where you have the convolution layer, you have subsampling or pooling layer and these are alternated over and over and again, there are nonlinearities in between. And then at the end, there are fully connected layers here.</p><p> They're called Gaussian connections, but they're actually normal, fully connected layers. And so again, these are all the layers that you need to know to express a fully convolutional neural network. And so in 2012, these types of convolutional neural networks took over and beat many competitions such as for image classification. And what we'll see is that over time, these neural networks have become more and more complicated. Now the specific layers have not necessarily all become more complicated.</p><p> Here you'll see the same combination of fully connected layers, convolution layers, and MaxPooling layers, and SoftmaxActivations or LossFunctions such as cross entropy. And the only thing is that we'll essentially have different connectivity patterns between the modules and we'll make these much deeper. And we can also have, for example, multiple loss functions as well. And through the power of automatic differentiation, the same technique that we used to optimize very small neural networks consisting of just fully connected layers, we'll be able to optimize all of the parameters across all the layers in these very complicated networks. And we'll also see that you can actually start to visualize what these networks learn.</p><p> And we'll see various patterns, for example edge detectors or detectors such as corners or small circular shapes and so on. And these are actually similar patterns that are also found in brain activations for example in biological systems and so we know we're on the right track. And we'll see that actually as the depth of the neural network increases, they actually tend to express more and more abstract features, for example, object parts or entire objects or faces and things like that. And finally we'll start talking about much more complicated tasks as well. And show how through the power of deep learning, we can essentially just look at all of these layers as building blocks and create even new layers for different applications or tasks.</p><p> And actually apply the same methods for optimizing. So here we'll talk about not just image classification, where given an image, all I get is a label distribution. Here we'll have object detection, where given an image will actually extract little boxes around the object and the classification for each of those boxes. This is a much more complicated task because you need to output some variable number of boxes over the image. You don't know how many actual objects will be in there.</p><p> And we'll talk about very specific types of branches of the neural network. For example, we'll have a different branch in the neural network that will predict random boxes across the image for things that might look like objects. And then we'll have another branch that classifies the outputs of those boxes. And so we'll essentially be able to show how you can have many different loss functions, many different connectivity patterns and many different branches in a complicated neural network to output a very complex task such as object detection.






<h1>01 Convolution Layers v2</h1><strong>M2L05</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll learn about a new type of layer called a convolution layer. Unlike a fully connected layer, convolution layers will not be fully connected to their inputs. And we'll see why this is important for various modalities such as images. We'll talk about what convolutions are, and how we can easily implement them in deep neural networks. Backpropagation and automatic differentiation allows us to optimize any function composed of differential blocks.</p><p> There's no need to modify the underlying algorithm dependent on what the blocks are. And the complexity of the function is only limited by computation and memory. This is really the power of deep learning. However, different types of layers are appropriate for different types of input data and their fully connected layer which has a very specific connectivity pattern where each output node is connected to each input node Is not necessarily the best for every type of application. Take images for example, suppose that an image has 1024 by 1024 pixels.</p><p> When we convert this to a vector, we'll roughly have a million elements. If we put a fully connected layer right after it with N nodes, let's say N equals to 1000, how many parameters or weights will we have to learn for this layer? If you calculate it, you'll have M*N(weights)+N biases, that is one bias value for each output. If M is a million and N is a thousand, you'll have lots and lots of parameters. So you can have hundreds of millions or billions of parameters for just one layer. In deep learning we can continue to add more and more layers together.</p><p> And there are several issues in machine learning with having so many parameters. For example, the more parameters or weights that you have to optimize our learn, the more data you need to actually be able to fit all those values. That is your model has an extreme amount of flexibility, actually, too much flexibility that it doesn't actually need. And you need lots of data to fit that flexibility and make sure that you don't over fit. And so there's a question that we can ask ourselves.</p><p> Is this really necessary? For example, for images. Images in particular have special characteristics that make fully connected layers not as applicable and allow us to do better in a more parameter efficient manner. Specifically, image features are spatially localized. For example, take edges or contours. As you can see on the image to the right, they're very informative.</p><p> You can already see that this is a bird even without seeing the pixel intensities on the image to the left. So what we'll have is features such as edges that we can actually extract not by looking at the entire image but looking at small image patches. For example, given a small image patch, we can detect whether there's a gradient. This is not a deep learning gradient but a differential between the pixels. There are dark pixels on the left and light pixels on the right or vice versa.</p><p> Those tell us whether there are edges in this little image patch. And we can repeat this across the entire image to extract features such as edges. This is well known in areas such as image processing, and so there's Smaller features that are repeated across the image and edges are one example. But other examples include color or even things like motifs such as corners or small circular shapes and things like that. Any local feature that you can extract or detect by just looking at small image patches, not the entire image itself.</p><p> If you think about it fully connected layers, each node looks at all pixels in the entire image and this may seem silly. Further, there's no reason to believe that one feature tends to appear in one location vs another. For example, if you just take a natural image anywhere in the world, there's no reason to believe a peak might appear specifically only in the middle of the picture or only to the upper left. Now you might have small image collections that have biases in locations, but in general over all possible images, there's no reason to believe these local features are gonna appear somewhere in the image specifically, in other words, the feature extractors do not have to be location specific. And so we can use these properties to induce a bias in the design of the neural network layer to reflect this.</p><p> And by bias, I mean that will explore specific connectivity patterns that are more appropriate to images and that will reduce the number of parameters that these layers will have. Specifically what we'll do is have each node in the neural network rather than take inputs from the entire image will take inputs from just a small what we call receptive field or small window or image patch in the image. For example, it will receive input from a K1 by K2 window on the upper left. And so this node will output the existence of a particular type of feature in that little window for example and edge. The advantages to this is that the number of parameters will be reduced to K1 times K2 plus one for a bias element times N where N is the number of output note, and so we can toggle this we can control the number of output nodes.</p><p> And this will allow us to have only a certain number of output nodes, each of which only takes input from K1 by K2 image patches. Again, the key idea here is to reduce the number of parameters is no longer M times N it's a smaller window K1 by K2 times N roughly. And one interesting thing about this way of doing things is that it also maintains spatial information. Now, a fully connected layer can maintain spatial information because each node takes input from the entire image and it can for example, weight any parts of the image upward down and so it can try to maintain some elements of spatial information. But here, we're actually gonna organize the output nodes also spatially such that they're explicitly maintaining this information.</p><p> And we can even do better we can think about the fact that I mentioned before. In terms of features not existing in particular location, do we really need to learn a vote that extract specific types of features as represented by the weights the K1 times K2 weights in a particular location in the image? And the answer is no. What we can have is nodes in different locations, sharing features or weights. Weight sharing means that the specific weights for example, W11 for the left most node is gonna be the same as W11 for the right most node. The way you can accomplish this is by just having the same variable in the computation graph feed into both of these nodes.</p><p> And so we'll have several nodes across the entire output all share weight. Now what is this intuitively doing? Intuitively, the weights will represent some sets of features that we extract. And what we'll do is we'll share those features across all the nodes that is will try to, let's say have an edge detection feature and that edge detection feature will be run across the entire image because each node will run that same feature across the entire image. And so again, we're using the same weights or parameters in the computation graph. This is called shared weight.</p><p> Again, the advantage here is to further reduce the number of parameters. Now we don't have this factor of n the number of output nodes. If we just wanna extract one type of feature, we'll only have K1 by K2 plus 1 parameters. And we'll run this feature extractor across the entire image. And again, we're still explicitly maintaining spatial information.</p><p> And so now we've gone from m times n weights all the way down to a small number of weights, K1 times K2. So for example, if this is a 3 by 3 window, we'll literally only have three times three plus the bias term, so 10 parameters. And we can also learn many of these features. So we may not wanna be limited to one type of feature. Obviously, we can have vertical edges or horizontal edges or lots of things in between.</p><p> And we at the same time also wanna represent different color features or texture features or. Corner features or other shapes. And so we will wanna have multiple types of features. So we'll have one channel of output, for example on the upper left, that represents locations of features. For example, let's say edges or a particular edge orientation.</p><p> And so this output channel will have nodes with high values in the locations that have such features very strongly. And then on the lower left, we'll have another channel of output that represents the location of a different feature. And so across the different types of features, the weights are not shared. We'll see in later slides that the weights themselves will represent what types of features we extract from these little windows. And so we want them to not be shared across different types of features.</p><p> But for one particular type of feature on the upper left, let's say all of the nodes are sharing their weights. That is, they're extracting the same type of feature over different locations in the image. And so the number of parameters now we've increased it a little bit, but we've also increased the expressiveness or representational power. That is, now we can represent multiple types of features. And we'll have (K1 x K2 + 1) * M features or parameters, where M is the number of features we want to learn.</p><p> And so now we wanna understand how can we actually implement this feature extractor? We've talked at a high level about feature extraction, but how can we actually implement this mathematically? If you have an electrical and computer engineering background. What we described, that is some filter or feature extractor, striding along an image, and outputting values that are high if it picks up a particular type of feature, may sound familiar. This is actually called a convolution operation. And it's extremely common in various fields of study, including electrical engineering, and so on. And it has a lot of deep mathematics behind it, some of which we won't really cover.</p><p> And it's also related to something called cross-correlation, which we'll also discuss. But it has a whole wide range of applications. And so really the reason we frame this as a convolution operation stems from the history of where this type of layer came from. So what is a convolution? In mathematics, and electrical, and computer engineering, there's actually a continuous forms of convolution operations that we won't go into. And there's also lower dimensional convolutions, such as 1D discrete convolutions.</p><p> Again, we're not really gonna talk about these because we're describing image processing here, and so we'll deal mostly with 2D convolution. Although later we may talk about 3D convolutions and extension. Now a 2D convolution in particular looks like this. We will have an image that is fed through what's called a kernel or a filter. And we will perform a convolution, that is, we'll combine the image with this kernel, and we'll get what's called an output or filter map.</p><p> Sometimes it's called the feature map, and in deep neural networks, it's called an activation map. In any case, it represents the same thing. The output is spatially relevant and maintains spatial information of where the particular kernel or filter is highly expressed in the original image. So here you can kind of see a pattern to this particular kernel we have here, if we visualize it in grayscale where dark values are very low negative values, and light values, or high value, positive values. You can see that this kinda looks like an edge.</p><p> And this is not a coincidence. What we'll have is, this filter will be convolved with image patches, so portions of the image. And if portions of the image have very dark locations on one side, and very light locations on the other side, this filter will activate very highly. And so you'll have very high values in the corresponding region in the output map. In deep learning will make this convolution operation a layer, that is, we'll have some input, say an image.</p><p> And we'll perform some function on it, some linear function in this case. And we'll have an output. And so what we'll actually learn is the kernel or filter itself. That is, these values where you see -1, -2, and -1, and so on. We'll actually initialize randomly to small random values.</p><p> And then we're gonna back propagate through this layer in order to optimize this filter. Such that the output maps after this operation will allow us to, for example, classify what's in the image. Now, there's a very mathematical way to describe convolutions, and we'll get to those. But let's describe the intuitive interpretation. What we're actually gonna be doing is very simple.</p><p> We're gonna be taking the kernel and flipping it or rotating it by 180 degrees. This is depicted here in the slide. And then all we're gonna do is we're gonna essentially dot product that kernel with all the different image patches or locations in the image. That is, we'll start from the upper left, and we'll take a dot product between the nine values in the upper left of the image and the kernel. And so again, we're just multiplying let's say the upper left of the image pixel multiplied by the upper left of the kernel, and so on.</p><p> And do this for nine of the values. And then we'll also add a bias term later. And this dot product will result in the value output of the first pixel in the output map, depicted as that white circle here. Now you'll notice that we'll do this over and over again over all locations in the image, but at some point we'll run out of room. That is, for example, if we move one, two, three over in the image, then at some point the filter will go off the image.</p><p> And so that's why there are blanks in the output map. That is, the output map size is going to be slightly smaller because as we move the filter over the image, we start to go off the image. And at that point we won't actually produce an output. So this is the intuitive way that we'll describe a convolution. We'll just take a kernel, we'll flip it, or rotate it 180 degrees, and then stride it along the image, just dot producting the kernel with that image patch and producing an output.</p><p> Now even though that description of what we're doing in the convolution operation is pretty simple, mathematically describing it gets a little bit hairy. And that's because we need to define coordinate systems for the image and the kernel. And somehow describe mathematically this operation of flipping the kernel as well as striding it over the image. Suppose that we take the image here, simplify it into a 5 by 5 grid, and we'll represent a coordinate system where the center pixel is (0, 0). And so the upper left is gonna be negative, (height- 1 over 2, negative width- 1 over 2).</p><p> And then the lower right will be the positive version of that. The kernel's coordinate system will be a little bit different. We'll have the upper left defined as (0, 0), and the lower right defined as (k1- 1, k2- 1). And so let's look at the equation that describes how to perform this convolution operation. So again, it's a little bit hairy because of the coordinate system issue.</p><p> But let's take the output map y. So y represents our output, and (r, c) will represent the pixels that are in the output. So r represents the row, and c represents the column, and so (0, 0) is gonna be on the upper left in this case. What we're gonna do is y of let's say (0, 0) will equal to the summation over the entire image where we dot product or multiply the input pixel, the image pixel times the kernel value. But if you look, we're summing over from upper left to lower right all of the pixels in the image, and we're multiplying x(a, b).</p><p> So a is the current pixel in the image, and b is the current pixel in the image. Again, this is the input image. r, c is on the output image. And we're multiplying pixel, a, b in the input image with the kernel value, but the kernel value is not a, b. It's actually r- a and c- b.</p><p> And this is actually what is representing mathematically that operation of flipping the kernel. Let's take a look at an example. Let's say y(0,0), what we're gonna do is iterate over all the pixels in the input image. And so this includes, let's say, on the upper left, which is x(-2,-2). And so now a equals -2, b equals -2.</p><p> And again, because we're looking at y(0, 0), r equals 0 and c equals 0. So if you work it out the actual kernel pixel that we're multiplying it by is r- a, which is 0- -2, which is 2 and the same for the second coordinate. And so we're multiplying x(-2, -2), again the complete upper left pixel in the image with k(2,2), which is actually the lower right of the kernel. And this actually what's representing the flipping operation. And so if you look, these lines show that we're directly multiplying the pixel image on the upper left with the kernel value on the lower right, and that gets to contribute to the y(0, 0).</p><p> Now that's just the first pixel. We also have x(-2, -1), and again we're actually, in this case, multiplying it by k(2, 1), and so on. Now if you notice, at some point, you'll have negative values for the kernel. And of course, you can't actually have that, there's no value there. And so we actually just throw those values away.</p><p> And so if you kinda work it out mathematically, we're actually doing what I intuitively described. We're multiplying the flipped kernel by just that upper left 9 by 9 set of values. And so again, you can work this out and you should spend some time to see how it all works out. But that's essentially what this mathematics is describing. And again, just to reiterate, as we're moving from the upper left to the lower right in the image, we're actually multiplying at each point in the input image by this flipped kernel.</p><p> Because we're going from the lower right in the kernel to the upper left in the kernel. Now this is pretty confusing. And so you can actually try to make this a little bit less hairy by rather than centering around the image, you can center around the kernel itself. So here we've changed the summations to iterate over the kernel. And now again, the only difference is that if you notice it's the x values, that is the values in the input image, are the ones that have this r- a and r- b.</p><p> And so as we've seen, we're actually taking the convolution operation and starting at the end of the kernel, that is the lower right, and moving backwards towards 0,0. And this is again intuitively described as a flipping operation. And it turns out that convolution has a relationship with another operation called the cross-correlation. The cross-correlation is actually very similar to convolution, except it's applied with the flipped kernel. And we're doing exactly what we described, which is we're taking the flipped kernel, and cross-correlation just takes the dot product of each image patch with the kernel and produces an output.</p><p> So again, there's an intuitive interpretation in that essentially, the convolution and the cross-correlation are very related. And really, the cross-correlation is only different in that it's flipping the kernel from the convolution and then applying the normal dot product operation that we've talked about. So again, you take the kernel, you rotate it 180 degrees and you perform this cross-correlation, which is just essentially this dot product as you strided along the image. And then you add up all those values to produce the output for each pixel. And so this is the mathematics of cross-correlation.</p><p> It's actually a little bit nicer because if you notice rather than having this weird r- a, we're now adding things which is a lot more intuitive. And we can have the coordinate systems be the same for both the image and the kernel. So specifically for the image, we have the coordinate system b00 on the upper left. And H-1,W-1 on the low right. And the same thing for the kernel.</p><p> And so again, if you go through the math of this, essentially all you're doing is taking that kernel which is now the flipped kernel from the convolution. And we're applying it at each location in image, producting that kernel and then producing the output. Now one interesting thing is that essentially, again, now the pixels are moving in the same direction. That is the indexing is moving the same direction, which makes things a lot more intuitive. And we'll see this make the backprop equation much simpler.</p><p> One interesting thing is that since we're learning these kernels anyway, essentially those kernel values are gonna be randomly initialized and some learned thing that gradient descent tells us to optimize to. It doesn't really matter whether you flip the kernel or not. And so really with respect to a learned kernel, there's no real difference between convolution and cross-correlation. And so let's take a concrete example here just with actual values. So let's say that our upper left nine pixels, so that is X(0:2,0:2) have these nine values and I completely made these up.</p><p> And let's say your dot producting them with the kernel k prime that is the flipped kernel. And so this is just one example of a kernel. This is kind of an edge detector called the Sobel filter, if you're curious. And so the dot product will essentially be two 200 times 1, plus 150 times 0, plus 150 times -1, and so on for all nine values, and then we'll get the result 65. So this is just a concrete example of the dot product.</p><p> And typically, as I mentioned, you'll also have a bias value similar to all the other linear layers that we talked about before. And again, we're just gonna do this and then stride it along the image. So there's a question in that some of this may seem confusing as to why we're actually going through the notion of describing what a convolution operation is describing and everything mathematically. And at the end, all we get is just another linear operation. Actually, it's very similar to W transpose X, except the only difference is that our W is gonna be a small window and we're gonna do W transpose X across the whole image.</p><p> We're gonna stride that w across the whole image to get a spatially organized output. And so why are we bothering with all this mathematical formulation of what a convolution is, as well as describing the relationship between the convolution and a cross-correlation? The first reason is that there's actually a duality between cross-correlation and convolution. It turns out that when you do the forward pass as a cross-correlation, which is actually how we'll implement it, because that's the easy thing to implement, and it's also easy to vectorize. It turns out that when we compute the gradients which we'll go through, it actually will be a convolution. And actually, if you do a forward pass as a convolution, the backwards pass will be a cross-correlation.</p><p> So it's good to know the relationship just because of that. Also convolutions have various mathematical properties that researchers care about. And so there's a whole rich set of electrical and computer engineering body of literature that has analyzed convolution operation. And so if we relate these layers to those, then maybe we can analyze them. For example, we can take the kernels that are learned when we do cross-correlation, and we can then flip them and describe them as a convolution and maybe do some analysis.</p><p> Also, this is historically how it was developed. The researchers that develop these had rich image processing backgrounds. And so really, they thought of these layers as a convolution operation. And so that's how these things are also described across the entire literature. So it's important to know that actually, when we describe a convolutional neural neural network or a convolution layer, it turns out that that's not actually what we implement.</p><p> We implement the cross-correlation and it's good to know this if people ask.






<h1>02 Input and Output Sizes</h1><strong>M2L05</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll describe the input and output sizes of a convolution layer and the various design decisions that can be made for these layers. A convolution layer as we described is taking a kernel of a particular size and striding it over the image and doing a dot product across all the locations to produce a spatially organized output map. Now there are several design decisions or hyper parameters that exists for these layers. This is showing specifically the output of a PyTorch documentation. For example, we have the input size that is the width and height but also how many channels.</p><p> For example in an image, we may have three channels, red, green, and blue. And then we'll have how many output channels, and we'll see this is actually equivalent to the number of kernels that we'll use. We'll also have the kernel-size, we can have three by three as we've shown, but you can also have five by five, six by six, or really any size that you want. They don't have to be square either. We can also have the stride that is we'll move the kernel along the image, not one pixel at a time but a few pixels at a time.</p><p> We can also have padding, as we'll see we can pad the image or surrounded by zeros for example, in order to change the output size. So let's took a look at the output size first. The output size of a vanilla convolution operation is just the dimension of the image minus the dimension of the kernel plus one. So for example, the height of the output will be the height of the image, here 5 minus the height of the kernel, in this case 3. So 5- 3 is 2 + 1, which is 3.</p><p> And so here, you can see since we have square inputs and square kernels, we'll have the same square output as well. So we'll have a three by three output map. Again, the reason it's smaller is because if we move that kernel over more than three times, for example, the fourth time, then the kernel goes off the image. And so that's not a valid convolution. And so, a valid convolution is only when the kernel is fully on the image.</p><p> We can also pad the image to make the output the same size. In some cases, we want to have one input size and then have the same output size. And so what we can do is just surround the image, for example with zeros, but there's lots of other things we can do, we can mirror the image. For example, the pixels at the border will be reflective of the pixels in the actual image across the border. And note that padding often refers to adding one dimension.</p><p> So, P=1 or padding size of one here is shown but actually, you're adding two to the height because you're gonna add a padding to the bottom as well as the top. We can also again, move the filter along in larger step sizes than just one. This is called the stride. One interesting thing is that this can potentially result in loss of information. For example, if your kernel size is size three by three and you're striding across sixth values.</p><p> That is, you're taking the kernel on the upper left of the image and then you're going to skip six pixels to the right to get the next one, then you're actually gonna skip pixels. And so, you can actually have some loss of information and you can have dimensionality reduction as well. So you don't necessarily have to skip pixels. For example, if you have a three by three and you're moving by two, you actually are still not skipping pixels, but you do have a smaller output on the output side. And so again, this is just one way that you can do dimensionality reduction.</p><p> Typically, this is not actually the best way to do it. We'll see other better ways because for example, you don't wanna lose information. Note that some combinations are not gonna be valid and can result in skip pixels at the edge. So for example, if you're taking a five by five input, and you're striding a kernel of size three by three, every three pixels, then actually the last time you stride, the kernel, it'll fly off the image. And so really here, you'll only have one pixel.</p><p> That's a valid pixel in the convolution if you're doing valid convolutions with no padding. And so again, that could result in skipped pixel. So you really have to make sure to account for edge effects here. So far we've talked about one channel inputs, such as grayscale images, but in reality images have three channels, red, green, and blue. And so we'll have a tensor of size height by width by three.</p><p> And so there's a question of how to apply the convolution operation. It turns out we can just have a three channel kernel that is, we'll have the depth of the kernel extended to be equal to the depth of the input. So if we have a k1 by k2 kernel, we'll now have a k1 by k2 by 3 kernel. And what we'll actually do is the same dot product operation, except rather than do it with three by three values, that is nine values. We'll do it with three by three by three values.</p><p> That is, 27 values if the kernel size k1 is 3 and k2 is 3. So this depicts how you can do this essentially, again, you're just dot product in the kernel with the image patch, except you're doing it by summing up the contributions across the depths as well. There's a different interpretations. You can, for example, just see this as doing three kernels that you essentially dot product with the three channels of the input image, and then you sum them up spatially. That is you take, let's say, pixel 00 of the three outputs that you'll have for the three kernels that are single channel and then summing them up.</p><p> We can also have multiple kernels per layer. Again, we want multiple feature extractors for each image. And so if these kernels represent things like edges of a particular orientation, we'll want to have many of them. And then we'll also want ones that represent extraction of color features or texture features, and so on. Again, we're not really enforcing what features they'll extract, all we're doing is randomly initializing it, and hoping that gradient descent will essentially learn different features.</p><p> This is a question that's actually pretty common, it's a question of why you won't learn the same exact types of features. So why do you think that is? And it turns out that the reason is that we'll initialize them to different values. So all of these kernels will initialize the different values and their local minima in their local weight space will be different, and so they'll end up learning different features. The gradients for each kernel will be different because we initialize them differently and they'll move in different directions. Now that doesn't mean that you might not have redundancy, you actually will.</p><p> And we'll see this when we actually visualize what this network will learn. So in summary, we'll essentially have many different kernels and each kernel output will be of channel one. And so the number of output channels which we'll combine by just putting them together, concatenating together will actually just be the number of kernel. So here, we have four kernels and so the output map will be of depth 4.
