And again, the height and width will be the same calculations as before.</p><p> So this is the key thing to remember, the number of channels in the output map is equal to the number of kernels that we have. Now let's take a look at the number of parameters. If you remember, this was the reason we did this whole exercise, we wanted to reduce the number of parameters. And so for each filter, let's say in this case, k1 by k2 by 3, that's how many parameters we'll have because each of those values in the kernel is the parameter that we're learning and that we initialize randomly. If you notice we'll have a plus 1 here again for the bias, each kernel will have a bias that the output will be offset by.</p><p> And so let's say we have n kernels, we'll have n times k1 times k2 times 3 plus 1 values for parameter. And so as an example, if k1 equals 3 and k2 equals 3 and we have four of them, then our input channels are 3 and our output channels will be 4. And the number of parameters we'll have is 3 times 3 times 3, which is 27 plus 1, which is 28. And then we multiply that by four because we have four kernels, and so the total will be 112. So that's how many parameters we're optimizing using gradient descent.</p><p> Just as with any other layer, we'll want to vectorize the operation that we want to perform. This is because specialized processors such as graphics processing units are really good at these linear algebra operations. And so, rather than take the image patches and do a four loop around them, in order to apply the kernels, what we're going to do is we're going to take the image patches in the image and vectorize them. So each image patch will be converted to a vector and this can be done even if it's a multichannel image as long as you keep the ordering the same, and then you'll lay them out as rows in a matrix. And then we'll just take the kernels and also lay them out in a different way as a matrix.</p><p> And we'll just perform the whole operation as a matrix multiplication, that is, in the first matrix, we'll have the image patches along the rows. And in the second matrix, we'll have the kernels along the column, and then we'll just multiply them together. If you notice, this applies the same kernel one to all the image patches, which is again what we do in this weight sharing scheme. And that's the key to the convolution operation. And this kernel matrix is all learned.</p><p> All of these values will have initialization of random values and then they'll be optimized to a gradient descent. And because we're applying the same kernel to all the image patches, this is equivalent to essentially doing weight sharing. That is, learning a feature that has the same weight and is applied to all the image patch.






<h1>03 Pooling Layers</h1><strong>M2L05</strong><hr><p>In this lesson we'll talk about a different type of layer called the pooling layer that can perform dimensionality reduction, that is downsampling things like images. Dimensionality reduction is an important aspect of machine learning. As we know, we have very high dimensional input and we often don't actually need to characterize those high dimensional inputs in as much information. That is we can compactly represent the important information, for example, for the task of classifying within the image. And so there's a question of whether we can make explicitly a layer that downsample images.</p><p> And the answer is, of course, yes. Again, there's nothing preventing us from applying many types of different types of differentiable functions. And so again, we show this Pytorch definition, where we can see actually the same types of hyper parameters as the convolution operation as we'll see. And so we can have a layer for example, called a max pooling layer. Here we're going to stride a window across the image very similar to how we did convolution.</p><p> Except rather than perform the convolution operation, we just perform the max operation. For example, we'll take a window three by three and take those nine pixels and perform the max and that will be the first pixel of the output map. Here's an example again with made up numbers where x(0:2,0:2) has these values then we just do a max and we just have an output of 200. So how many learned parameters does this layer have? And the answer is none. This is just the max operation.</p><p> It actually doesn't have an argument other than the things that you're doing the max over. But there are no parameters w that we need to learn for this layer. So this is strictly a max layer that is striding across the image. Now of course, you're not restricted to a maximum, you can use any differentiable function. So for example, you can apply the average pooling where you're averaging all the nine pixels here to get one u output pixel.</p><p> Now this is actually not very common in practice. Typically we use max operation. And actually you'll see in much later neural network architectures, we actually might get rid of the pooling layer all together and perform dimensionality reduction for example, using convolutions themselves. So the output of a convolution and pooling layer, are just multi channel images, that is tensors of size, width, and height by depth. We can actually just sequence them together just like any, other layer.</p><p> For example, we can take an image, perform a convolution operation, in this case, just one kernel, get an output channel or image, and then we can apply pooling to that same output. And so we can just continue to sequence these together over and over again. Now it turns out that this combination where we perform a convolution and then a pooling actually has a powerful feature. Specifically it results in what's called invariant. That is if the feature for example, a beak, translates or moves a little bit in the image, the output value may still remain the same.</p><p> This is because the kernel for example, the feature that picks out beak will have a high value that moves a little bit in the output map. But if we move within the pooling window, that is as long as the movement is not much larger than the size of the pooling window, then the max across that window will still be the same. And so if there's a high value there because there was a beak there, then we'll still after pooling have a high value. And so movements, at least slight movements of the features themselves in the input image will result in the same exact value in the output map. This is what's called invariant.</p><p> Now we can also have something called equivariance. And this is something that convolution operations naturally have, even without polling. That is if the feature such as a beak gets translated a little bit, then the output values may move by the same translation or transformation. So specifically, if the beak feature or pixels move a little bit, then the kernel will still stride across the entire image and pick it up in that new location. And so it'll have a high output value in that new location.</p><p> And so this means that in the output map, the high value moves in the same direction as the actual feature in the image. Again, this is called equivariant. And both of these types of features are actually quite important. For example, in terms of invariants, we want various transformations or things like translation or rotation to not affect the output very much. Eventually at least deep in the network, when we start to do classification we don't want the classification outputs to change very much.</p><p> We still want this bird to be classified as a bird, even though the beak feature moved. And so having these equivariance and invariance properties are actually very important.






<h1>01 Backwards Pass for Convolution Layer</h1><strong>M2L06</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll set up the math or cross correlation again. And discuss some terms and simplifications that we'll make, in order to compute the backwards pass for a convolution layer. It's instructive to calculate the backwards pass of a convolution layer. Even though in practice, automatic differentiation will do it for us. Similar to the fully connected layer, we'll end up at the end with a simple vectorized linear algebra operation.</p><p> That can be implemented efficiently in graphics processing units. We'll also see an interesting duality, between the forwards and backwards passes. As it relates to the cross correlation, and convolution operation. As a reminder, here's the cross correlation operation. Specifically, we'll have a kernel as shown in the middle here, a three by three kernel.</p><p> That is strided across the image on the left, and this produces the corresponding output map on the right. If you remember, we start with a coordinate system on the upper left being (0,0) in the image. And the kernel as well as the output map. Each output pixel specifically gets contributed to by an input pixel, multiplied by some element of the kernel. Let's take a look at the equation a little bit more detail.</p><p> The double summation is iterating across the kernel. And so we can define these iterators a and b, that go from top to bottom and left to right. Starting from the upper left pixel (0,0), and moving down to the lower right. Similarly, we can have iterators across the alphabet. Specifically, this entire equation is showing how to calculate the output y(r,c).</p><p> However, in general we wanna calculate all of the outputs. And so we have these iterators r and z, that again go from top to bottom, and left to right. Now, we're going to make a bunch of simplifications just to derive the gradients. This does not lose any generality, because we can always actually extend it to more complicated settings. But in order to derive it it's much easier to do it this way, it'll make our life a lot easier.</p><p> Specifically, we're gonna assume that we're gonna have one channel input. That is we're not doing RGB, it's just a grayscale image for example. We're just gonna have one kernel. And so, what is the output size gonna be on the output map depth? It'll only have a depth of 1. We're also gonna add padding, and here it's gonna be a little bit different than how we showed padding previously.</p><p> We're not gonna center the image across the padding. We're gonna add padding to the right and to the bottom, in order to make the output size the same. That way we can use the iterators r and c, also on the input. Let's start by defining some things. The output map y is going to be height by width, this is the same size as the input.</p><p> And the reason this is true, is because we added padding at the input in order to make the output the same size. So the upstream gradient, the partial derivative of the loss with respect to our output for this convolution layer. Is given by whatever layer is after this one, and we're going to assume some things about it. Specifically it'll be height by width, and then again this is because we added padding. And you'll notice a small change in the convention in terms of the partial derivative of the loss, is scalar with respect to y a matrix.</p><p> Again, this is just to make our life easier. We'll also use this notation in order to access one particular pixel of the Jacoby. That is we'll want the partial derivative of the loss with respect to one pixel in our output y. We'll have similar accessor mechanisms for the input, as well as the kernel. Just like any other layer, we'll define the convolution layer as some black box.</p><p> That has an input and output, and a set of parameters. Specifically it has an input hl-1, typically some tensor. An output h of l, where again the depth is equal to the number of kernels in this layer. And w, the learnable parameters. In this case the parameters are the kernel values themselves.</p><p> And we'll again wanna perform these various calculation. We wanna compute the partial derivative of the loss, with respect to our input, hl-1. And we'll wanna compute the partial derivative of the loss with respect to our weights. That is the kernel values, in order to update them. And while we wanna do this based on the upstream gradient that were given from whatever module exists after this one.</p><p> That is the partial derivative of the loss, with respect to our output. This is something we're given. And if you remember, we'll use the chain rule to compute this. The partial derivative of the loss with respect to our input. Will just be equal to the partial derivative of the loss with respect to our output.</p><p> Times the partial derivative of the output with respect to our input. Again, this is saying that if we know how the loss changes as our output changes in small ways. And we know how our output changes. If our input changes in small ways, then we can multiply those contributions. And get the ultimate change of the loss with respect to our inputs.</p><p> Similarly, the partial derivative of the loss with respect to our weights, again uses this chain. And so, we'll go through each of these two different terms and show you how we can derive them.






<h1>02 Gradient for Convolution Layer v2</h1><strong>M2L06</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll derive the gradients for the convolution layer and show how interesting characteristics derive from it. And how it can be implemented efficiently just like any other layer using linear algebra operation. Let's start with the gradients for the weight update. Specifically, we can do this one pixel at a time. That is, the partial derivative of the loss with respect to W(a, b).</p><p> For example, we can pick (0, 0) in the kernel. Again, this is one pixel in that middle kernel that's 3 by 3 matrix. And so we can try to ask ourselves the following question. What does this weight affect at the output? Because if you remember, the forward paths induces a computation graph. Where this particular pixel W(0, 0) this weight performs some effect on the output.</p><p> And this can be multiple outputs. You can see it as multiple edges coming from this pixel in the kernel to the output map. And so for each edge that's outgoing from this pixel, we want to have a corresponding backwards edge through which gradients flow. And so what do you think this weight affects at the output? Which of the pixels in the output does it affect? The answer is everything. This is because we're striding the kernel across the input image.</p><p> So in the first location, that first pixel in the input x(0, 0) is multiplied by W(0, 0). And that gets summed with the other contributions to result in that output map y(0,0). But then we move the kernel over one spot, and again it's weight shared, we're using that same weight. And so there's another outgoing edge. Where now we're multiplying W(0, 0) with x(0,1).</p><p> And that gets contributed to the output of y(0, 1), and so on. As we continue to do this, if you think about it, that one kernel pixel is affecting the entire output. If we change that one kernel pixel, it'll actually change the entire output map, at least by a little bit. And so because this one kernel value affects all of the pixels on the output, we actually need to incorporate all of the upstream gradients. That is, partial derivative of loss with respect to y(0, 0), (0, 1), and so on, all the way to the end.</p><p> And the way we can do this is through the chain rule. Again, if you have an outgoing arrow in the computation graph from a particular variable. That is, that variable affects multiple things at the output, then we'll just sum the gradients where we perform the backwards pass. That is, you'll have a corresponding backwards edge back to the same variable and you'll add all the gradients across all the edges. And so this is what it looks like.</p><p> We'll have the partial derivative of the loss with respect to W(a prime, b prime) is equal to the summation across the entire output map. And for each pixel, we'll use the chain rule locally, we'll do the partial derivative of the loss with respect to that pixel. And again, this is given to us as an upstream gradient times the partial derivative of the output pixel with respect to this particular one. And so again, what we're doing is summing over all output pixels and performing the chain rule locally within that. We're multiplying the upstream gradient, which is known times some value that we need to convert compute.</p><p> And so this is really the only term that we need to compute. The partial derivative of our output pixel (r, c) with respect to our weight or kernel (a prime, b prime). Now, what will this look like? You can do this actually visually or analytically. In this case, let's do it visually. On the bottom, you can actually see that when we have a pixel (r, c) at the output.</p><p> And we're applying a particular kernel pixel, (a prime, b prime), and actually there's a question of what is the input pixel that is multiplied by it? And if (a prime, b prime) is (0, 0), then the input pixel (r, c). Again, this is just because the way we define the operation and when we stride the kernel, this is the kernel position that corresponds to the output pixel (r, c). That is, the kernel pixel (0, 0) is multiplied by the input pixel by (r, c). And so when we actually have the kernel pixel, ( a prime, b prime) which input pixel is multiplied by it? The reason we wanna know this is we're trying to take the derivative. And again the derivative of this W times x dot product is just the particular elements of x that are multiplied by the kernel pixel (a prime, b prime).</p><p> And if you look here, the arrow gives it away. It's actually x(r + a prime, c + b prime). And so again, when we're looking at the output pixel (r, c) and a particular arbitrary kernel pixel (a prime, b prime), the actual input pixel which gets multiplied by. And hence is the derivative is x(r + a prime, c + b prime). Again, one way to easily do this is just think of the extremes.</p><p> When a prime and b prime are both 0, then we just get x(r, c), which is visually what is depicted here. If we move it one to the right and one down, then we get r + 1, c + 1, and so on. And so that's it. That's our gradient for the partial derivative of the output pixel (r, c) with respect to the kernel pixel or weight (a prime, b prime). And so let's plug this in to the original equation we had.</p><p> Remember, this is just the derivative for (a prime, b prime) for this one particular kernel location. If we move or stride the kernel across the image, we need to sum up the gradients across the entire output image. And so that's what this equation is doing. And so we have just a summation over all output pixels of the chain rule. The partial derivative of the loss with respect to output pixel (r, c) times x(r + a prime, c + b prime).</p><p> So one thing is you can look at this equation and maybe be reminded of something that we learned about before. In other words, what does this equation actually look like? It's implemented. And if you think about it, it's actually just a cross-correlation. It's the cross-correlation between the upstream gradient, partial derivative of the loss with respect to the output and the input. And we do this particular cross-correlation between the upstream gradient on the output and the input until we get k1 by k2 values.</p><p> And then that is our gradient. This highlights it a little bit better. In the forward path, we're striding this kernel across the image, and we have some particular kernel value that we care about, (a prime, b prime). And we wanna compute the backward pass for that. When (a prime, b prime) is (0, 0).</p><p> This is showing the cross-correlation that we'll be doing. We're actually just cross-correlating literally the input and the upstream gradient, partial derivative of the loss with respect to our output. Which again will be a matrix of size H by W. For the backward pass of k(2, 2), this is showing what we're cross-correlating. Again, if you remember, we're padding the input.</p><p> And so we're gonna cross-correlate the partial derivative of the loss with respect to our output, which is this matrix and the input but offset. And so essentially, this is what we're doing. We're just striding the upstream gradient across the input. And we're gonna do it for the size of the kernel and that will be our gradient. Now that we have the gradients with respect to our weights, let's calculate the gradients with respect to our input.</p><p> Again, the reason we need this is not to update the weights for this layer, but to pass back to whatever previous layer occurred before this one. And so again, what we wanna do is let's calculate this one pixel at a time. The partial derivative of the loss with respect to our input pixel (r prime, c prime). And again, we can try to think what does this input pixel affect at the output? What do you think it is? Again, if you think about it and visualize striding the kernel around the input, the image producing the output. What you'll notice is that there's several positions where the particular kernel touches this pixel.</p><p> And whenever the kernel touches the pixel that means that the pixel gets incorporated into the output through the summation. And that means that if I change this particular input pixel then the output pixel will change. Which means that there should be a gradient. And so I can try to reason about what the neighborhood is that is affected at the output. This is because I need to chain rule it with the partial derivative of the loss with respect to that particular output pixel.</p><p> And so I can try thinking about all the different positions that this pixel effect at the output. And so if you think about it, you can try to visualize all the places where the kernel can be that touches this pixel. So this shows the four extremes of that. On the upper left, that is position one, that is the kernel position where the lower right of the kernel is touching that pixel. Similarly, in position two, the lower left of the kernel is touching the pixel (r prime, c prime).</p><p> Again, the reason we care about this is if the kernel is touching this pixel, that means that pixel is multiplied by a particular kernel value and gets added to the output value. Position three and position four again are the same except they're the extremes on the bottom side. And so we can try to reason at these four extremes and the input side which parts of the output does it touch. The reason we care about this is we're applying the chain rule and we need to know which elements of the upstream gradient that we get. Should we actually use in the chain rule? And if you work it out, this is what it looks like.</p><p> The four extreme points on the input correspond to these four extreme points on the output. That is point four, which is where the kernel position (0, 0) touches (r prime prime, c prime). It actually corresponds to (r prime, c prime) on the outputs. And so again, these are the four points on the output where the corresponding locations are for this particular input pixel (r prime, c prime). Now that we know all the positions on the output map that are affected, we can compute the chain.</p><p> That is, we can compute the partial derivative of the loss with respect to this particular input pixel (r prime, c prime) as the summation of all the affected pixels on the output and sum all the chain rules. That is, partial derivative of the loss with respect to y of the affected pixel times the partial derivative of the affected pixel at the output with respect to this particular input pixel (r prime, c prime). Again, the reason we're summing up all the gradients is because you can see this as a computation graph. Where this particular pixel in the input (r prime, c prime) has an outgoing edge to multiple output pixels. And so for each of those output pixels, we wanna calculate it's effect and calculate the backwards gradient going through that edge.</p><p> And so we can try to figure out what should these actual pixels be? And so this shows the particular pixels that are affected on the output. Specifically, if you think about it, when you have kernel pixel (a, b) equal to (0, 0), then you have the output pixel y(r prime, c prime). That is, when the input pixel (r prime, c prime) touches the kernel pixel (0, 0). That kernel is all the way to the right and all the way to the bottom. And so that corresponds to position four.</p><p> Similarly, when the kernel is all the way to the upper left, that means you're multiplying the input pixel (r prime, c prime) times the lower right of the kernel. So that's why you subtract (r prime- a) and (c prime- b). And so this is the final chain rule or set of chain rules that we're gonna sum in order to compute the gradient with respect to this particular input pixel. Again, the partial derivative of L with respect to y(r prime- a, c prime- b) is given to us, we're given that entire matrix or Jacobian. And so all we need to compute is the right side, partial derivative of y(r prime -a, c prime- b) with respect to this input pixel x(r prime- c prime).</p><p> This time will do this analytically with the definition of cross-correlation again. But in this case we're gonna use different variables, a prime and b prime. The reason is that we've already define a and b as iterators over the kernel in the previous slide. So you wanna distinguish it from that. And we can plug in the actual pixel that we wanted.</p><p> We didn't want r prime and c prime, we wanted r prime- a, and c prime- b. So if we use those pixels instead, then this is what we get. Again, this just comes from the definition of cross-correlation. And so we wanna compute the partial derivative of y of this pixel (r prime- a, c prime- b) with respect to the input pixel x(r prime, c prime). So what do you think that comes out to? That is which of these terms in the double summation actually touch this pixel x(r prime, c prime)? Because all the other terms that touch different input pixels don't matter.</p><p> And so it turns out it's just the kernel of (a, b). The reason is that we want the term with x(r prime, c prime) in it. And this happens when a equals to a prime and b equals to b prime. So now we can just plug into the earlier equation that we had. That is, we summed over all affected output pixels.</p><p> And for each affected pixel perform the chain rule. And if we do that, this is what we get. And again, this might look familiar to you. This is actually just a convolution between the upstream gradient and the kernel. And so this can again be implemented efficiently rather than performing the convolution we can actually just perform cross-correlation.</p><p> But we need to flip the kernel here. And so we can just implement the kernel flipping and cross-correlation. And all of these operations can be implemented via matrix multiplication, same as the fully connected. And so again, we've derived both aspects of the gradients for the convolution layer. There's lots of indexing and it's a little bit confusing.</p><p> So you should go through it to make sure that you understand it. But in the end, we get very simple operation and we get a nice duality. Where if we perform cross-correlation in the forward path, then the particular gradient with respect to the input is actually a convolution which is pretty interesting.






<h1>03 Simple Convolutional Neural Networks</h1><strong>M2L06</strong><hr><p>Now that we have many different types of layers under our belt, that is fully connected layers and pooling layers and convolution layers as well as non-linearity. We can start building very complex functions like building blocks. And so in this lesson, we'll talk about simple convolutional neural networks, which alternate different layers of these types. Since the output of convolution and pooling layers are multi-channel images for tensors, we can actually sequence them just as any other layer. That is, the input will be some width and height and depth.</p><p> And if we're using a number of samples in a mini batch, then the number of batch elements, and the output will be the same. Perhaps, a slightly different height and width or a different depth, but still the same shape tensor. And so we can, for example, take an image perform a convolution layer on it, which has a certain number of kernels of the depth that the image has. So for example, RGB which is depth of three. And the output of that convolution layer will have the depths equal to the number of kernels and the width and height can be either the same, if we pad the input image or slightly smaller If not.</p><p> And then we can perform pooling operation, for example, max pooling. Again, get the same shape tensor, except we might have a smaller width and height for example. And then again, we can just continue to iterate or alternate across these different types of layers. Here's a depiction of a simple convolution neural network that you can design. You have a particular input image, you have one convolution layer, and typically we add non-linearities, because again, convolutions are just linear operations.</p><p> And we can't really alternate linear operations because it doesn't really give us any additional representational power. And so, we'll have the output of the convolution layer be fed through an element-wise non-linearity, and then we'll perform pooling to down sample. And then, we'll apply another convolution layer, again with some non-linearity after that. And at the end of this, we'll have a set of much smaller features. They're still spatially relevant.</p><p> And they're not converted into vectors as they are in fully connected layers, but they're useful, much lower dimensional features. That if we optimize to reduce some loss, will hopefully represent more abstract features the deeper we go in this neural network. And typically, we'll take these last feature maps and feed them through several fully connected layer. And these, again, can be seen as just the classifier. The hidden parts of this fully connected layer will again extract some hopefully, high level abstract meaningful representations that are much lower dimensional again than the input image.</p><p> And then, it will feed it to some last fully connected layer that has the number of nodes equal to the number of classes that we have. And we'll convert the outputs of those nodes which can be considered as scores into probabilities using softmax and feed it through a cross entropy loss for example. So now, we have an end to end convolution all neural network that starts from a raw image progressively extract more and more abstract and meaningful feature representation. Feeds it through some deep, fully connected neural network, and then outputs some set of predictions. And through the loss, we'll be able to optimize the entire chain here through back propagation.</p><p> We'll start at the loss feedback gradients update the weights for the fully connected layers. Push the gradients back through to the convolution layers updates the kernels. Push it through the pooling layers which don't have parameters, but will send back gradients to the inputs. And then, push it again through the convolution layers to update the kernel there all the way to the image, which of course we don't really need to update. So again, we can just optimize this entire chain of transformations in an end-to-end manner.</p><p> Where we're optimizing the best kernels that we can possibly find in order to minimize the loss at all stages, as well as optimizing the weights in the hidden layers as well. This is called a convolutional neural network. One interesting aspect of alternating these types of layers is that you'll have an increasing receptive field for a particular pixel deep inside the network. Again, the receptive field defines what set of input pixels in the original image affect the value of this node or activation deep inside the network. If you see the depiction here, a particular pixel in the output map, in the last convolution layer here is affected by a small window around it in the previous layer.</p><p> But each of those pixels In this small window are affected by some window around it in the previous layer before that, and you can keep going back over and over. And as you can see the window gets bigger and bigger and bigger. And so as you get deeper and deeper into the neural network, as you perform more convolution layers and pooling as well. You'll see that this receptive field continues to increase over and over again, until you get a pretty large influence in terms of the actual input image with respect to a particular pixel deep inside the network. This will be important later when we start designing interesting convolution neural network architecture.</p><p> Just a bit about how people typically depict convolution neural networks. You'll see these types of diagrams quite frequently either in conference papers or in blogs, and so on. You'll see, for example, on the upper left these 3D convolution neural networks where you have progressively smaller image sizes, sort of like a 3d trapezoid. And then, you'll see these two, for example, fully connected layers which are typically depicted as 3D vectors. Or you can have a 2D depiction as well, where you just have a 2D trapezoid and that feeds into two fully connected layers.</p><p> Again, as it will get more and more complex neural networks will wanna depict them in visually simple ways, so that you can immediately understand what the architecture looks like. So we've finally gotten to the point where we can now understand convolutional neural networks as they existed since the 1980s. Again, these have been processing bank checks for example, to perform optical character recognition for quite a while now. So what you can see here is that these architectures are very simple and similar to what I've shown in previous slides. You have an input image, in this case a 32 by 32 image, and you have that being fed into a convolution layer.</p><p> In this case, you have six kernels, and so the output is 6@28 by 28, output maps or feature maps. Now, we down-sample those, in this case it's called sub-sampling, but it's just a max pooling layer, and so we get 14 by 14 output maps. We perform another convolution layer, and again, we get your 10 by 10 maps. In this case we'll have 16 kernels, and this is gonna be a similar trend to other neural network architectures where we'll have increasing numbers of kernels as we get deeper into the network. And then, we have another sub sampling layer.</p><p> And finally, we'll end up with very tiny maps will have 16, 5 by 5 feature maps. And again, we're hoping that these 5 by 5 feature maps represent more abstract features, for example, strokes or shapes in the input image. And so, now these feature maps are small enough that we can feed them into fully connected layers. We don't have to worry that much about a large number of parameters. And in this case, we'll have two hidden layers and one output layer in this case of size 10, because that's the number of output categories.</p><p> If you notice here at the end, it says there are Gaussian connections. And actually, that just corresponds to a mean squared error loss function. This was back then when we didn't use cross entropy. For example, these days rather than mean squared error, we use cross entropy. And so, now we can start looking at understanding what are these networks learning when we feed them a bunch of images and optimize the kernels and the fully connected layers.</p><p> Here, we're gonna look at handwriting and specifically hand digit recognition. And so, we'll have digits from zero to nine and at the output will have a fully connected layer with ten outputs. And in between, we'll have a series of convolution layers as well as fully connected. We could try to visualize various things. In this case, we can visualize the actual output maps themselves.</p><p> That is when we stride a kernel across the image, we'll have an activation map that'll show high values where the particular feature exists on the image. And so, we can try to visualize those output maps and that's what this is visualizing in the intermediate layers. We can also visualize the fully connected layers, but as you notice, they kind of destroy spatial information, and so it's a little bit harder to interpret. And so, we can look at various features that we talked about. For example, we mentioned that convolution operations have this property of equi-variance, that is when you move the input in particular ways across the image, the features also move.</p><p> That is the feature detection in the output maps also move in the same way as you move the input. And you could see this in the intermediate layers. You can also see invariance at the final outputs. That is, even if you move or translate the digit across the image, it'll still output that it's a four. We can also have some rotation invariance.</p><p> Again, this is not as strong as the translation invariance. And you can try to enforce this a little bit more by adding rotated digits inside the training set, as well in a data augmentation form. But here, you can see that there's some rotation that the network is invariant to. At some point, if you rotate it too much, then it stopped predicting that it's a four. This is for example, likely because the convolution kernels, for example, might detect edges of particular orientations.</p><p> And obviously, those orientations change as you rotate the image. We can also have some form of scale invariance where making the digits smaller or larger still results in the network predicting boards, which is what it's printing on the top. And so, now we've come to a point where we can have these very generic building blocks. Just designed arbitrarily complex convolutional or other neural networks. Again, the only thing limiting what we can use is aspects such as memory, computation, or our ability to optimize.</p><p> That is, if we make the networks too complex or too deep, it could be that our optimization methods are too simple and can't really find good local minima. And that actually, indeed turns out to be the case, and we can then make some architectural or other changes in order to fix that. So now, we get to the fun part of the course where we can just explore the space of architectures. And show which ones produce state of the art results across various applications including computer vision and image processing. And later, we'll talk about things like natural language processing as well.</p><p>






<h1>04 Advanced Convolutional Networks</h1><strong>M2L06</strong><hr><p>In this lecture, we'll talk about, Advanced Convolution Neural Network Architecture. That is advanced modifications that we can perform when we design different types of neural networks in order to get state of the art results across large scale applications such as computer vision. One of the key things that was required to show the true power of deep learning, is large scale benchmarks. In the past small data sets just did not have enough data to fit very complex function, yet the real world consists of very complex things. That is the function mapping from images in natural world to class labels is actually pretty complex.</p><p> If you have a very tiny convolutional neural network to try to perform that mapping, you'll probably not be successful. If you have a very large convolutional neural network then it has enough capacity in order to model that function. But fitting all those parameters requires a lot of data and so this is why deep learning came onto the stage again around 2012. It was entered in a particular competition called IMAGENET that had over 1.2 million labelled examples of images where you had each image fitting into one of 1000 different categories.</p><p> These categories included many different dog and cat species but also random objects, such as keyboards and mice, and so on. And so on, the bottom you can see the plot of improvement happening across the years in this benchmark. On the y-axis, you could see the top one accuracy, that is you have to get the correct answer in your top one prediction. So you can take your arg max over your probability distribution over the classes and that is your prediction and that has to be correct. And around 2012 is when deep learning was employed for this and it completely blew the existing methods out of the water.</p><p> It performed much much better than all of the hand coded, hand engineered, feature representations that were then fed into various machine learning classifiers such as Support Vector Machine Don. And as you can see, this was only the tip of the iceberg better neural network architectures kept coming about, better optimization methods, better regularization and data augmentation techniques. All led to progressive improvements such that the accuracy now is above 80% for a very complex data set. So we can take a look at some of the dominant convolutional neural network architectures that have performed really well on this benchmark task. Again, the space of possible convolution neural network architectures and optimization algorithms and loss functions and regularization is very large, and in fact infinite.</p><p> And so we can't really cover all of them, we'll just cover the major ones that dominated the scene. The first architecture that performed really well, again introduced in 2012, is the AlexNet Architecture. This shows again a depiction of the convolution neural network architecture. One thing that might be a little bit strange is that you can see this horizontal split and that's only because this neural network architecture were so large that it could not fit into one graphics processing unit and so it was split into two. And so what you can see is again similar to what we have seen before you have an input image, in this case step three.</p><p> You have a particular convolution operation or convolution layer here of size 11 by 11, performed with a stride of 4 and then you have max-pooling layers, and additional convolutional layers and max-pooling layers, and so on. All the way to a fully connected layer at the end, that leads to output nodes that have 1,000-dimensionality since there are 1,000 classes. Let's take a look more detail of each layer. Here we can see each layer laid out in terms of its dimensionality, specifically, the input here was 227 by 227, which is the width and height of the image by 3, which is the depth of the image. We then performed convolution layer with 96 11 by 11 kernels at stride 4 with no padding.</p><p> What you notice is that in the beginning, very large convolution were done the window size 11 by 11 is pretty large and this was done because again, memory was an issue. These days, the kernels that you'll see are much smaller. And so you can try to reason about how many parameters this convolution layer has or how many do you think CONV1 layer has? In this case, because you have 11 by 11 filters, and you have 96 of them, you'll have 96 times 11 times 11 times 3, because again, all of these filters have a depth of whatever input that they're taking, plus some bias terms. Then we have a pooling layer. In this case, it'll be 3 by 3 max-pooling at a stride of 2 and you'll see that the output is 27 by 27 by 96, again, the depth does not change, we're only changing the width and height.</p><p> Then there are some specialized normalization layers that I won't discuss because they're actually not common anymore. There's another convolution layer, here we have 256 5 by 5 filters at stride 1, padding 2. And as you notice, again, as I mentioned, the number of kernels that we use actually tends to increase as we get deeper into the neural network. One reason for that is the sizes are actually getting smaller and smaller and so because your filter sizes will be smaller, you'll actually be able to not increase the number of parameters too much by having many kernels. Then there's another max-pooling layer again, here it's 3 by 3 that results into a 13 by 13 by 256 output.</p><p> We'll have another normalization layer and then several more convolution layers in sequence, and then finally a max-pooling layer. And here at this point, we have very tiny feature maps, we'll have 6 by 6 by 256 outputs and we'll actually just have fully connected layers after that. So we have two hidden layers FC6 and FC7, and then output layer that has 1000 nodes because that's how many classes we have in the data set. So there are several key aspects that were really important to getting this network to perform really well. This was the first network architecture that used the rectified linear unit, instead of sigmoid, again, sigmoid was extremely popular or 10h in some cases, but they have some properties that were not very good for optimization.</p><p> They had specialized normalization layers, although these days we don't use that anymore. They actually use PCA based data augmentation, so PCA is principal component analysis and you can use it to actually for example. Model different lighting conditions, because lighting actually tends to produce the most variance in your data. And so that's an interesting form of data augmentation, again, it's a little bit computationally heavy and not done anymore. This was again the first network to use dropout as a regularization.</p><p> And again, because there are so many parameters here and such capacity for the network, we do wanna heavily regularize it to prevent overfitting. And finally, in order to eke out those last few percentage points, there were seven neural networks all initialized randomly and trained to convergence, and then their predictions were combined in some way. For example, by weighting the probabilities and summing them together. Subsequent to the initial success of AlexNet lots of new architectures were designed. And often these architectures had various interesting changes, but also just went deeper, that is added more and more convolution and pooling and other types of things.</p><p> This depicts the VGG neural network architecture that was very popular for a while, as you can see, there's actually different variants of it depicted by different letters. One of the key interesting things about VGG is that they used the notion of repeating particular blocks of layers. That is we can have, for example, convolution layers 3 by 3 that are in sequence and this represents a module and then we can just alternate that module in this sequence. And so you can see here different depths of networks had different types of modules that are repeated over and over again. And again, the more layers you had typically the more parameters you have at the end as well.</p><p> So this shows one particular variant, and here again, the input is 224 by 224 by 3 there's a series of convolution layers here. CON3 means 3 by 3 convolutions and then we have pooling layers occasionally interspersed. One thing to notice is that all the convolutions are 3 by 3 unlike the larger convolutions that were made earlier in AlexNet. And again, one of the key factors here is that due to the increasing receptive field, the deeper you get into a neural network, you can actually not use those large convolutions which aren't that efficient. Because they have a lot of parameters, 11 by 11 convolutions have a lot more parameters than 3 by 3 convolutions.</p><p> And so here we're just repeating 3 by 3 convolutions, except that we're gonna make it deeper and then at the end, we still have a good receptive field that is deep inside the network. The last convolutional output map actually has a high receptive field that looks at most of the image in the original input. And so again at the end you have a pooling layer and multiple fully connected layers and so on. One thing to note is that you have most of the memory usage occurring in the convolution layer. Why do you think that is? If you remember in order to produce the gradient in the backwards path, you have to store the activation that you obtain during the forward path.</p><p> This is because the gradients are functions of those forward path activations And so if you think about it, a convolutional layer has a very large output. For example, if you're given an input image 256 by 256, the output is close to that, except that the depth is the number of kernels. So if you're using 256 kernels, you have 200 by 200, roughly times 256 size tensor, which represents a large memory footprint. On the other hand, most of the parameters are in the fully connected layer. The convolution layers don't have that many parameters because the 3 by 3 convolution just have that many 3 by 3 by the depth of input plus some bias terms number of parameters.</p><p> The fully connected layers, on the other hand, have the input dimensionality times the output dimensionality. So in this case, you could see that the first fully connected layer has 7 times 7 times 512, which is the size of the input times 4096, which is the size of the output. And that's how many parameters you roughly have, of course, there's some bias terms as well and that represents 102 billion parameters just for one fully connected layer. So again, the fully connected layers are very parameter heavy and this has a lot of implications for how much data you'll need to fit those parameters and so on. Some of the key aspects of the VGG network again are that there are repeated blocks and these repeated blocks have 3 by 3 convolutions with small strides.</p><p> If you notice AlexNet had very large strides, but you're kind of losing information if you do that. And so here they were able to afford larger strides, some of this came due to better computational platforms, that is better graphics processing units came out. 2 by 2 max-pooling layers were also used and the end result had a large number of parameters, for example in this case we had hundred of millions of parameters unlike about 60 to 70 million parameters per AlexNet. And so here we almost doubled the number of parameters, however, as you can see in the chart in the previous slide, the performance is much better. And so in subsequent years, even deeper networks were developed.</p><p> This shows the inception architecture, which again you can tell has repeated blocks that are repeated over and over again to form the neural network. And each of these blocks are composed of simple layers that we have already learned about, the fully connected layer, convolution layer, max-pooling layers and softmax activation layers to feed cross entropy. And these modules had several interesting aspects, first, they used parallel filters, that is, filters of different sizes in parallel, so that you can get features at multiple scales. For example, if you have small edges or large object parts within the same layer, it can pick them up. They also had these smaller filters such as 1 by 1 convolution that we'll talk about later.</p><p> And so you can manipulate the sizes of all these including padding and so on, so that the output sizes in terms of width and height are all the same. And then you can perform a filter wise concatenation, that is if one of these blocks output a particular width by height by 100, and another block outputs width by height by 50. Then at the end you can catenate them and then you'll have a depth of 150, and again the key idea here is we wanna pick up complex features at multiple scales, all in the same layer. One of the downsides is that this increases computational complexity. It doesn't really add a lot of parameters but you are performing four times, for example, the number of computation, then if you just had a single convolution layer here.</p><p> Eventually, as the depth of the neural networks increased, the ability to optimize them became a bottleneck, that is, as we increased the depth, we actually obtained higher error. So here you could see the 56 layer neural network had a higher error on these different data sets. And so researchers investigated why that was the case and it turns out a simple modification you can make to these network architectures is to add what's called a skip or residual connection. That is you can see here a path that goes from the input x through some set of transformation, some weight layers and for example a relu and that transformation is added to the identity function. That is rather than having to output a completely new thing, given the input, you're just adding residual elements to the original input.</p><p> That is you're just optimizing the weights such that you make small changes to the input, rather than each layer having to output something completely new. And it turns out this is easier to learn and there's some theory here that you can show, for example, that there's better gradient flow. Again, gradient flow is one of the key things that one can look at in terms of making sure that learning is occurring properly. And you can actually show that these skip connections allow learning to occur much more effectively. You can actually show that any particular layer can transfer its output to any other layer subsequently in the neural network, in identity, that is without transforming it.</p><p> This is because for example, it can learn in the weight layers to not perform any transformation or for particular types of inputs, it can learn weights that make the transformation zero. And so this is actually also true in terms of gradients, that is during the backwards path, you can pass the original gradients from any particular layer to any other layer. And so again, the neural network can learn to essentially have good behavior in terms of the forward and the backward propagation of information. And so you can take these particular modules, and again, repeat them over and over again. And so on the left you can see various different types of modules, you can see a 34 layer, plain neural network, but a 34 layer residual neural network, and there's nothing special about 34.</p><p> You can have any number of arbitrary layers here and one of the key things is that adding these skip connections can actually allow you to optimize these deep networks. So the winning entry that used residual networks, for example, used 152 players, and in some cases people have used even more as well. Another interesting development is that we can actually explore the space of possible architectures and in many cases, just modules that we repeat over and over again using learning methods as well. For example, you can use evolutionary learning or reinforcement learning, which we'll learn about later, in order to explore this space in a more intelligent way than just random. We can also learn very densely connected, deep neural networks and then prune connections that we may not need in order to perform automated neural network connectivity, learning.</p><p> And again, typically we don't perform this over large neuro networks, we just learn the building blocks that we then repeat over and over again and we can even parameterize how we repeat these blocks. And so using these automated methods, we can actually in some cases beat human design neural network architect. One thing to note is that often some of these neural network architectures have some difficult properties in terms of optimization. So not all of them are as easy to optimize, residual neural networks, for example, are well known to be very easy to optimize, whereas some of these evolved architectures require a lot more tuning. And one of the key things that is important now is not just increasing the depth and number of parameters, but actually the reverse.</p><p> How can we get the same performance by reducing the number of parameters? And so over time, people have designed different types of architectures that actually get even better performance but are much more efficient. So again, different evolved architectures such as what's called EfficientNet have been designed and these networks perform really well as well as not have a lot of parameters. And again, you can see the sheer pace of progress that has gone from a top one performance of around 55% for AlexNet, all the way up to 80 plus percent on a very challenging data set that has 1000 categories. So now we'll start exploring some of the more interesting things that you can do with convolutional neural networks as well as other types of architectures. Because we can not just add depth, but we can also add for example, additional loss functions or additional types of layers that are specific to different types of domains that really increase the performance across a wide range of applications.</p><p>






<h1>05 Transfer Learning & Generalization v2</h1><strong>M2L06</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll talk about generalization, that is how can we generalize from the training set to the test set, as well as transfer learning, which can significantly reduce the amount of labelled data that we need to fit the large number of parameters that we'll have in these very complex networks. Given a particular architecture that you're exploring, there are several sources of error that prevent you from fully modeling the real world. For example, there is an optimization error that is, even if your neural network can perfectly model the world, your optimization algorithm may not be able to find the good weights that model that function. There's also estimation error. Even if we do find the best hypothesis, this best set of weights or parameters for our neural network that minimizes the training error, that doesn't mean necessarily that you will be able to generalize to the testing set.</p><p> For example, you might be overfitting or you might be learning features that perform really well on the training and are actually reasonable to learn. For example, they might be very simple features or features that just tend to occur in your training set, but they don't generalize very well. You might also have modelling error, that is given a particular neural network architecture, your actual model that represents the real world may not be in that space. For example, there may be no set of weights that model the real world. And so you can take a look at a simple neural network, for example, multi-class logistic regression.</p><p> And you can think about here we're actually using a very simple function. And so our modelling error is gonna be pretty large. Clearly the mapping between images to class labels can't be modelled by this simple function. And so there's no real set of weights within the space that we're exploring that can model it. If we use AlexNet instead what would happen? For example, would our modeling error be larger or smaller? Since we're using a much more complex neural network with much higher capacity, our modeling error is probably going to be smaller.</p><p> That is our more complex function might be more likely to be able to fit this really complex function that models real natural images. However, we'll still have things like estimation error, even if we find the best hypothesis that minimizes the training error. We may not be able to generalize, because we have a lot of parameters, maybe we have a small amount of data and will overfit. And we may have optimization error. For example, because we made the neural network deeper, maybe the dynamics of our optimization will get more difficult to handle.</p><p> Again, this is true of larger networks as well. Our modeling error will continue to get smaller because at some point, we'll have so much capacity that we can probably model the true function that we're after. However, it may be that our optimization error will continue to increase. Or it may be that our estimation error will continue to increase because we're overfitting more and more and more and we're not applying appropriate regularization. Again, all of the things that we have learned about such as dropout regularization, batch normalization, residual networks, and so on, are all techniques designed to address some aspects of these sources of error.</p><p> One question that always comes up is what if we don't have a lot of data? Again, we don't typically have a million labeled examples for all of our domains that we're interested in. In fact, getting that many examples is pretty expensive and time consuming. You need people to look at a million things and actually typically you need multiple people to look at every data point in order to make sure that it's correct. And so one of the key surprises that came out early in the resurgence of deep learning is transfer learning. That is we can reuse the features that we learned on a very large dataset or completely new things.</p><p> Here's how it works. The first step is we'll train on some large scale datasets, such as image net. That is we'll take a very large convolutional neural network, optimized all of the parameters, both for the convolution layers as well as the fully connected layers. In the second step, we'll take our custom data set. Our data set may have different categories, it's not gonna have the same thousand categories that image net has.</p><p> And so what we're gonna do is we're gonna initialize the network. So the parameters or weights that we use as initialization won't be from the methods that we talked about such as Xavier. We'll just industrialize it from the training that we've already done on image net. However, because the last fully connected layer should be different because the number of classes might differ or the classes themselves differ, then we'll remove the last layer and just add a new layer. Here it's shown as a smaller one because maybe we have less classes.</p><p> That part is initialized randomly. The final step is just to continue training from that initialization on your new data set. So again, you initialize based on the weights that you learned on the large scale data sets, such as image net, but then you now train again using your data set. This can be done in several ways, you can update all the parameters, just train as normal and update both the convolution filters as well as the last linear layers. Or you can freeze particular aspects or parts of the neural network.</p><p> For example, you can decide to freeze all the convolution layers. What does freezing mean? Freezing means that you don't actually update those weights or parameters. And so you can just update the last fully connected layers instead. Why would you wanna do this? This reduces the number of parameters that you need to learn given your new data set. If you only have a small amount of data, then maybe you don't have enough data to fine tune all of the features across all the convolution layers.</p><p> Maybe you can just treat the large scale trained features as some fixed feature extractors that hopefully have relevant information because you trained it on a lot of other categories. And then you freeze it, and then you only update the weights of the fully connected layers that depend on those features. This works extremely well. And these days seems very quaint because everybody does this, but actually was pretty surprising back when it was discovered. One of the key findings is that if you train a convolutional neural network on image net which has 1,000 categories and performs classification.</p><p> You can actually apply that neural network to all sorts of different types of tasks. For example, here we show we can actually perform very small amount of data training on completely different types of things such as scene recognition. For example, classifying whether a scene is a beach or indoors and so on. If you think about it, this might require very different features than classifying objects. But it turns out that using the features or the weights as initialization ends up doing extremely well when fine tuned.</p><p> And others have shown and we'll see this later in the course as well that we can actually also use these features, for example, that were trained for classification on completely different tasks. For example, object detection where you're classifying tiny windows in an image rather than the entire image itself, or even for various forms of combinations of images and language. For example, image captioning, were given an image we wanna generate a set. The image features that we extract from this classification network are actually useful even for those kinds of tasks, which is pretty surprising. However, there are limitations, it's not magic.</p><p> For example, this transfer learning approach does not work very well if the target task that has a new data set is very different. So for example, if we train a convolutional neural network on natural imagery, and then we wanna apply it to things like sketches where you just have a silhouette or a contour of an object. Those features actually might be so different that maybe the initialization doesn't matter that much or won't help you that much. It also turns out that if you have enough data for the target domain, and it does have some difference from the source domain, then you might actually get better results by just training on the original target data set itself with random initialization. This was shown recently in a paper that's cited here.</p><p> Another interesting finding is that we still haven't reached a bottleneck in terms of amount of data, if we do have it. That is if we continue to add more and more data beyond the millions that we already have, performance continues to improve. And again, this is quite surprising. On the left, you see this from a Google blog. As we get to 300 million examples compared to the one million in image net, our performance on object detection as measured by a metric called mean average precision on the y axis continues to improve.</p><p> And you could see this both for fine tuning from image net classifier or weights to no fine tuning. In both cases you get significant improvement and the curve is still linear. And again, this isn't a log scale, and so we know that more data will continue to help. We haven't reached the peak here. On the right we can see some exploration where there is some irreducible error that we get to eventually, again in log scale, but this is only for a particular domain.</p><p> What's interesting is that there are different regimes that were identified. For example, if you have too little data, then at some point, it's very difficult to decrease the error. Then you enter a power law region where essentially the training data set size in log scale continues to linearly improve the error again in log scale. And then again, at the end, you might get into some regime where you can't reduce the error further, no matter how much data you get. But again, it's not clear that we've reached that for many of the interesting applications such as computer vision or natural language processing.</p><p> Finally, there's a lot of interesting research that's being done on the other end of the spectrum. That is how far can we push in terms of reducing the number of labelled data. Unfortunately in this field, there's a lot of different settings. So we have semi-supervised learning, where we have a single label data set and a single unlabeled data set. And typically the amount of labeled data is much less than than unlabeled data, but there's no shift between the two.</p><p> By shift I mean, there's no distributional difference from a probabilistic definition. There are different types of shift actually. You can have non-semantic shift shown on the lower left. For example, you can have a sketch of a bird or natural image of a bird. You can also have semantic shift that is shown on the lower right.</p><p> You can have both images, but images of different things. And so there's a whole range of different types of machine learning settings that people have looked at. Domain adaptation, for example looks at if you have a single label data set and a single unlabeled target data set, but there's no semantic shift. That is the label space is the same, you have the same categories. But you might have some type of non-semantic shift, that is you might go from natural world images to sketching.</p><p> You might also have what's called few-shot learning where you have only one example or maybe three examples and you're learning to generalize from a very large data set with many categories and many labelled examples. All the way to a new data set that has completely new types of objects, but you only have one to three examples per category. And this is the same again for a bunch of other different types of settings. And a lot of these are still in the research stage where it's not clear how to get the best performance across these settings. However, very significant performance gains have been made in the past few years.</p><p> For example, in semi-supervised learning, you can often get very small degradation in accuracy with only 5% to 10% of the data, which is pretty impressive. And as the research progresses, I'm sure many of these settings will become much improved.






<h1>CS7643 Module 3 Introduction</h1><strong>M3L00</strong><hr><p>In this module, we'll go beyond fully connected or convolutional neural networks. We'll specifically start looking at richer structures, such as sequences or graphs. For example, we'll take a look at a sequence of words in a document and try to process it sequentially, propagating information as we go along such that we can represent the meaning of everything we've read thus far. We'll see that a notion of attention will be important that is looking at sequences of things or graphs of things where you have many nodes or many elements. And trying to figure out which ones are important to incorporate at any one point in time.</p><p> We'll also cover cool applications such as machine translation. And finally, we'll see examples where we can actually combine things like computer vision and natural language processing. To jointly process both of these modalities together by again, combining these building blocks together all into a large computation graph, that can be optimized using the same algorithms that we've discussed. For example, we'll cover things like image captioning, where you can take an image and generate a sentence automatically describing that image. Thus far, we've covered two types of neural network architectures.</p><p> We began with fully connected neural networks which consist of linear layers where each output node is connected to all input nodes. Then we can alternate these with nonlinearities as well as make the architecture deep, such that we have hidden layers which hopefully extract meaningful lower dimensional features as we go along the network. And then at the end, we can make some predictions. We've also talked about convolution layers, which are actually not that different from linear layers. Really here, what we're doing is making use of the fact that we know about images and their statistical regularities and trying to add architectural biases.</p><p> That is we're changing the connectivity pattern to better reflect the patterns or statistics of the data. So in this case in images, we know that we don't need to connect every output node to all input pixels. Because we wanna extract not global features across the entire image, but small, spatially coherent features such as edges, or textures, or color and so on. And so we'll use the notion of weight sharing and take whose weights were optimizing and stride them along the images. And then we'll alternate these with other types of layers such as pooling or nonlinearity layers.</p><p> And at the end again, once we have sufficiently low dimensional structures, extract meaningful hidden representations in the form of vectors for fully connected layers and then make predictions. Again, the reason we did this is to add architectural biases such that we can learn better and faster with less data. That is all of these neural network architectures if they have sufficient depth and some mild assumptions can learn any function. And so really it's just the question of how much data will we need and how many parameters or what is the complexity of the function itself that we're learning that will be necessary to learn this function. So it turns out for other types of structures, such as sequential structures.</p><p> For example, words in a large document or graph structures where you have relationships among many different elements, there are other types of architectural biases that we can add. And so throughout the years, several research groups have developed these types of architectural biases. And that's not to say any one of these are the best. Again, this is the space that researchers have currently explored and represents the current state of the art but it It may be an ongoing discussion. For example, convolution all neural networks were originally also used for text data before we had more specialized structures.</p><p> And conversely, there's current research looking at how to represent image type structures using things like attention based mechanisms which are developed for text. One of the early network architectures for sequential data, such as text or recurrent neural networks. Unlike feed-forward neural networks, where we have a fixed network of a particular depth, and the output of the previous layer is fed to the input of the next layer, and all the weights or parameters of each layer are unique. Here we'll instead have a recurrent structure, we'll specifically have a state vector representations that is a vector of numbers that represents everything we have encountered in the sequence thus far. So for example, as we read the sentence and go along the sentence we'll continuously maintain a vector that represents all of the words that we have read thus far and their meaning.</p><p> And given the next word, we'll then feed this current state representation into the next layer and then update this representation. The key thing is that this update mechanisms that is the weights of how we update the vector as we go through the sequence is weight shared. That is we'll have the same parameters applied over and over again, no matter whether it's the first word or the hundredth word. One of the key advantages of this is that it addresses the limitations of fully connected neural networks where you're expecting some fixed size input. And so you can't really process a variable length sentence that has an unknown number of words.</p><p> Here because we're using the same size vector that is just updated over and over again using the same function as we go along the sequence you can actually process and arbitrary length sequence. We'll learn that recurrent neural networks have several disadvantages in terms of optimization of long sequences, such as hundreds or thousands of elements. In the case of language, for example, you can have a very large document with thousands of words. What we'll find is that as we back propagate through this recurrent structure, the gradients may get smaller and smaller or larger and larger in what's called the vanishing or exploding gradients problem. And so this will make optimization much more difficult.</p><p> Another problem is that propagation of information through this single vector is difficult. For example, making sure that at any point in time, we can represent all this words that occurred early in the document while we're processing the end of the document is difficult. You have to propagate all the information necessary at any point in time across the entire sequential structure. In order to address these issues, researchers developed what's called attention based mechanisms. Rather than have one compact vector represent everything that we've read thus far in the document for example, we'll just have a vector that represents each element, for example, each word in the document.</p><p> And then at any point in time, we'll use an attention mechanism to weight up or down each of these elements. For example, you can think of using the softmax function where you have a probability distribution across all the past words that you've read. And so this represents some sort of competition mechanism where you can up and down weight each element. And if you need to while processing the current word, incorporate information from way back early in the document, then you can do so by just weighting those elements more heavily at this time stand. So this allows you to dynamically at each point in time as you're processing the current word highlight or focus on an arbitrary set of passwords as you wish.</p><p> We'll also cover what are called transformer architectures, which are really using attention based models as building blocks. And add other things such as multi-head attention that is multiple attention mechanisms for the same items that are combined together in order to achieve state of the art results. While a lot of these architectures were developed for sequential pieces of data, such as words in a large document, it's important to recognize that this can be generalized. Specifically in text we have an ordered set that is we know which word comes before which other words, but if you think about it, attention based mechanisms don't really require this. We had an attention that up or down weighted each element in this set of words, but nothing required them to be ordered.</p><p> For example, the softmax function can actually produce a probability distribution not only across an arbitrary set of items ordered or unordered. It can actually produce this probability distribution or weights across an arbitrary size set. That is, it doesn't matter how many elements there are, you can still apply the same softmax function. And so we can generalize all of these notions to a graph where you have those and edges. The nodes have a vector representation representing its own local features.</p><p> For example, if a node is an image, we could use a CNN to extract the features of that image if the nodes are users, we can other mechanisms to extract features for that user. Or if the nodes are words, then we can extract meaningful vector representations for the words. And then, we can combine this across the graph where we refine the features of each node, using not just its local features, but also the features of its neighborhood. And we get this neighborhood, using the attention mechanism. And again, this can use softmax Or we can use learn similarity functions that are also optimized.</p><p> And so given a particular node, we can now get refined features that take its local features as well as the weighted sum of its neighborhood and updates that representation. And so this represents not just its local appearance or other features, it also represents the structure of the entire set of elements. In this module we'll talk about several applications, and there's different taxonomies that you can break these applications into. For example, for sequential data, there's different input and output representation. For example, in many to many, we have many elements all sequentially ordered that are output into many elements that are also sequentially ordered.</p><p> For example, speech recognition, we have the input being high frequency sound signals, again ordered temporarily. And then we have the output which are the sequence of words that were said in that sound.
