We can also have many to one, for example, we can have a sentence which are a sequence of words and we wanna only output a classification tasks such as the sentiment is this sentence negative, positive or neutral. And we can also consider one to many and one to one again. So again all of these can in general be represented as mapping one sets of things to another set of things and they can be sequentially ordered or not.</p><p> And they can have many elements or not. In this module we'll focus a lot on natural language processing or NLP tasks. So let's see how we can build up representations starting with vectors that represent the words all the way to vectors that represent entire sentences or entire documents. One of the application areas of sequential modeling is language model. That is we wanna model the probability of a sentence occurring in some language.</p><p> For example, we wanna say what is the probability of this particular sequence of words occurring together? Again, you can try to learn this probability distribution by processing billions of pieces of text, for example, from the internet. And we can factorize this probability distribution as really a task of modelling the next word. That is we can have a probability of the first word, and then the probability of the second word given the first word and the probability of the third word, given all the previous words before it and so on. And so using this factorized probability distribution, we can model what is the probability of a sentence. You can also generalize this to rather than predicting just the next word, actually predicting all the contextual words.</p><p> For example, given the word into, you might wanna predict all the surrounding words before and after it. Now you may wonder, why should I want to do any of this? Clearly we have the large pieces of text, for example from the internet and so that I know the answers to this is not a task that I might wanna do. Now there are several answers to this. First, you might wanna generate text. So given a word that's given by a human, you might wanna generate whatever sentence that might come after it.</p><p> Again, this is just generating some plausible finishes to the sentence that you started. You might use this for auto complete, and so on. But actually more interesting answer is that we can actually learn really good vector representations for each word in order to, for example, feed it into sentence modeling using this simple task. What's nice about the task is that it's self supervising that is no human has to do any extra annotation. All we have to do is get the large amount of textual data across the internet or in documents, and we can automatically train a model that somehow represents each word as a vector such that it represents everything necessary to predict for example, the surrounding word.</p><p> And we'll find that these vector representations for words actually turned out to be really interesting, that is, they have some interesting structure that reflects the structure in language. Once we have embeddings for words, we can actually sequentially structure them similar to how we talked about before using recurrent neural networks are attention based mechanisms. But more generally, we can structure them as a graph where you just have nodes and each node has an associated vector. And the relationships between the different elements are more complex than just the sequence or an ordering. Specifically, we can, for example, learn similarity function built on things like softmax, or other functions that allow a competition between elements in order to build a graph.</p><p> So that when we update the feature representation of C, we use both its own embedding, but also the embedding of it's neighborhood, in this case A and B, that connect to it. And we know this neighborhood based on just the learned similarity function. And so all of this, including the similarity function and the refinement of how you take A, and B, and C vector representation to refine the representation of C are all learned. Now again, there are some cool applications because now we have arbitrary elements in a set that all have embeddings and we can combine these embeddings across many different modalities. For example, if we have a page that has videos and other textual information, we can actually combine the embedding for each page, the video embedding and the word embedding.</p><p> And each of these embeddings can be optimized individually using their own data. For example, page embeddings can be optimized based on their graph structure, that is, the connectivity structure of which page links to what other pages. And then we also can jointly optimize all of these embeddings together to perform some combined task. For example, recommendation of videos that combines not just the video features, but also the features of the page that it's on, as well as the features of the words inside that page. We'll also cover all sorts of cool applications such as machine translation.</p><p> For example, we may wanna input one language and have the neural network model output the same text in a different language, hopefully capturing all of the meaning. And so this can be as seen as a search problem, for example, searching all possible output representations in terms of the target language given the text that's in the source language. One of the explicit benefits of attention based mechanisms is that they can perform what's called alignment across languages. For example, when we're translating German to English, there's not a one to one mapping between German words and English. It's really there are different grammatical structures across the two languages.</p><p> And so some subsets of words in the German can represent one or more output words in English. And so what we wanna do is use attention mechanisms to actually represent this alignment. That is, every time we're outputting some word in the target language, we'll look at some embeddings or words in the source language in a weighted manner. We'll also see familiar architectures such as encoder or decoder architectures, which we've seen for images such as image segmentation tasks, but here we apply for language translation. Specifically, we'll wanna encode the entire meaning of the source sent in one vector, and then use that one vector to decode or output a set of words in the target language.</p><p> And we can also use attention mechanisms here to rather than compactly represent everything in the sentence via one vector we'll attend to all the words in the source language. Finally we'll show how these techniques such as machine translation can actually affect people's lives positively and some of the challenges that occur when dealing with real world data. For example, having to perform language identification before you perform translation, as well as predicting what dominant languages a particular user is using.






<h1>1 Structures and Structured Representations</h1><strong>M3L11</strong><hr><p>In this lesson, we'll introduce the concept of structured representation. That is, unlike convolutional neural networks, which have very specific connectivity biases, we'll try to develop architectures that can learn some of these structured representations explicitly. Thus far, we've talked about how to build and optimize deep feedforward architectures consisting of linear and nonlinear units. And again, this can be generalized to arbitrary computation graphs. And we can use backpropagation and automatic differentiation to optimize them.</p><p> We've talked about convolutional neural networks, which alternate convolution, pooling, and nonlinear layers, as well as fully connected layers at the end, in order to process spatially structured information, such as images. One of the main motivations for convolution layers was adding architectural bias in order to represent the things that we know are true in images, such as stationarity, that is small local features that can appear anywhere in the image. And we showed that, indeed, it is able to learn after optimization of compositional feature space. That is, low level features such as edges, or textures, or color, mid-level features representing shapes such as circles, or corners, and so on, and then, object parts. If you think about it, what we did in convolution layers is to add this architectural bias, and specifically, determine how the connectivity between nodes and receptive fields in the image interact.</p><p> But we may wanna do this in a much richer way. For example, we may wanna represent arbitrary items or elements, not just pixels. Let's say, also words or other items in the world, and try to model how relationships between them exists, and try to do that in a learnable way. And this is true because compositionality exists not just in computer vision. We also have it in other domains.</p><p> For example, in speech, we have things like different input representations of the raw audio, as well as phonemes, and entire words, and sentences. And similarly, in natural language processing where we have text, we wanna represent the compositional nature of language. And so, we may want to think about designing general architectures that can explicitly learn to represent these kinds of compositional elements in a way that's not as strong in terms of architectural bias. That is, we don't, for each modality or domain, explicitly try to design the connectivity structure to represent the compositional nature in that particular domain. But we may want a more general mechanism that can automatically learn this compositional structure automatically.</p><p> And the structures that we wanna model, that is, the relationships between different elements, may be even higher level than each different modality. For example, we may want to model the relationship between different elements in a scene, such as shown here. This is what's called a scene graph. We want a graph representation where each node can be an object or an object part. And we wanna model the spatial or other types of relationships between them, in this case, showing that the man is wearing a hat and that the mountain is behind the horse.</p><p> And this similarly occurs in language, where we may want to model more than just the sequential structure in a particular sentence. We may wanna model different interrelationships between the words, for example, being able to model which words come across which contexts. Or being able to model things like parse trees or grammatical structures. And the structures that we want to represent may go even higher level than that. We may want to represent all concepts in the world.</p><p> This shows a data set called Wikidata, which has elements such as people, and places, and occupations, and so on, and maybe even has information about relationships, such as a person can be an author. And we may wanna learn feature vector representations for each nodes in this. For example, each element here, each data point might wanna have an associated feature vector representation. And this feature vector should represent the structure in some way. For example, things that are conceptually similar should also be similar or close by in terms of their feature vectors.</p><p> And we can maybe even also explicitly represent this as a graph. That is, we can have nodes and edges, where edges represent some sorts of relationships or similarity. If you think about it, the current architectures we've discussed, fully connected layers and convolution neural networks, can't really represent these kinds of structures. In some sense, convolution layers do add architectural biases in terms of connectivities. That is, based on our knowledge of computer vision, we add some bias in terms of how nodes are connected to the image.</p><p> But what we want is something more general, that is, a general method to represent relationships between different items, and we wanna do this in a learnable way. That is, we don't want to impose connectivity patterns for particular domains. We want to just have some representation that can hopefully learn this connectivity pattern, given the particular data and the structure in it. And so, we'll talk about various forms of architectural biases that researchers have developed. Ranging from recurrent neural networks, which are typically designed for things like sequential data.</p><p> To more general attention-based mechanisms that can up or downweight a whole range of elements in a set. And this can be an ordered set, such as language, or it can be an arbitrary set of different unordered items. And we can then generalize this even further to a graph representation, where we explicitly model nodes in this graph and their feature vectors, and then represents the neighborhood of that node. And we're able to use that structure to refine the features to represent, not just local features, but also, features of the neighborhood. And so really, graphs are the more general way to look at this.</p><p> We can have embeddings or vectors, for each node, and we'll show how to do this. We already know how to do this for images. For example, we can feed it through a convolutional neural network, for example, that's pre-trained. We'll show how to do this for things like words. But we can, in general, come up with embeddings or vector representations for anything.</p><p> And then, once we have these embeddings, we can represent them as a graph where the nodes are feature vectors and the edges represent some sort of connectivity, or similarity, typically. And so for each node, for example, C, we can find the input nodes, that is, nodes that are similar in terms of some type of relationship. And this can be multiple types of edges. For example, we can represent in that computer vision image example, something being on top of the horse, or something being in front of or behind, and these can be different types of edges. When representing structured information such as graphs, there are several things that are important.</p><p> For example, we'll have what's called a state or a vector representation that compactly represents all the data we've looked at thus far. In the beginning, this is just the different nodes or elements that occur in this image, for example. For example, the mountain, the man, the horse, and so on, can all have features associated with them as extracted from a convolutional neural network and an object detector. So each of these regions of interest have associated features to them. We then have things like neighborhoods, which represent what other elements to incorporate, these are the edges in the graph.</p><p> For example, should a man and a horse be connected for this image, and if so, through what relationship? Typically, we do things like similarity relationships, although in this case, you can also see other things like spatial relationships, or verbs that one element is performing on the other. And then, once we have the nodes and the relationships, that is, the edges, we can propagate information. Now what we wanna do, for example, is represent as a vector the notion that the man is riding a horse. It's not just any man, it's not just a horse, independently, these are two interconnected objects. And so, we may want to have a representation, a vector that represents that relationship.</p><p> And so, what we'll do is through the nodes and the edges, perform some functions or computations in the computation graph that combines these different vectors together in a special way that we'll see. For example, a weighted summation in order to come up with a new vector that represents not just the individual items, but also, the items as seen through their relationships. This is essentially a problem of propagating information. And again, after this propagation of information, you get a new state or a new vector. Now I'm showing a visual example right now.</p><p> Similarly, in language, you'll have a set of words that will read through the document, and we'll have a state representation that will track through the sentence. And in that case, it's not a complex graph structure, it's just a flat linear sequential structure. But concepts that we'll learn actually will relate to all of these different types of forms of structures. One of the key elements for how to update the representation of a particular node based on its neighborhood, or some other sets of elements, is what's called an attention mechanism. And since we wanna have a differentiable attention mechanism, typically, we'll use things like softmax functions.</p><p> Specifically, given a set of other vectors that we wanna weight up and down based on the current node that we're representing, we'll essentially do a dot product between our current node and all the other nodes. And then have a softmax function on top of that to convert it to a probability distribution. In that way, you're weighting all the nodes, and then we'll actually compute a weighted summation of all the other nodes and use that to refine this particular node's representation. This notion of attention is extremely powerful, because it allows you to represent some arbitrarily sets of information, and this set can be any size. You can apply the softmax function to any sized set, and you can then automatically use that to weight and combine information.</p><p> And so, again, this can be applied to all manner of structures. This can be applied to sequential structures, where, as you're reading a sentence, for example, to translate it to a different language. You can essentially look at arbitrary past words and weight them up and down every time you're converting it to a new word in the target language. Similarly, you can apply this to graph structure, such that every time you process a node, you can find the weighting or similarity to all its neighbors. And use that to do a k-nearest neighbor-type refinement, except in a fully learnable way.</p><p> Now we've talked pretty generally about structured representations and relationships between different item. And so, we'll make this much more concrete as we move forward. And we'll talk about specific structures, specific representation, and specific application, such as natural language processing. However, let's start with a simple example that relates nicely to convolution layers that you know about. If you remember, convolution layers were developed because it did not make sense to connect an output pixel to all input pixels across a high-dimensional image or a feature map.</p><p> This is because we know that we'll probably want to extract local features, edges, and so on, and that doesn't require tying it to the entire set of pixels. However, we can actually generalize this and allow the network to learn its own connectivity pattern through an attention-like mechanism. This is what's called a non-local neural network. This is called non-local because unlike convolution layers, you don't have for each output node a very specific local receptive field. Instead, what you'll have is the equations on the upper right.</p><p> Specifically, to compute the output yi, that is pixel i and the output y, we'll sum over all possible inputs g. And so this is very similar to a fully connected neural network. Except that inside the summation, we'll have a weighted summation. That is, we'll have a weighting factor, a multiplication factor, between two functions, f and g. Now, g(xj) is just extracting some set of features from the input xj.</p><p> The function f is a binary function that takes not just xj, but also xi, because we're computing the output at yi. And so, what we're doing is we're going to compute a similarity between xj and xi. And we're going to modulate the contribution of the features from xj by that similarity. So you can see on the lower right some examples for f and g. And again, this can be generalized to many other things, these are just examples.</p><p> Specifically, for f(xi,xj) what we'll have is just a Gaussian around the similarity, in this case, just a dot product. A dot product is just an unnormalized cosine similarity. And so what we're doing is we're saying how similar are xi and xj, and then we're exponentiating. And so high values mean that xi and xj are very similar, and low values will mean that they're not that similar. And so, the function g(xj), which is just extracting features, again, in just a linear way.</p><p> You just have a Wg times xj, will be modulated by the similarity function. And so, again, the output yi is just the weighted summation across all j's, and the weighting is dynamically computed based on the data. That is, you're computing the similarity function f(xi,xj) dynamically. And so you might wonder, why is this different from a fully connected layer? And the fact that you're doing this dynamically is the key part that makes it different, because when you're doing a fully connected layer, the weights are not dynamic. That is, you learn the weights, and then you apply those weights regardless of the input, they're not data-dependent.</p><p> In this case, the similarity function f(xi,xj) is data-dependent. And so you're modulating the inputs in a data-dependent manner, and this makes all the difference. It allows the network to, in effect, learn the connectivity pattern, learn for each piece of data what is important. And then, sum up the contribution across those pieces of data in order to form the output representation. Here's an example from the paper showing what was learned.</p><p> This shows arrows across, not just space, but also time. One of the interesting things is this summation across j can be not just for the current input, but it can also be input across time. And so what we can see is that the arrows with high weights are visualized, whereas, all of the connectivity that is ignored is not shown here. And so the red arrows represents high similarity function. And what you'll see is if you wanna, for example, take a video, which consists of many different frames, and you want to extract what activity is being performed in the video, such as playing soccer or kicking.</p><p> Then you allow the neural network to automatically figure out which pixels to pull from across space and time in order to combine those features into an overall representation that, at the end, you can use to classify. Again, this shows the power of attention-based mechanisms to automatically and dynamically, in a data-dependent way, figure out what's important in the input. And it can do this in a way that's not specific to how many there are. If you notice, this function does not actually depend on anything about how many (xj's) we choose from. And so, if you learn this particular neural network, non-local neural network, you can actually apply it to all sorts of other, for example, image sizes, and so on.</p><p> And again, this is the power of these attention mechanisms in representing relationships between different types of things. And we can apply the same type of ideas for representing the relationships between words in a piece of text or between different nodes in a large graph.






<h1>0 Lecturer Introduction</h1><strong>M3L12</strong><hr><p>Hi, my name is Jean Maillard and I'm a research scientist at Facebook AI within the language and translation technologies team. In this course I will be covering various topics related to sequence modeling.






<h1>1 Language Modeling Part 1 v2</h1><strong>M3L12</strong><hr><p>Welcome to Part 1 of the module on language modeling. This first part will be a high level overview, explaining what language models are, what they are good for, and giving you some example applications. It will be followed by a more in depth part 2, where we will see how language models are actually built and trained. In very general terms, language modeling is the task of determining a probability distribution of a sequences of words, such as the one in the example. But perhaps more interestingly, a language model would also let us compare probabilities between different sequences of words.</p><p> Allowing us to determine for example, which of two sequences is more likely. But still, even assuming we managed to do this with real text, instead of with the silly examples I picked, what would that achieve? Before we explore real world applications, let us dive a bit deeper into how we would model these probabilities mathematically, which will help us motivate the applications. So, let us define the problem a bit more rigorously given a sequence s of words, which we can decompose into w1, w2, all the way to wn. We are seeking to estimate its probability, we can expand this into a product of many terms. Namely the probability of the first word times the probability of the second given the first times the probability of the third, even the first two and so on.</p><p> Know that all I have done here is apply the chain rule of probability, so this is very general. We can make this a little easier on the eyes by collecting these terms with a product operator. If we look at it this way, now we can see that all we have is a product of conditional probabilities over the variable i, which indexes, our words. After the first term, which trivially reduces to the probability of the first word these terms can be interpreted as the probability of the following word. Given all of the previous words, or the history, if you will, the sequential construction helps us see how language models are, in fact generative models of language.</p><p> Indeed, we can easily generate new sequences of words with it, starting from a history of past words. Which could simply be empty, if we are at the beginning of a sentence. We can repeatedly generate new ones by randomly sampling from the conditional probability of the next word, given the history. And this brings us to our first example application, predictive typing. It's quite common these days when performing a search online on any number of platforms to be offered suggestions for what you might want to type next.</p><p> Nowadays a system like this one for a query completion would most likely rely on amongst other things on a language model. It would take the probability distribution of the three words following the partial query the user has entered, and sample from it to offer suggestions. Often this works quite well, and it ends up saving us quite a bit of typing. Sometimes though it doesn't work so well, as in the fictional example I am giving here. What seems to be happening here is that the language model failed to pick up on the fact that we are talking about a backpack.</p><p> So while these suggestions are all grammatically correct and better than randomly sampled words, none of them make a lot of sense. As an aside, I should note that query completion is typically a bit more complicated than this. With more components than just language modeling, but this example is good enough to illustrate the general concept. We've seen predictive typing in search fields as a possible application, but there are more one, which you've probably thought about by now is text completion on your phone. But there's also full sentence completion, which is present in some email clients and assisted typing services Which is able to predict whole sentences rather than just one or two words.</p><p> But language models also used outside of purely text based scenarios, consider for instance, the task of automatic speech recognition, where we take in a recording of a voice and we want to turn that into text. Understanding what was said purely based on the sound can be tricky, as in the example given in the slides. The two sentences, My hair is wet, and My hairy sweat, sound almost exactly the same, and it can be really difficult to tell them apart if we add background noise. How do we know which one was actually said? Well, a language model can easily solve this problem for us as the first option is clearly much more likely than the second. One last example I would like to give you is a basic system for grammar correction, in general, assuming our language model was trained on well formed language.</p><p> A sentence with a mistake in it will have lower probability than its correct version and so this can help us catch mistakes. Note again grammatical error correction is much more complex than this, but certainly language models can play an important role in it. Now recall from a few slides ago, a nice compact way of modeling language. And how we define the probability of a sequence of words as a product of terms, there is a related problem, which I also want to cover briefly. As it is extremely useful and has a ton of applications and that is conditional language modeling, have a look at the new definition.</p><p> All we have done here is condition on an extra term c, other than that nothing else has changed. Note that I am being intentionally vague about what c is, it is by defining exactly what c represents in each case that we will arrive at various applications of Conditional Language Models. So let's do that next, so let's look at some examples. The first is what we could call Topic-aware language modelling, you can imagine that a language model that is aware of the context in which it is being called could perform much better than one which isn't. Let's say that I asked what the probability of the sentence I eat an apple is, and I got a number.</p><p> Now what if I asked that again, but I specified that I am only thinking about the context of car repair manuals. Presumably the probability of I eat an apple, would be much lower there. Another example is text summerization, given a long document as the context c, we could sample from p of s given c to get possible summaries of it. One of my favorite examples is machine translation, if we let c be a French sentence, we can sample from p(s | c) to get possible English translations of it. This will be covered in more detail later on in the course, but we don't have to stick to natural language processing purely, conditional language models are very useful elsewhere to.</p><p> If we let c be an image, then an image captioning model can be seen as a conditional language model. If c is specifically the image of a line of text, then we have optical character recognition or OCR, where the task is to transcribe an image depicting text into the text itself. A final example outside of the field of computer vision speech recognition, here we are letting CBS sound recording. And we want to decode it into external description






<h1>2 Recurrent Neural Networks Part 1 v2</h1><strong>M3L12</strong><hr><p>This is the first of a set of two modules on Recurrent Neural Networks or RNN is a class of neural architectures which are designed to model sequences. Before we delve into how RNNs work, which will be the topic of the next module, in this module, we will discuss why we should care about modelling sequences in the first place. And why we need a new architecture to do it. So where do sequences occur in machine learning? A first example is sound. What you can see here is a spectrogram of my voice saying test.</p><p> Perfectly reasonable way of processing this data would be to split it up and treat it as a sequence of chunks. And this would allow a machine learning model to transcribe it. A related example is optical character recognition. Given an image of a page of text, we could split that up into smaller images of individual characters and try to recognize each one. And we already mentioned sentences, which can be seen as sequences of words.</p><p> A classic example from natural language processing is sentiment analysis. Where we are given a piece of text and we have to classify whether the author was feeling positive or negative when writing it. We have seen that sequences can play different roles. They can be both the input and the output of the model, in which case we have the many to many case, also known as sequence transduction. Example of these tasks are speech recognition, OCR, and a whole class of setups, commonly known as encoder decoder.</p><p> Sequences can also be the inputs to model that produce a single output, such as in all text classification tasks, like sentiment analysis and topic classification. We can also have models that take a single input and produce a sequence like an image captioning model. And finally, we have the much simpler case of models that simply do not deal with sequences at all, such as old school regression problems. Many of our examples in both texts so before we talk about models, let's discuss how we are going to represent this text such that it can be fed to the models. As the first approach, it is good enough to just use a so called one-hot vector representation.</p><p> We will take the list of all possible words in our vocabulary, and then use that to assign an index to each word. The representations of words will then be vectors which are 0 everywhere, except for the entry corresponding to the words index which will be 1. More sophisticated ways of representing words will be discussed later on in this course. So how do we build a neural network that can process inputs which are sequences? We could try using a multi layer perceptron, let's say to build a supervised model to classify the sentiment of text. The inputs would just be the word vectors.</p><p> And we would train the network to perform sentiment classification. This is looking promising. However, we quickly run into problems the moment we try to feed in a different sentence to the network. The sentence here is the wrong length for the network. So what do we do with the bits that don't fit? And here lies one of the problems with using multi layer perceptrons sequence models.</p><p> They cannot easily support variable sized sequences as inputs, and we have to start coming up with hacks to make that work. And we haven't even thought yet of supporting variable sized outputs, but clearly that will be a problem too. Moreover, given that sequences have a time component, it would be useful for sequence models to have an inherent temporal structure. But multi layer perceptrons don't have that. By which I mean that they have no notion that input one comes before input two, and then comes in for three, and so on.</p><p> This notion of ordering isn't built into this type of network. And learning it by training would be difficult. Also, when we are processing sequences of inputs one by one, it is useful to have some mechanism to hold state. Consider the case of text and the word bank for instance. In the sentence I am waiting in line at the bank.</p><p> The word bank has a very different meaning than in the sentence I am sitting by the river bank. If we look at the word in isolation, we have no way of knowing which of the two meaning is the correct one. But if we have a memory of what words have come before we do, the multi layer perceptron might learn from training that if bank appears in position seven and river in position six, then the meaning of bank there is not the financial institution, but this does not generalize. What if these words appear in different positions. What would be much better is to have a general system of holding state, a memory if you will, which the network can access to recall information it has previously seen.</p><p> And finally, another big problem is that within multi layer perceptron the size of the network grows with the size of the longest sequence, we must support.






<h1>3 Recurrent Neural Networks Part 2 v2</h1><strong>M3L12</strong><hr><p>In this second module on recurrent neural networks, we finally get to see how they are implemented. As a reminder, in the previous module, we saw how sequences are ubiquitous in machine learning. We attempted using a multi layer perceptron to model them. And so how do two fundamental limitations of multi layer perceptrons using them to model sequences is more trouble than it's worth. So let's jump straight into it then and introduce recurrent neural networks.</p><p> RNNs are a family of neural architectures which have been designed to model sequences. At every time step they will receive an input and use that to update a state h of t. In order to do so, they also have access to the state and the previous time step h of t minus 1. We can draw the arrow a little differently to illustrate the recursive nature of this process, the yellow box I've labeled f of theta which we will call the cell gets repeatedly cold to update the state. This also explains why these models are called recurrent.</p><p> Mathematically we can just model this as a function f of theta, where theta is used to represent the set of training weights of the network. We can expand this picture along the time axis, by unrolling the previous diagram for n time steps. At time step one, the network receives the first input in the sequence. Computes the state and passes that on. At time step two.</p><p> The state is again updated by looking at both the new input and the previous state, and so on until the last time step. Crucially, the function f of theta that is called repeatedly, it's always the same, giving rise to the recursive nature of RNNs. Going back to our example of sentiment analysis, the final state h of n can be used to predict our label as the network has now seen the whole text. So the outputs of an RNN can either be directly the states of the network. Or they can be computed as a function of those.</p><p> You might also be wondering how backpropagation works when we have recursion in the network. Well, if you unroll it along the time dimension like we've done before, then backpropagation just works as normal. Sometimes this is called backpropagation through time. And the way it works is you run the network forward and compute all the outputs, then you compute the loss as a function of those. And then you run the backward step to compute the gradients for the update.</p><p> If the sequences are very long, the computation graph becomes very long too. Because you have as many layers effectively as you have time steps. And the updates become very expensive. And this is a problem. The solution is known as truncated backpropagation through time where the states are carried forward forever, but we only backpropagate for a fixed number of time steps backward.</p><p> We have looked at RNNs in an abstract sense so far. So let's look at a concrete implementation now. The element RNN, also sometimes called the vanilla RNN. The status update is obtained by performing an offline transformation of the input and the previous state. That is, we multiply the input by a learn matrix, do the same for the state and add a bias term also learned.</p><p> We then apply an activation function and perform an other affine transformation of this plus an application of a potentially different activation function to get the output. The activations used for these networks are typically the logistic function, also known as the logistic sigmoid, or simply the sigmoid, or the hyperbolic tangent, or some other function with similar properties. I should note that I have used the term RNN somewhat colloquially here without giving you a precise definition. The examples have shown you here are what people will commonly understand if you say RNN. Sometimes though the term is also used more formally, to indicate any neural network whose information flow does not follow a directed a cyclic graph.</p><p> >> RNNs in practice can be difficult to train due to a problem known as vanishing gradients. Let's discuss it by looking at a simple example. Consider this trivial RNN which takes an input at timestamp 0 and then repeatedly updates itself by multiplying its state by learn weight. If we look at the gradient of the state at time t with respect to the state at time 0, we see that this is proportional to the weight w theta to the power of t. Now, this is a quantity that we have to deal with in the update rule to train this RNN.</p><p> And the power of t is a problem. The reason is that for large T is the magnitude of w theta is greater than one and the gradient will get very large and update steps will be erratic. On the other hand, if the magnitude is less than one, then the gradients get vanishingly small and the model does not get trained at all. An idea to attempt to alleviate these problems came in the 90s in the form of a different architecture. This was proposed by set off right and Juergen Schmidhuber.</p><p> It is known as the LSTM network or long short term memory network. And these are its object roles. So let's look at them in detail. The first four values defined here are the gates and intermediate values. And we will look at them soon.</p><p> But the main update rules are the two lines at the bottom. Notice that on top of the state HFT, which we already had before, we have an additional cell state CFT. This definition is important in avoiding the vanishing gradient problem. Know that it is updated in an additive way by adding something to its previous value of CFT minus one. This is different from the multiplicative update rule of RNNs, which as we saw in the previous slide got us into trouble.</p><p> Also, we should note that this is fundamentally different from the element RNNs we covered in the previous slides. And many RNNs when unrolled are essentially just feed forward neural networks with our fine transformations and nonlinearities. Instead, this is completely new. With the idea of gating we are now taking parts of the input to the cell and multiplying them together. To get a better feel for how LSTM works.</p><p> Let's look at how an update is performed step by step. We start with the previous cell state c of t minus 1 which is used along with some other values to compute the new cell state. The first value is the forget gate. FT is the result of an offline transformation of the previous hidden state and the current input, pass through a sigmoid so that it lies between zero and one. Intuitively, this gate decides how much of the previous cell state, we want to keep around.</p><p> The two extremes when its value is 0 in which case we forget everything. And when its value is 1, in which case we'll remember everything. But the old cell state is not all we use to compute the new cell state. We also have a cell called candidate update, u of t. Intuitively, this is the new information coming from the input we've just seen.</p><p> This is also modulated by a gate the input gate IFT. Intuitively, this decides how much we should let this particular input affect the cell state. Finally, the update state is used to compute the hidden state, which is the value that can then be used to compute an output. The value of the hidden state is modulated by an output gate, O of T, which decides how much of the sale state we want to service.






<h1>4 Language Modeling Part 2 v2</h1><strong>M3L12</strong><hr><p>In the second part of the module on language modeling, where we'll see how to build and train a language model using recurrent neural networks. As a recap, we saw how language modeling involves estimating a probability distribution over sequences of words. We also looked at recurrent neural networks, a family of neural architectures which are specifically designed to model sequences. The way a language model would work is as follows, assume that we want to compute the probability of a word, given the ones that came before. As we saw previously, the scan of conditional probabilities are central to language modeling.</p><p> In order to do this, we will input the words in the history one by one, then make use of the output of the RNN at the final time step, to perform a prediction. The yellow dots in the inputs are used here to indicate 100 representations, which we previously discussed in the first lecture on RNNs. Of course that's just one possible choice of representations. Let's look at this process step by step. This is the inference part, that is, we are running the model in forward mode only to perform a prediction, assuming it has already been trained.</p><p> We will look at training later. We start, with the first word, in the form of a vector representation of a word. In practice, it's often useful to have a special symbol, be the first word, to indicate to the model that a new sentence is starting. We then feed the words in the history until we run out of history. And then we take the hidden state age, perform a transformation of it.</p><p> To project it to a very high dimensional space that has the same dimension as the number of words in our vocabulary. And then we normalize this vector using a softmax, which leaves us with a probability distribution of what the model believes could be the next word. In this case, people is the word that the model feels the most confident about. Before we look at training, it's useful to be able to measure how well a model is doing at language modeling. If our model is good, it will assign high probabilities to real sentences.</p><p> In order to get a measure of performance, we can use a quantity from information theory known as cross-entropy. Given a reference distribution p star, and the proposed distribution p, cross-entropy is defined as in the slide. Intuitively, this can be seen as the expected number of bits required to represent an event, drawn from the reference distribution p star, when using a coding scheme optimal for p. The exact reason why cross-entropy is defined like this is beyond the scope of this course. But I wanted to mention it as it is used to define a measure that is common in language modeling, and that is per-word cross-entropy.</p><p> This is the cross-entropy averaged over all the words in a sequence. When the reference distribution is the empirical distribution of the words in the sequence. This is commonly used as a loss function, as it is an effective way of measuring how good the model is at estimating probabilities. Another value that is seen in language modeling is perplexity, and it is defined as the geometric mean of the inverse probability of a sequence of words according to the model. Note that we can expand this definition by using the laws of logarithms, where b is any base.</p><p> And we see that the exponent in the second line is just the per-word cross-entropy that was defined in the previous slide. Perplexity is commonly used as an evaluation metric. The lower the perplexity, the better our model is. Now this formula can look fairly hostile, and talking about geometric means of inverse probabilities isn't particularly helpful either. So you may find the following intuition useful.</p><p> The perplexity of a discrete uniform distribution of a k events is k. So if you flip a fair coin and asked me to guess, I'll get it right about half the times. And my perplexity there is two. If you throw a fair die and asked me to guess, I'll get it right on average one sixth of the times, and my perplexity there is six. To train a model, we feed the words one by one, using again the special symbol first to indicate the start of a new sequence.</p><p> After every time step, we've projected a high dimensional space like we did during inference, turn that into a probability distribution and calculate the loss using cross-entropy. Note that at the following time step, what we input into the network is not the word predicted at the previous time step, but the actual word that is present in the training data. This practice is known as teacher forcing, and allows the model to keep training effectively, even if it would have made a mistake in the previous time steps. Once the whole sentence has been fed, the overall loss is computed as the average of the losses for each word. And backpropagation can be used to calculate the values necessary to perform an update step.</p><p>






<h1>5 Masked Language Models v2</h1><strong>M3L12</strong><hr><p>This module introduces the concept of mass language modeling, a task which has been used very effectively in NLP to greatly improve performance in a variety of tasks. You will remember that language models estimate the probability of sequences of words. Masked language modeling is a closely related task, as the name suggests. Assuming we have some NLP tasks that we want to solve, masked language modeling can often be used as a pre-training task. That is, a task which is not the one we ultimately want to solve, but which can still be useful as an extra training signal to find a good set of initial parameters for our model.</p><p> Often, if we first train a model to perform masked language modeling, and then we train it again to perform our final desired task, we will achieve better performance than by just training on the final task alone. Masked language models take as input a sequence of words. They add special symbols to mark the start and the end of sequences, similarly to language models. But they also cover up some of the original words with special tokens that I have marked here with the word mask. We then take the word embeddings corresponding to these words and we feed them into a transformer encoder.</p><p> Since transformer encoders have no inherent notion of position of their inputs, and this is useful for language, we also add to the input some special positional embeddings. This might seem like a horrible hack, and it is in a sense, but in practice it works quite well. The final task is to predict what the masked words are. This is a bit of a strange and artificial task, but it is quite difficult. A model that learns to solve it well will have not only learned a lot about the structure of language, but also about common sense knowledge.</p><p> And indeed, this knowledge is quite useful, as I already mentioned. If we take this model and then train it again to perform some task we are actually interested in, the model will not only learn to perform the new task. But it will also retain part of the knowledge it learned to perform masked language modeling. And this will often give a significant boost in performance. Let's see how this model can then be trained to perform other tasks.</p><p> One type of tasks we might want to perform are token-level tasks, where for each output we want to perform a classification. An example is named entity recognition, which involves identifying which input tokens identify entities such as persons, dates, locations, and so on. Here we would simply input a sentence without any masked tokens. And for the outputs at each position, we would train the network to perform the correct classification. The labels at the top represent the various types of entities, so persons, locations, states, and so on.</p><p> Another type of task is sentence-level tasks, where we are more interested in the global meaning of a sentence. An example is sentence classification. Conventionally here we take the first output of the transformer encoder at the top layer and use that to classify the sentence. In this example, we are performing sentiment analysis again. An interesting development of masked language modeling came when people realized that we didn't have to stick to a single language.</p><p> Consider the following two sentences. The first is in English and the second is its translation in French. We can join them in a single sequence by using a special separator token and then add start and end special tokens again, and similarly to before, also add masked tokens. We can then perform masked language modelling of this sequence. And the model will learn to look at the two translations simultaneously in order to better predict what the masked words are.</p><p> Now, a model pre-trained with cross-lingual masked language modelling can be used in the same way as a model trained with normal masked language modelling, of course. But the real strength of these models comes from cross-lingual transfer. Imagine we took this pre-trained model and further trained it to perform classification using English training data. Because of the cross-lingual nature of its pre-training task, this model would then also be able to perform classification in other languages, even though its training data only covered English. Let's look at another popular cross-lingual task which this model can perform with further training.</p><p> This is a classic NLP task known as natural language inference, or NLI, which we are seeing here and its cross-lingual version. Given two sentences, one and two, the task is to decide whether the first implies the second one or whether it contradicts it, or whether the two sentences are completely unrelated. In this case, the first sentence entails the second one, since if you've had lunch, then you must necessarily have eaten. So far, nothing special. This is all monolingual and we're only looking at English data, really.</p><p> As I previously mentioned, though, what makes this type of model interesting is cross-lingual transfer. So for instance, even if we train the model on a natural language inference data set that only contain English data, we would find that at inference time the model is also able to work, for example, on French data. In this case, the slide depicts the model correctly predicting entailment for these two French sentences, [FOREIGN], which means you had lunch, necessarily implies [FOREIGN], which means you ate. This class of models, which are all based on pre-trained transformers, have been truly revolutionary for NLP. In the graph I am showing you in the slide, I have put along the y-axis the performance on the GLUE benchmark.</p><p> GLUE is a set of tasks which are meant to cover various aspects of NLP. The nature is not important, and I'm just using it as a proxy for measuring roughly how well a model is at performing language-based tasks on average. The graph shows how well various models perform on GLUE, with the dashed line showing human performance. On the x-axis, I have put the number of model parameters to give an indication of how large these models are and how expensive they are to run. As you can see, while transformer-based models have led to an incredible boost in performance, often beating the human baseline, they are also getting incredibly big.</p><p> And this means that they are slower to run, that they are more expensive in terms of computation, memory. And this leads to higher energy costs and a bigger environmental impact. As an aside, I should note here that the fact that these models beat the human baseline doesn't mean much, as these tasks often have small flaws that machines are very good at exploiting. So while performance on the GLUE task in general is certainly correlated with the ability of a model to understand language, performance relative to the human baseline isn't particularly meaningful. In any case, the problem remains that these models are too big.</p><p> Fortunately, there are ways to reduce their size while still maintaining most of their performance. Perhaps the most important is known as knowledge distillation. Consider the standard way of training a generic NLP model. We give some input text, the model performs a prediction. We know what the target answer is from the training data, and so we can use a loss function to encourage the model to learn.</p><p> Knowledge distillation works slightly differently. Assume we have at the top a pre-trained model, which we will call the teacher. This model works amazingly well. However, it's too slow or expensive to run. We will use this big model to teach a smaller model, which we will call the student.</p><p> The input text from the training data will be passed to both models and both will make a prediction. Since we know the target that we want the model to predict, we can use a loss like before. We will call this the student loss, as it only involves the student model. And this is just standard training. Additionally, though, we will also encourage the student model to align its predictions with those of the larger teacher model.</p><p> Why should this be useful, you might wonder. After all, training using the student loss should provide us with all the training signal we need. Why knowledge distillation works as well as it does is still an open research question, which maybe one of you will be able to answer someday. However, we do have some ideas. First, notice that the slide specifically says soft predictions.</p><p> What do I mean by that? Well, assume that the task is to predict a word that has been masked. Let's say that the input sentence is the dog licked its fur and howled, and we mask dog. Now, if we look at the predictions made by the teacher model, which has been pre-trained on a lot of text and is very advanced, you will see that it correctly predicts the word dog. The final prediction, the hard prediction, is not the only bit of interesting information there, though. Notice how wolf and fox also have a fair amount of probability mass, presumably because the teacher model, having been exposed to a lot of text, gained some knowledge of the fact that wolves and foxes also lick their fur and also howl.</p><p> This is why the distillation last between the teacher and the student, which aims to align these probability distributions rather than just the heart predictions, is a useful addition. Instead of just telling us that the right answer is dog and that's it, it also tells us that we want to rank wolf and fox highly. And that contains useful information for the student to learn about the world. Another advantage of knowledge distillation compared to just training the student from scratch is that once we have a teacher, we can go beyond the labeled training data that we have. We could just take any unlabeled text and use the teacher to make predictions on it, which can then be used to augment the training for the student.</p><p> Now let's look concretely at what the distillation loss would be like for a classifier. You will recall we encountered the cross-entropy H when talking about evaluating language models. Now, the cross-entropy between two distributions takes its minimum value when the two distributions are the same. For this reason, it is often used as a loss function for distillation, where the aim is to bring as close as possible the target and student models' predictive distributions. So then for a given example for which the teacher model has predictive distribution t and the student model s, the distillation loss is simply the cross-entropy between them.</p><p> The other common loss function here is the very closely related KL divergence. For the other term of the loss, the student loss, this would just be a classification loss. A standard choice here would be again the cross-entropy loss. Although this time, it would be between the empirical distribution y, which is just one for the true label and zero everywhere else, and the student model's predictive distribution s. For the total loss, this is simply given by a linear combination of these two terms.</p><p> Now, for further details on this topic, I will recommend you read the excellent 2015 paper by Hinton and others, Distilling the Knowledge in a Neural Network. I've also listed within the references a more recent paper, which shows the application of distillation specifically to masked language models.






<h1>0 Embeddings Introduction</h1><strong>M3L13</strong><hr><p>Welcome to the lecture on Embeddings. I'm Ledell Wu, a research engineer at Facebook AI Research. I work on large-scale and general purpose embeddings and entity linking. I also studied learners and biases in LP models. In this lecture, I will be talking about the following topics.</p><p> First, I'll start with word embeddings. Word embeddings plays a very important role in NLP and applications. From the last class, you may have learned about LSTM and RNNs. The word embeddings can be used as the initialization of lookup table in LSTM and RN models. So I will only talk about the high level ideas around word embeddings.</p><p> And if you're interested to know more about it, there are great online resources. Next, I will also introduce graph embeddings briefly. Graph embeddings can be seen as a generalization of word embeddings, which also has a great body of work in research and application. Then I will be focusing more on the application side of embeddings. In this part, I will give you several concrete examples of how to use word or graph embeddings for different tasks, including ranking, recommendation, classification and tagging, and so on.</p><p> The idea comes from the question of whether we can embed everything. Like a user or a piece of content, can we use it to to determine if one person is going to like a piece of content, or if two people are likely to become friends? At the end, I will talk about some additional topics I will mention about hierarchical embeddings as well as the issue around fairness and biases in word embeddings. So, in a nutshell, embeddings can be viewed as mapping objects to vectors through a trainable function. In previous lectures, we've learned about neural nets such as CNN where it maps an image into a vector in real space. Similarly, we can map other things such as text into a vector.</p><p> Typically, the neural net can be seen in RNN or a transformer for text, or simply a shallow one, such as word2vec. Here is a picture illustrating mapping different objects into the same space. Usually the distance between the vectors in the space is used as a similarity function for different objects. For instance, we want to map similar objects closer in the space. In this case, at the upper right, there's a video about a birthday cake.</p><p> And then it's mapped to close to the text Happy Birthday and hashtag IamOld. For the rest of the lecture, we will be talking about how we're going to learn the vectors of different objects. At the end of the lecture, you will have an idea of what are word embeddings and graph embeddings and how they're learned. You'll also learn how to use those embeddings in applications and what kind of tasks can benefit from it such as recommendation, tagging, search, etc. You'll also get an idea of how large scale computing words for learning embeddings.</p><p>






<h1>1 Word Embeddings</h1><strong>M3L13</strong><hr><p>The search for good representation of word has been a long-term pursue in NLP. The idea of distributional semantics is if you know what contexts to use a certain word, then you understand the meaning of a word. As J.R.Firth said, you shall know a word by the company it keeps and it is one of the most successful idea of modern statistical NLP.</p><p> When a word w appears in text, its context is the set of words that appear nearby with a fixed-size window. And then you can use the many contexts of w to build up a representation of w. So the meaning of the word can usually be inferred by the words around it. For instance, the example of banking, if we know the context of many examples where banking is used, we can infer the meaning of it. There is a series of work based on idea of knowing word representations using neural networks.</p><p> The work by Yoshua Bengio in 2003, A Neural Probabilistic Language Model, proposes the following. Associate in each word in the vocabulary, a distributed word feature vector,and it uses a neural network model essentially trying to predict the next word. And later, the work by Ronan Collobert and Jason Weston and other collaborators used convolution neural net to know what embeddings the word vectors and other parameters of the neural net is chained on several different tasks including language model, entity recognition, and part of speech tag accenture was sharing the word vectors. And it showed that it's useful for all these tasks, and they also looked at the nearest neighbor of the word vectors and find that it displays syntactic and semantic properties of words. More recently, Thomas Mikolov et al proposed a relatively simple model called, Word2vec, which is really efficient to compute where the word vectors are the only parameters to be known in the model because of these efficiency and powerful bonuses because wide adoptions in both NLP research and applications.</p><p> Now I'll introduce briefly about the Collobert and Weston vectors. The idea comes from that a word and its context is a positive training example. And a random word in the simple context gives a negative example. So in this example, the positive example is the phrase cat chills on a mat. And if we take a random word, Ohio, the negative example becomes cat chills Ohio a mat.</p><p> Obviously, that doesn't make much sense. Then the score is calculated by a neural net built on top of the word vectors, and we wanna penalize a score of cat chills Ohio a mat and optimize the score of cat chills on a mat, the positive example. So here we use a margin loss on it. This is similar to the ideas in support vector machine where you want to increase the margin between the positive and negative examples. Is also noticeable that we only need positive examples in the training and negative examples or draw from random words.</p><p> So in this case a random word from the dictionary. In the later part of the lecture, I'll talk more about finding negative samples or negative sampling as it is plays a very important role in different embedding models. Next, I'll talk about what to pack in a bit more details. The idea is to use word to predict the context words. This is the skip-gram model.</p><p> There's also the continuous pack of words, model you want to pack which are not covered here. The context is a fixed window size 2m. Let's take a look at this following example. So here is a example, the context window is size two, and we'll have part of the sentence as problems turning into banking crisis. Assuming the word into is the center word.</p><p> So we hope to use the vector representation of what into to predict what will be in the context of into. We'll try to make those predictions and change the vector representations in a way that we can do the prediction better. Similarly, we go on to the next word banking and essentially we'll do the same thing. More formally, we write in the following formula as skip-gram objective function. For each position t, predicting the context words within a window of fixed size m given the center word Wj and we multiply all those probabilities to be our, likelihood and here theta is all the parameters to be optimised.</p><p> So the objective function is the average negative log likelihood. Note that in this particular model, the parameters to optimize owning the word vectors, and this is simpler than the earlier neural net models and also it enables very fast computation, the question then becomes how to calculate the probability. In what you back model, it proposes two vectors to represent each word. One, when the word is the centre word and one for when the word is a context word. Then it uses inner product to measure how likely where w appears with context word o, and if the inner product of these two vectors is bigger, the probability is bigger and if the inner product is smaller then the probability is smaller.</p><p> So this is the softmax form that we've learned earlier in the class, and the probability falls within the range of zero to one and sums up to one and two sets of vectors are the parameters in this model. So we can do Stochastic gradient descent on softmax function, but the problem is that it's very expensive to compute because the size of the vocabulary is very big, usually, tens of thousands or hundreds of thousands, make it impossible to compute. So there are two solutions. One is to use hierarchical softmax and the other is to use negative sampling. I'll skip the hierarchical softmax and talk about negative sampling.</p><p> Remember that computing the probability is very expensive as it requires to compute all the vectors in the vocabulary. The intuition for negative sampling is that for each chain examples, but only update the network with selecting a random set of word work vectors. So for each w, c pair, we want to sample k negative pairs w, c prime for the k choosing in the set of like 5, 10, 20 and wants to maximize the probability that the real outside word appears and minimize the probability that random words appear around center words. So this is similar to the ideas in the Collobert and Weston vectors were random negative examples drawn. Say we were to vec a specific distribution of words based on the word, for Chrissie, is chosen to shun the best performance, it makes less frequent words to be sampled more often.</p><p> There are other family of what embeddings, which also have been widely used, they differ in several aspects, such as algorithms, text corpora, dimensions, accenture, for instance, globe where the training of the embedding is performed or aggregated global word [INAUDIBLE] statistics from corporates. Fast text, which is also from Facebook's AI and has wide adoptions, it adds some more information in addition to what you pack, which better handles out of vocabulary words, and it's also available in more than 200 different languages. It's shown to be very efficient for text classification tasks. So, you can find us pertained word vectors through the links here and a common way of using the embeddings is to use the especies in downstream ml models, or as initialisation of neural net models for an NLP such as r and stm. And finally, more recently, the context tries to word embeddings has becoming very popular such as Elmo and Bert.</p><p> So it will be covered in detail in later lectures. Now I want to talk about how to evaluate wording beddings as evaluation is always a very important part. There are mainly two categories of evaluations, namely, intrinsic ones and extrinsic ones. In intrinsic evaluation wording embeddings are usually evaluated on a specific internode task and such as checking the nearest neighbor of a particular word of vector and is usually fast to compute. So you can check the quality of the word embeddings during training, maybe helps you to understand what model is learning.</p><p> And, however, it is not clear whether it really helps in real tasks. On the extrinsic ones, it's usually evaluated on a real task, so it can take a long time to compute. And another issue is if the result is not as good, then it's unclear if the problem comes from the word embedding or from the interaction, the word embedding and other systems. So a common way of serving this is to keep the other parts fixed and only intended to word embeddings, if that improves metric, then it usually tells you that the word embeddings is of better quality. And we also use this approach for evaluate other embeddings such as graphing embeddings, I will talk about later.</p><p> One interesting example of intrinsic word embedding evaluation is the word analogy task. In this task, we have a pair of word man and woman and also a word, king. We wanted to know which word to king has the same relation as women to men. We observed that the trained word embeddings have the following property. Evaluate word vectors by how well their cosine distance after addition captures intuitive semantic and syntactic and analogy questions.</p><p> If you find the vector that satisfy the formula on the right top, you will find the vector as queen. This is really interesting as you can find this type of relation by simply doing additions and subtractions of the work factor. There are more examples in the following links that you can try to find out. For extrinsic variations, I will give some examples in the application sections.






<h1>2 Graph Embeddings</h1><strong>M3L13</strong><hr><p>Graphs are networks of entities and connections between them. They can be used to present stuff like protein structures or map data or networks of people's interactions. Multi relation graph embeddings are typically studied in the context of knowledge graphs. So you can have these graphs of structured Wikipedia data, like Freebase that include facts about the world. And there are other similar graphs like word ontologies.</p><p> There are also related areas of study such as a recommender system and embedding methods like Deep Work that were primarily designed to operate on social graphs. From last section, we talked about word embeddings. And you can think of it as defining a graph where each word to be a node and the node has an edge to its context word in sentences. And word embedding models like Word2vec are essentially learning the embeddings of the graph node, which is the word. Let's take a look at an example here.</p><p> This is also known as matrix completion, where you have a big matrix and you know some neighbors, labels, between persons and items. For instance, you know that person one likes item two and do not like item one. They're also some missing entries in the matrix. Whether they are relations between items and people and the items can be people, can be movies, pages, articles, products, word sequences, and you like to predict if someone likes an item or a word, or follow a word sequence. So you can know the vector representation of people and items here such that some simple form of the function between these two vectors will fit the existing value in the matrix and predicting the unknowns.</p><p> So that is a particular case that we want to use graphing embeddings for. So what is graph embedding? Here we define embeddings as a learned map from entities to vector of numbers that encode similarity. A mapping is just an algorithm that converts entities with relations to vectors or features that include similarities. For word embeddings, you enter features such that the features of a word is similar to the features of the words surrounding it. For graph emeddings, you enter features that connected nodes are more similar than unconnected nodes.</p><p> And enter these embeddings by optimising this objective by Stochastic gradient descent. In other words, we are talking about graph node embeddings here. And note that you can also do path embedding in the graph structure embedding, which we will not cover in the lecture. Just as word embeddings, graph embeddings are a form of unsupervised learning on graphs. It can be used as task agnostic entity representations.</p><p> The features are useful on downstream tasks without much data. And the nearest neighbors are semantically meaningful. Now I'm going to introduce a particular family of graph embeddings. This is from the open source project PyTorch BigGraph that I worked on with Adam Lerer and others, where we implemented several graph embeddings algorithms in a large scale setting. Here I'm going to talk about a family of graph embeddings that we spurred in PyTorch BigGraph and essentially the way that we train those embeddings.</p><p> So given that we have a motor relation graph like the one on the left, where different colors of the edges representing different relations, we want to optimize the loss function L such that for a simple function of an edge e, and a negative sampled edge, e prime, we want to minimize the margin loss as similar to the loss in the column by western vectors if you remember from the word embedding class. So the simple function f can be overruled in the word embedding, such as the dot product or cosine between the two vectors of the nodes of an edge, except here we'll add a transformed version of the destination node of an edge to represent the type of the edge. So theta s is the source vector and theta d is the destination vector and theta r is the relation vector. In addition to the node vectors, we also name parameters of different relation types of the edges. So the negative samples are constructed by taking a real edge and replacing the source or destination node with a random node.</p><p> This again is similar to the negative sampling technique for word embeddings, if you recall. Let's take a particular edge here as the edge b to c. So essentially the loss function is saying that we want the distance between the vector b and the transformed vector of b to be close and the distance between vector b and the transformed version of a and e to be large, as there's no edge between them. Similarly, we'll do this again for positive edge b to c and negative edges a to c and d to c. So the loss can be again optimized by Sgde, and this is how the graph node embeddings and parameters of the relation's transformations learned.</p><p> So here are the different types of relations that we spurred in PyTorch BigGraph. The first one is identity where we treat every edge to be the same, this fall into the case where all the age is the same type in the graph. The second one is a translator where we use a vector to represent a particular edge type and then we add the edge type vector to the node vector. This is from the Transient model by Bordes et al, 13. So we can also do a fine translation where we have a matrix A and a translator vector delta for each edge type, and we do multiplication of the matrix A and node vector plus this translator, this is from Nickel et al, 11', where it allows more complicated transformation then the translator model.</p><p> It also has more parameters to be entered. And then we could also have the diagonal transformation from Yang et al, 15', where we have a vector b wedge type and we multiply each dimension of b with the corresponding dimension of x. What can we do with the new graphing embeddings? Here is an example from embedding a knowledge base. This is from Bordes et al, 13, the Transient model. So we have a subgraph from Freebase, where it has the entities like Clooney, actor, male, and the relations between the entities.</p><p> We can enter a graph embedding on the knowledge graph, then for a question like, who did Clooney marry in 1987? You also have embeddings of the question through the word embedding table. You can then detect the entity in the question and find the corresponding entity in the Freebase subgraph. And to find the relevant entity to answer for this question through the entity embeddings. So that's the high level idea. So again, we're gonna talk more about examples of how to use graph embeddings in the application section.</p><p> So let's take a look at two dimensional Disney visualization of the entire Wikidata graph from the PyTorch BigGraph project. So we follow the method in transient, but we scaled it to 55 mini entities in 3 billion edges, with 5000 different relations. This is a huge graph. The picture on the left is the visualization of the top 500 popular entities on Wikidata projected in two dimensions. As you can see in the graph, we have several clusters, which is quite meaningful.</p><p> For instance, the lumbers are clustered together and from the top cluster in the middle you can see different occupations. And there's a cluster of countries on the left bottom and the entity embeddings known on the knowledge graph exhibit certain behaviors in the vector space and you can usually find meaningful clusters. We will see those properties again in the applications section. So in order to chain embeddings fast on a giant graph like Wikidata, which I just showed you, we need to optimize a lot of things. One thing that is particularly helpful is what we called optimized negative sampling.</p><p> So recall in the previous section that we're talking about sampling negative nodes to construct fake edges, but the chaining time is dominated by computing the scores for fake edges. But how can we speed that up?
